voice_to_text: Sister in law snooped and stole our baby's name, then announced it right after she gave birth. But her face immediately dropped when she realised that we tricked her. My sister in law, Maya, has always been competitive with me since the day I married her brother, Jake. She couldn't handle that someone else was getting attention and what she considered her family. When Jake and I got engaged, I tried to announce her own engagement at our party. When we bought our first house, she suddenly started house hunting, too. So when we both ended up pregnant at the same time, I knew the competition was about to get intense. Maya was due just two weeks before me. And from the moment we announced, she became absolutely obsessed with finding out our baby name choice. At first it started innocently enough. She'd casually ask during family dinners, have you guys thought about names yet? When we'd discuss, she'd push harder. Come on, just give me a hint. But then it escalated. Maya started showing up at our house unannounced, trying to peek at any baby books we had lying around. She'd walk through our nurse free and comment on everything, clearly fishing for clues. She even asked my mother in law to pressure us into sharing our choice. The breaking point came when I caught her literally going through our mail when she thought we weren't looking. She was flipping through baby magazines and packages desperately searching for any Evidence of our name decision, my husband thought I was being paranoid when I told him I suspected Maya wanted to steal our name and use first. She wouldn't do that, he said, but I knew better. This was exactly the kind of petty move Maya would pull. That's when I decided to set a trap. I created blank interest boards filled with names I'd never actually consider using. I strategically left a notebook open on our kitchen counter with Final Decision written in big letters next to the name Aurora Rose. When Maya came over for dinner, I even coordinated with my mom to call me while Maya was within earshot, having a completely fake conversation about how Aurora fits so perfectly with your family naming tradition and I'm so excited you finally decided. Maya took the bait completely. Over the next few weeks, she started casually bringing up the name Aurora in random conversations, testing how we'd react. Aurora is such a beautiful name, don't you think, she'd say. Watching our faces carefully, I played along perfectly, acting slightly uncomfortable whenever she mentioned it, like she'd stumbled onto our secret. Two weeks later, Maya went into labor. Within an hour of giving birth, she posted on Facebook, welcome to the world, Baby Aurora Rose. Our little princess has finally arrived. The whole family flooded the comments with congratulations, but I noticed Maya kept checking to see if I'd responded. She was clearly waiting for my reaction to her Surprise. The next day at the hospital, Maya was practically glowing with smugness when I walked into her room. She actually had the audacity to say, I hope you don't mind that we ended up using Aurora when she was born. It just felt so right for our daughter. I know you guys were considering it, too. That's when I pulled out my phone and showed her our real pic.

Charge them the same family rate they charged me. So my kids daycare had some family emergency and shut down for the day. They sent this email at like 3 in the morning, which was real helpful when I'm already asleep and have to work the next day. I'm scrambling around trying to find someone to watch my kid because I literally could not miss work that day. Had this huge presentation that would basically make or break my job. So I'm calling everyone I know at like 6:00am. The only person who picks up is my stepbrother's girlfriend, Ashley. She doesn't work, just sits around all day while my stepbrother pays for everything. I mean everything. Her daily Starbucks runs, weekly nail appointments, a whole designer purse collection. been trying to get her to do literally anything productive for years. But whatever, I'm desperate. I call her up, and she's like, oh, sure, I can totally watch him for you. I'm thinking, finally, someone's actually gonna help me out. Then she hits me with it. My family rate is $200 for six hours. I literally had to ask her to repeat that because I thought I heard wrong. $200 for six hours to watch one kid who mostly just plays with his tablet anyway? Are you being serious right now? I asked. She goes on this whole speech about how this is her livelihood and she takes childcare very seriously and that she's already giving me a family Discount. I'm thinking, what livelihood? You haven't worked a day since you moved in with my stepbrother three years ago. But I'm stuck. If I don't show up to work that day, I'm literally getting fired. So I agree to her insane price, and she demands the money up front before I even drop my kid off. I hand over $200 cash, drive to work fuming, and end up working barely four hours after you factor in traffic. So I basically paid 50 bucks an hour for her to sit on her couch and make sure my kid didn't burn the house down. Fast forward two years. Ashley and my stepbrother break up, but somehow she ends up living rent free in his dad's extra house and driving my dad's old car. My stepbrother still pays all her bills because they have a kid together. Now. She finally gets a job at some retail place because he stopped funding her weekly spa days. Then last month, I get this panicked text in our family group chat. Emergency. My babysitter bailed, and I have to work today or I'll get fired. Can anyone watch my daughter, please? I'm desperate. I'm reading this text, and I can't help but smile a little. I text her back super fast, I can totally help you out. I'll watch her. She's so relieved and grateful, sending me heart emojis and everything. Then I hit her with the kicker. My family rate is $200 for the Day, the typing bubbles appear and disappear, like, five times. Then my phone starts blowing up. Are you kidding me right now? That's way too much. I thought we were family. You're being ridiculous. Just screenshot our old conversation from two years ago and send it back to her. This is the exact same rate you charged me. You said it was the family rate, remember? You said you took this very seriously. She completely lost it. Started calling me every name in the book, saying I was petty and vindictive and that she was in a real emergency. I told her that's exactly what I said to her two years ago. The best part? She ended up having to call out of work anyway because nobody else would watch her kid for free on such short notice. And apparently, her manager was not happy about it.

Weirdest thing someone's ever paid you to do. This rich kid at my college paid me $500 to take his final exam. For him not cheat. Literally show up as him. See, Brad was this trust fund baby who partied through freshman year while I worked three jobs just to afford ramen. His dad threatened to cut him off if he failed chemistry. And Brad was looking at a solid F. Problem was, Brad and I looked almost identical. Same height, same messy brown hair. Even wore the same thick rimmed glasses. People mixed us up constantly. Which gave Brad a brilliant idea. He cornered me outside the library one Tuesday, panic in his eyes. You're a science major, right? Just walk in, take the test, walk out. 500 cash. I thought he was insane, but $500 was two months of rent money. My bank account had $47 in it, and my landlord was already leaving threatening notes. So I agreed to the stupidest plan ever. For two weeks, I lived and breathed chemistry. I memorized Brad's textbook, practiced his signature until my hand cramped. Even Learned to write with my left hand, since he was left handed. I studied his social media to copy his mannerisms. The kid barely knew what carbon was, but I was determined to nail this thing. I even got his roommate to help me practice. You need to slouch more, he said. Brad never sits up straight, and he always taps his pen when He's thinking the day of the exam, I showed up 20 minutes early, put up trying to look casual. My hands were shaking as I walked into the lecture hall. 200 students, and I was pretending to be someone else. The professor barely glanced at Brad student ID when I handed it over. Good luck, Bradley, he said without looking up. I found Brad's usual seat in the back corner and sat down. My heart was pounding so loud, I thought everyone could hear it. When they handed out the test, I felt confident. The first 30 questions were exactly what I'd studied. Molecular structures, chemical equations, periodic table stuff. I was flying through it. Then I hit question 47. Describe the quantum mechanical model of electron behavior in metallic bonding under extreme pressure conditions. I stared at the question for five full minutes. This wasn't just advanced chemistry. This was graduate level theoretical stuff. I'd never seen anything like it in Brad's textbook. That's when it hit me. Brad had been skipping so much class, he'd missed entire units. The professor had been covering cutting edge research while Brad was passed out in his dorm. I was complete. We screwed. Panic set in. I looked around the room. Everyone else was writing furiously. Some girl in the front row was already on the back page. I had two choices. Leave half the test blank and guarantee Brad fails, or make something up and hope for partial credit. So I Started inventing chemistry. I wrote about electrons forming pressure cascades and quantum tunnels under extreme conditions. I made up equations that sounded scientific but were complete nonsense. I described metals becoming molecularly fluid and electrons fade. He's shifting into higher dimensions. It was like writing science fiction, but with chemical formulas. When I handed in the test, the professor actually looked up from his papers. He flipped through my answers with raised eyebrows. Interesting approach, Bradley, he said slowly.

Prince, how did the system fail your child? The school called me during a client meeting. Your daughter won't stop crying. We need you here now. My stomach dropped. Maya never cried at school. She was my tough girl who scraped her knee last month and asked for a Spider Man Band Aid while blood ran down her leg. I left my presentation half finished and drove like the world was ending. The secretary's face was pale when I walked in. She pointed down the hall without speaking. That scared me more than the phone call. Maya sat curled in the corner of the nurse's office, arms wrapped around her knees. Her favorite purple dress was torn at the shoulder. The butterfly hair clips I'd put in that morning were gone. When I touched her arm, she jerked away like I was made of electricity. Baby, what happened? I whispered. She wouldn't look at me. Just kept staring at the wall with empty eyes. The nurse shifted uncomfortably and told me Maya hadn't said a word since PE class ended. Missus Johnson brought her in like this. I took Maya home. She sat in the back seat, not her usual spot, next to me. That night, she wouldn't eat her favorite Mac and cheese, wouldn't watch cartoons. Just sat on her bed holding her stuffed elephant while helping her into pajamas. I saw them. Finger shaped bruises on her upper arms. Dark purple marks where someone had grabbed her hard. My hands shook. Maya, who did this? She finally looked at me. Her voice came out so small. Mister Garcia said if I tell, he'll hurt you. He said nobody believes little girls anyway. Mister Garcia, the PE teacher parents loved because he coached the winning soccer team. The one who high fived kids in the hallway, who'd been teaching for 15 years. I called 9 1 1 that night. The female officer who interviewed Maya was gentle, patient. Maya told her everything. How Mister Garcia took her to the equipment room during class. How he made her play a secret game. How it hurt. How he did it to other girls, too, during their special practice time. The principal called me at six am. Not to apologize, to scold me. He said I should have come to him first. That calling police was premature. That Mr. Garcia was a valued member of their community. I recorded the entire call.

You ever been asked to explain your ankle monitor at Disney World? The Disney princess stopped mid autograph, stared at my ankle, then at my six year old daughter, Emma, then back at my ankle. Sir, is that she started clearly breaking character, which apparently requires something serious at the Happiest place on earth. It's not what you think, I said quickly, but Cinderella was already flagging security. Within minutes, I was surrounded by three guards and mouse ear hats trying to look threatening, while tourists took photos of what they assumed was part of the show. Here's the thing. I'm not a criminal. The ankle monitor was court ordered, but not for the reason everyone assumes. My ex wife, Patricia, claimed I was a flight risk during our custody battle. Said I might take Emma to Brazil because I'd renewed my passport. I renewed it for a work conference in Toronto. Judge still ordered the monitor as a caution until custody was finalized. I've been wearing it for three months, setting off every metal detector in Orange County. Emma didn't understand why Cinderella looked scared. Daddy, why is the princess sad? I knelt down, ankle monitor clicking against the pavement. She's just confused about daddy's special bracelet. Security moved closer. One spoke into his radio, we have a code yellow in fantasy land. I didn't know what that meant, but it sounded bad. Tourists started pulling their kids away from us. One mom loudly whispered, that's why we check The registry, Karen. The head of security, a surprisingly intimidating man named Raul, escorted us to Disney jail. Yes, that's a real thing. It's a small office behind Main Street that smells like churros and broken dreams. Emma thought it was a VIP experience. Are we getting special Mickey ears? She asked. Raul pulled up my information on his computer. His expression shifted from suspicious to confused to sympathetic. City battle? He asked quietly. I nodded. He sighed. My brother went through the same thing. Judge made him wear one for six months because his ex said he'd flee to Cuba. He's never even been to Cuba. Raul made some calls 20 minutes late. Later, we had a Disney escort. Not because I was dangerous, but because Raul felt bad. No kids should have their Disney trip ruined by adult problems, he said. Our escort, Jerome, was a former NBA player who'd retired to work at Disney because he loved making kids happy. Emma rode on his shoulders the entire day. We skipped every line, got front row seats to every show. Jerome told everyone I was a special guest, which technically wasn't a lie. The ankle monitor kept setting off the sensors on rides. Space Mountain stopped three times because of me. They had to manually override the system. By the third ride, the operators knew me by name. Ankle monitor dad is back, they'd radio ahead. It became a running joke. One operator said, you know, we've had Weapons, drugs, even a snake once. But you're our first ankle monitor. I chose to take that as an achievement. Plot twist came at dinner. We were at the character meal when goofy sat down at our table. He pointed at my ankle, then did an elaborate MIME of being arrested, going to court, then being innocent. Emma laughed hysterically. Goofy's silly daddy. But then goofy pulled out his phone.

Dad said I dressed like a slut and told me to cover up. So I gave him exactly what he asked for. It started when I wore a tank top and shorts to the grocery store on a 90 degree day. You're not leaving the house dressed like a SLT, my dad said. While I was grabbing my car keys, I looked down at my completely normal summer outfit. Cover yourself up because I'm not having my daughter walking around looking like she's for sale, he continued. His face red with anger. I went back upstairs and changed into jeans and a hoodie despite the heat. And he nodded approvingly while saying this was about respect and dignity and protecting my reputation. That night I did some online shopping with his credit card since he cared so much about my clothing choices. Thank you for helping me understand modesty, I said. The next morning wearing a full length denim dress that covered everything except my hands and face. He seemed pleased until we got to his office barbecue where everyone kept asking if I was feeling okay and why I was dressed for winter. She's exploring modest fashion, he explained uncomfortably, while his co workers exchanged concerned looks and I stood there sweating through three layers of fabric. Monday, I wore a beekeeper's suit to school because dad had been very clear about covering up and protecting myself from unwanted attention. The principal called him within an hour asking if Everything was alright at home and whether I was being forced to wear extreme religious garments, it just a phase, my dad told them. But I made sure to explain loudly in the main office that my father said my body was shameful and needed to be completely hidden from men's eyes. The counsellor started taking notes while my dad's face turned purple. Tuesday brought his important client dinner at the country club and I arrived in a full birka. I'd ordered express shipping from Amazon. This is our daughter, my dad said weekly, as his Japanese investors stared in complete confusion. They kept asking questions about our family's religious beliefs and whether this was common in American households while I sat silently eating through my face covering. His biggest client pulled him aside to discuss their concerns about doing business with someone who had such extreme views about women. And I heard my dad desperately trying to explain it was just teenage rebellion. Wednesday, I upgraded to a hazmat suit for his company picnic because he'd mentioned Protection so many times that biological Protection seemed appropriate. His boss's wife cornered him by the potato salad to express her deep concern about what was happening in our home. If you need resources for controlling behavior or religious extremism, we have employee assistance programs, she said, while I stood nearby in my yellow containment suit explaining to anyone who asked that my dad said my skin was too dangerous to be Exposed to the public, Thursday was parent teacher conferences and I wore a Victorian morning dress, complete with a black veil that covered my entire face. My teacher asked my dad Point Blank if he was abusing me or forcing me into a cult while I sat there looking like a Gothic ghost from 1850. She seems to be crying for help, the teacher said sternly, while my dad tried to explain that I was doing this to myself. But she'd already seen my essay about how my father called me a slut for wearing normal clothes. Friday, I went full throttle when I wore a full medieval suit of armour to his promotion announcement dinner because nothing says covered up like actual metal plating. The clanking drew everyone's attention as I walked in and his regional manager immediately asked why his daughter was dressed like she was going into battle. My dad says my body is a weapon that needs to be contained. I announced to the entire restaurant and several people took out their phones to record while my dad tried to disappear into his chair. His promotion was put on hold pending an investigate into his home situation. Saturday morning, the neighbours had organised an intervention after seeing me mow the lawn in a radiation suit all week. We're concerned about your daughter's well being, Mrs. Jacob said, while six other concerned parents stood behind her. They documented everything with photos and time, time stamps, creating what they Called evidence of escalating abuse. My dad kept insisting I was doing this to spite him, but I maintained perfect innocence and said I was just following his rules about modesty and covering my shame full body. By Sunday, his girlfriend had dumped him via text, she couldn't date someone who psychologically tortured his daughter. His boss had suggested he take family leave to deal with his issues and Child Protective Services had opened a case file after receiving 17 different reports from concerned citizens. He sat at the kitchen table with his head in his hands while I stood there in my newest purchase, which was a full deep sea diving suit, complete with brass helmet. Please stop this, he begged. But I reminded him that he said I dressed like a slut and needed to cover up. Fine. Wear whatever you want, he said in defeat. But then his phone rang and his lawyer's name appeared on the screen. My mom had heard about everything from concerned friends and was filing for.

Airport gate, waiting for my delayed flight when they announced they needed volunteers to give up their seats for an over booked flight. The compensation was $800 plus a hotel voucher. This businessman in an expensive suit storms over and taps my shoulder. Hey, you should volunteer. I have a million dollar deal closing tomorrow. I politely told him I had an important interview and couldn't give up my seat. His face turned red. Do you know who I am? I fly first class every week. You look like you could use that $800 more than I need this hassle. I said no again and put my headphones back on. But he wouldn't let it go. He sits down right next to me. Listen, I'm trying to be nice here. That interview can be rescheduled. My deal can't. I told him he didn't know anything about my situation and asked him to leave me alone. He laughs and pulls out his phone. What company? I probably know the CEO. I. I can make one call and get you a better position. I ignored him completely and moved to a different seat across the gate area. He actually follows me and sits down again. You're making this harder than it needs to be. I'm offering to help you out here. Other passengers started noticing this guy literally following me around the gate area, starts talking loudly to anyone who listen. Can you believe this? I offered to compensate him personally and He's being completely unreasonable. A woman with kids nearby asked him to keep it down because he was being, he turns to her and says, ma'am, I'm trying to solve a problem here. Then he goes back to the gate agent and I hear him say, that guy over there refuses to volunteer. Can't you just bump him instead? The gate agent explains that's not how it works and they need actual volunteer. He storms back over to me with this entitled smirk, fine. The gate agent suggested I negotiate directly with passengers. I told him the gate agent definitely didn't say that and he was lying. His voice gets even louder. I've been flying for 20 years and I've never met someone so stubborn. Now half the gate is watching this spectacle he's creating. He pulls out his business card and waves it around. I'm a senior partner at Donaldson and Associates. Look it up. Nobody cared about his business card, but he kept waving it anyway. Then he starts approaching other passengers, asking if they'll volunteer and pointing at me saying, he won't do it, so maybe you will. This college kid tells him, dude, leave him alone. You volunteer if it's so important. Snapped back, I'm in first class. They can't bump me. It has to be someone from economy. The college kid laughs and says, then deal with it like everyone else. He's getting more aggressive now, pacing around the gate area and complaining loudly to Anyone who'll make eye contact, then he pulls out his wallet. Fine, I'll give you 1,000 cash right now. Just take the voucher, I told him.

Barber stopped cutting and asked, why do you have the same tattoo as the missing person poster outside? I froze in the chair, Scissors still hovering over my head. What missing person poster, I asked. But Tony was already walking to the window. He pointed at a flyer taped to the glass outside his shop. That one missing guy named Jake Morrison. Same eagle tattoo on the left shoulder blade, same scar through the wing. From what I can see. My stomach dropped because my name was Jake Morrison and I definitely had that exact tattoo. Tony, that's probably just a coincidence. Lots of people have eagle tattoos. But Tony was shaking his head, studying my reflection in the mirror. Jake, I've been cutting your hair for two years. Never seen your full name anywhere until today. And this poster says, Jake Morrison went missing three months ago. He showed me his appointment book, but you've been coming here every month like clockwork. I twisted around to look at the poster through the window. The photo was grainy and taken from a distance, but it definitely looked like me. Same build, same hair color, same general features. This has to be some mistake, I said, but my voice sounded shaky even to me. Maybe there's another Jake Morrison with a similar tattoo. Tony pulled the poster off his window and brought it inside. Says, here, he disappeared from Portland, Oregon, on March 15th. His family's offering a ten thousand dollar reward. He looked at me carefully. Jake, where were you living before you moved here? I tried to remember, but my memories before arriving in this town were surprisingly fuzzy. I came from the East Coast, I said. But even as I said it, I wasn't sure if that was true. Been traveling around for work. Tony raised an eyebrow. What kind of work? I opened my mouth to answer and realized I couldn't remember what I told him. Before construction, I said finally, but it felt like a guess. Tony set down his Scissors completely. Jake, this is serious. If this is you on this poster, your family thinks you're dead or kidnapped. Are people looking for you? He pulled out his phone. Maybe we should call the number and clear this up. My heart started racing and I didn't know why wait, I said, grabbing his wrist. Let me think about this first. If I call that number and it's not me, I'll be wasting everyone's time. And if it is me, I trailed off because I couldn't finish that thought. If it was me, then I had no memory of having a family or disappearing from anywhere. Tony sat down in the chair next to me. Jake, when you first came to my shop, you paid cash, said you were new in town, starting fresh, but you never talked about where you came from or why you moved here. That seemed normal at the time, but now he Just should at the poster now it seems like maybe you were running from something. I stared at my reflection trying to remember my life before this town. I had an apartment here, a job at the hardware store, a routine. But when I tried to think further back, everything got blurry. I think I might have been in an accident, I said slowly, hit my head or something. My memory of the past few years is pretty foggy. That would explain a lot, Tony said gently. Head injuries can cause amnesia. Maybe you disappeared from Portland because you were hurt and confused, ended up here without remembering who you are. He showed me the poster again, says here you have a wife and two kids. They've been searching for you for three months. The words hit me like a punch to the. A wife and kids I couldn't remember. People who loved me and thought I was dead. Tony, what if I don't remember them? What if I call this number and these strangers claim to be my family? My hands were shaking now. What if I've built a life here that I have to give up for a life I can't even remember? Tony stood up and locked the front door of his shop, flipping the sign to closed. Jake, we need to figure this out properly. Let me call my brother in law. He's a cop. He can help us contact the right people and make sure This gets handled safely. He was already dialing. If you really are this missing person, there might be reasons why you left that have nothing to do with memory loss. While Tony talked to his brother in law, I studied the missing person poster more carefully. The physical description matched perfectly, 5 feet, 10 inches, brown hair, Hazel eyes, 32 years old. Even the birth date was right. But the address listed was completely unfamiliar. 1,247 Maple street, Portland, Oregon. I've never heard of that street in my life. 20 minutes later.

I don't care what anyone says, there is nothing in this world more disrespectful than a phone charger that decides it only wants to work if you fold it like origami, rub it three times, and whisper a prayer to the tech gods. Like bro, are you a charger or a puzzle? Every single time I plug it in, it's like flipping a coin with my life on the line. I plug it in and the phone's like charging, not charging, charging, not charging. Bro, make up your mind. Why are you playing hard to get? You are a cable. You have one job. And don't let it be night time either. You're in bed, lights off, trying to sleep, and now you're having to hang your phone half off the edge of the table, hold the charger with your foot, and balance a water bottle on top of it just to keep it charging. And if you breathe too hard. Boom. Disconnected. Back to 2%. Game over. Like, who manufactured this thing? A leprechaun with commitment issues. Why do I have to enter a cheat code for electricity? And the worst part? It's always that one charger in the house. You don't want to throw it away because it technically still works, but it also technically ruins your life daily. So now you're telling your friends, hey, don't move the cable or the whole house might explode. Like bro, this is not a medical ventilator, this is a phone. Why is this situation so tense? And don't even get me started. When someone else tries to use it, they plug it in casually like, oh, it's not working. Yeah, because you didn't turn it 74 degrees northwest with the tablet tilt and the moon phases aligned. I hate it here.

Scary man walked into our classroom and said, everyone whose parents work downtown, stay after class. He's sweating so bad it's dripping on our test papers and he keeps checking his phone every few seconds. I look for our teacher, but she left to make copies 10 minutes ago and never came back. The man doesn't even say his name, just stares at all of us breathing heavily and then asks really loud whose parents work in the downtown offices, you know, the big buildings. Nobody raises their hand because we all know about stranger danger and this guy seems dangerous. He gets mad and his face goes from red to almost purple. He yells, I know some of you have parents there. This is important. Finally, me and four other kids slowly raise our hands because maybe something happened to our parents and he needs to tell us. He points at us and says, you 5, stay after the bell rings. Everyone else, leave as fast as you can. The girl next to me grabs my wrist and whispers, run with me, but my legs won't move. What if my mom needs me and this man is supposed to take me to her? The bell rings and everyone practically runs out like the rooms on fire. The man locks the door behind them with this loud click and my stomach drop like on a roller coaster. He won't even let us near our backpacks where our phones are. The Quiet girl starts crying and he doesn't even care, just keeps checking the window. Then his watch saying 15 minutes. We wait 15 minutes, which makes no sense because our parents usually pick us up in five minutes. Classroom phone rings and he rips it from the wall, like actually rips it out and throws it in the trash. And now I'm really scared because why would he do that unless he's kidnapping us? We hear sirens outside, lots of them getting louder. He stands in front of the door, blocking it with his whole body. The football player kid who's bigger than some teachers rushes the door. The man catches him with one hand. It didn't take him any effort to stop the biggest of us. He keeps saying no calls, not yet. Your parents can't know you're here. And those sirens aren't for us, but they're connected. I think maybe he did something bad downtown where our parents work. Maybe we're hostages. The room smells like his sweat now, sour and wrong. The Principal's voice crackles on the intercom saying all students proceed to evacuation positions immediately. But the man doesn't move from the door. We hear hundreds of feet running in the hallways, doors slamming, teachers yelling. There were more sirens than I've ever heard before. Like every fire truck and ambulance in the city is coming here. The quiet girl throws up on her desk from being so scared. He tosses her his jacket to clean Up. And when he does, I see he has an empty gum holster under his arm, which makes me almost scream, but I cover my mouth. Teachers are banging on our door, yelling to open up. But he yells back, official emergency protocol, these students are accounted for, and keeps mumbling as he checks the time, 12 minutes, 11 minutes, 10 minutes, like he's counting down to something bad. I can hear my phone in my back.

Hi. Hi, my love. Why did you text me? Because I miss you. I wanna tell you something. I made the soccer team. Really? That's great. I'm proud of you. Thank you. Congratulations, my love. But we can't be texting. Oh, okay. I know you told me not to text you, Jacob, but I miss you so much. Please respond. Why are you leaving me on read? Hi, Leah. Jacob. Hi, Leah. We've been over this. I love you, but we can't keep talking. You know, I moved on. But I just wanna tell you something. Okay, love, what is it this time today I had my first soccer game and we won. Really? Yes. 7:49. Listen, for real this time, we have to stop texting, Leah. Oh, hi, Jacob. I know. I know you told me to stop texting you, but seriously, I can't stop. Leah. I'm sorry. I just wanna talk to you and I want to talk to you, my love, but I can't. I've moved on and you should, too. Do you still love me? Of course I do. I'll always love you. Really? Yes. But you need to get over us and move on. Okay. Also, one last thing before you go. Yes, love. We had another game today. Sounds fun. How was it? Great. We won 12 to 10. That's nice, dear. Thank you, Jacob. Okay. Bye now. Bye, Jacob. Jacob. Guess what? I had soccer practice today and I made a new friend. Lol. Remember when you used to make fun of me for only having one friend? Jokes on you. Now I made another friend. Hello. I said I made another friend, Jacob. Guess what? I had another game today. It was 9 to 8 and we won by one point and I was the one that broke the tie and made my team win. Are you proud of me, Jacob? Leah, you've been texting me a lot recently, but I don't like you anymore like I used to. Well, of course, I still love you, but at the same time, I don't want to talk to you. I meant that I have moved on and we can't be talking anymore. Whatever. Leah, are you okay? I'm sorry about what I said to you last night. I didn't mean that I don't wanna talk to you. What I meant was that you really need to move on. I would love to talk to you if I could, but you know, I'm meeting someone else. You need to get over it. Please. Jacob, I quit soccer. What? But it's been your dream for so long and you finally got into the team. Why would you quit? I know, but I've been struggling to motivate myself and I haven't been feeling the best. Leah, Leah, Leah, answer my call. Leah, I'm coming over and we're talking about this. You should go back to soccer and continue following your dream. You shouldn't quit. Everything will Be okay, I promise, Leah.

What's the funniest thing you've witnessed in a courtroom? I'm a court stenographer and last month I witnessed the most savage 16 year old absolutely destroy everyone in juvenile court. Meet Tyler. He got arrested for spray painting math is stupid on his high school. Officer Johnson is presenting the case. Your honor, the defendant was caught red handed vandalizing school property with anti educational graffiti. Tyler raises his hand. Object action. Judge Williams looks confused. Son, you're not a lawyer. You can't object. But your honor, Officer Johnson said I was carted handed but I was actually caught blue handed because I was using blue spray paint. That's false testimony. The entire courtroom goes silent. Officer Johnson's eye starts twitching. Tyler, that's not how objections work then how do they work? Because nobody explained the rules and I don't want to accidentally break more laws. Officer Johnson continues, the defendant caused $200 in property damage and showed no remorse when arrested. Tyler raises his hand again. That's also incorrect, your honor. What now? I showed plenty of remorse. I said sorry when Officer Johnson tackled me. I also said ow and get, get off me, you're heavy, which shows genuine emotion. Officer Johnson jumps in. You also said this is stupid and math still sucks. Those were factual observations not related to my remorse level. Judge Williams is trying not to smile. Tyler, why did you write math is stupid on your school? Because it's true, your honor. Math Is objectively stupid. That's your opinion. No, sir. It's science. Why do we need to find X? X doesn't wanna be found. X is probably in witness Protection for a reason. The prosecutor tries to jump in. Your honor, the defendant is being disrespectful to education. Tyler turns to the prosecutor. Ma'am, education is being disrespectful to my brain cells. They're making me learn about imaginary numbers. If they're imaginary, why can't I just imagine I passed the test? Judge Williams asked Tyler, do you understand why vandalism is wrong? Yes, sir. It's wrong because I got caught. If I hadn't gotten caught, it would just be a mysterious street art and people would call me Banksy junior. It's not art. It's vandalism. Your honor, that's discrimination against my artistic vision. Michaelangelo painted on ceilings without permission. I painted on walls. We're basically the same person. Officer Johnson is getting frustrated, your honor. He compared himself to Michaelangelo. Tyler looks at Officer Johnson. Officer, don't be jealous of my artistic talents. You wrote math is stupid and bubble letters. Bubble letters are a legitimate artistic choice. They're fun and approachable. Judge Williams tries a different approach. Tyler, what do you think your punishment should be? Well, your honor, I think the real criminal here is whoever invented algebra. I should get a medal for warning future students about mathematical torture. That's not how the legal system works. The prosecutor is getting annoyed. Your honor, I recommend 40 hours of community Service and restitution. Tyler raises his hand. I'd like to cross examine that recommendation. You can't cross examine a recommendation. Why not? This is America. I have rights. I demand a trial by combat. That's not a thing. It should be. I bet I could beat math in a fight. Judge Williams is openly laughing now. Tyler, what's your response to 40 hours of community service? Your honor, that's cruel and unusual punishment. It only took me 10 minutes to create my masterpiece, so I should only owe 10 minutes of community service? That's not how it works. Then math is even more useless than I thought. Also, why should I pay $200? My graffiti increased the property value by adding character. Officer Johnson can't take it anymore, your honor. He thinks he improved the school. Tyler nodded seriously. Officer Johnson, before my artwork, that wall was just boring brick. Now it's a conversation starter. You vandalized public property. I enhanced public property. There's a difference. Judge Williams makes his decision. Tyler, I'm sentencing you to 20 hours of community service and $200 restitution. Your honor, can I appeal this decision? On what grounds? Temporary insanity caused by pro longed exposure to quadratic equations. Also, I think Officer Johnson has a personal vendetta against artistic expression. That's not a real legal defense. It should be. I have nightmares about the Pythagorean theorem. As we're wrapping up, Tyler asks, your honor, can I get a copy of the transcript? Why I Want to use it for my college application essay.

While walking in the halls, someone pushed me and said, aren't your shoes part of the Kitty crew? What are you talking about? I'm not part of a freaky gang. I had no idea who the Kitty crew was or why anyone would think I of people was part of it. The guy looked down at my feet and shook his head. Not with those shoes on. You gotta take those kicks off immediately. Those mean something around here. What? What's wrong with my shoes? He just walked away, leaving me confused in the hallway. I made it to art class, thinking maybe that guy was just messing with freshman. But when I sat down, missus cook stopped mid sentence and stared at my feet. Young man, do you really think it's appropriate to wear those shoes? Her voice had that teacher tone that meant I was in trouble. I really don't know what you're talking about. I was getting frustrated now because nobody would explain what was happening. Girls sitting behind me started giggling and taking pictures of my shoes with their phones. I could hear them whispering, but couldn't make out what they were saying. One of them leaned forward and tapped my shoulder. You're either really brave or really stupid, she said, before going back to her phone. Throughout the entire class, people kept staring at my feet. When I got up to sharpen my pencil, everyone went silent like they were waiting for something to happen. This is a cook. Kept glancing at my shoes nervously like they might explode. By the time the bell rang, I was paranoid and confused. In the hallway between classes, it got worse. It's would see me coming and move to the other side of the hall. A group of sophomores pointed, and one of them made a slashing their neck motion across his throat. My locker neighbor, who usually said hi every day, grabbed his stuff and practically ran away when he saw me. By lunch, my phone was blowing up with Snapchat notifications. People had posted pictures of my shoes all over their stories with crying emojis and comments I didn't understand. R I P. And he doesn't know, and someone tell him before it's too late. I sat alone at lunch because nobody would come near my table. Even the lunch ladies gave me weird looks when I went through the line. One of them actually blessed herself like she was warding off evil. I tried to eat my sandwich, but my appetite was gone. What was so wrong with my shoes? In chemistry class, my lab partner asked to switch seats. The teacher agreed without even asking why. So I did the experiment alone while everyone whispered and stared. Someone had written brave or stupid on the board with an arrow pointing to my seat. During passing period, I saw a memorial plaque on the wall I'd never noticed before. Someone said the name Matthew and I tried googling it on my phone, but the school Wi-Fi blocked all the results. The few snippets I could see mentioned tragic incident and gang violence, but nothing specific. My hands were shaking as I walked to gym class. During gym class, I thought things would be normal since we all had to wear the same uniform sneakers. But Coach Wiley blew his whistle as soon as I walked in and pointed at me. You step outside in the hall now. I follow.

What made a female patient refuse all the male doctors in the building? The first thing I noticed when I entered the patient's room was her deep sunken eyes and pale cracked lips. I approached her cautiously, remembering how the charge nurse warned the girl refused all male staff. We all knew what that meant. And she looked as broken as I imagined. I pulled up a chair next to her bed instead of standing over her and gently asked if she wanted some water first. She nodded. Sweetie, you're safe here, I said, keeping my voice soft like I do with my anxious patients. Male staff won't come near you, I promise. It's just us girls here. She looked at me for the first time and whispered, he's here. I asked who. And at first she refused to even say his name. I handed her my pen and clipboard. After a second, her hand moved her Percy. My blood boiled at the name. He was my everything, she finally whispered and started showing me photos on her phone of them together at college, confirming that it was the same Percy who is now a resident at the hospital. I did everything for him, everything. Her voice cracked as she swiped to screenshots of assignments, time stamps showing her submitting his biochemistry homework at 3:00am, his pathology essays at 4:00am, his anatomy exams that she taken for him. She showed me his Instagram from those same nights, him doing beer Pong and body shots with other girls while she was writing his thesis on cellular biology. The day after graduation, after I'd spent three years making sure he got into residency, he sent me this, she said, and handed me her phone. The text made me want to throw something. Babe, you're too clingy and it's honestly suffocating. Need to focus on my career without distractions. And honestly, doctors are supposed to date doctors and you're not one. We're done. Please don't contact me again. I waited until she was stable and sleeping before I stormed into the break room where three other nurses were charting. You guys are never going to believe what I just found out about Percy, I said. I told them everything and watched their faces go from confused to furious. And within 10 minutes, we had half the female staff crammed into that tiny. I knew something was off when he asked me to explain what antibiotics were sent. June from pediatrics and Doctor Sydney are attending walked in right as someone said we should report him. And she closed the door behind her. Actually, I've been documenting his knowledge gaps for weeks, she said, pulling out her phone to show us pages of notes. But this explains everything. The room went quiet while we all looked at each other. And then Lita from the I C. U. Said, what we were all thinking, ladies, we don't need to destroy him. We just need to Let him destroy himself while we enjoy every second of it. The plan rolled out so naturally. It was almost beautiful to watch. Percy started getting paid for every.

Why did my dad's no closing doors rule get him arrested? We had the weirdest rule in probably the entire state. No closed doors while changing clothes, ever. Not my bedroom door, not the bathroom, not even the closet. Teenagers hide tattoos all over their body if we let them, dad would say, or they could be hiding pills in their pockets. My friends were horrified when they heard about it. Mickey came over once and watched me change from school clothes to normal one and right in the middle of our living room while dad sat there with his newspaper glancing up every few seconds. That's so creepy, she whispered. And I wanted to disappear. My older brother had already escaped to college partly because of rules like this. I counted days until I could leave, too. Mom tried to help without directly challenging dad. She couldn't change his mind about the rule, but she found ways around it. The shower has frosted glass. I mentioned one day while folding towels, you're only visible as a shadow. She also helped me rearrange my room, putting my full length mirror at an angle where it looked like you could see everything from the doorway, but there was actually a blind spot. Perfect for 30 second wardrobe changes. I got really good at it too. I kept spare clothes in the bathroom and changed when dad was busy watching TV. Mom would create distractions, calling dad to fix something right when I needed to change for school. For weeks, this worked perfectly. Dad thought he was enforcing his rules since door stayed open. He even bragged to his co workers about how his visibility system kept me safe. But then one weekend, everything exploded in ways I never imagined. Dad's colleague Rob came by to drop off work files. Dad was on a video call in his office. Mom was grocery shopping. And I just gotten home from track with my entire body sweating. I couldn't wait for Dad's call to end. So I ducked behind my mirror blind spot like always. But Rob didn't know our house layout. He was looking for Dad's office and saw what looked completely wrong from his angle, a teenage girl while hiding behind furniture to undress. He looked away immediately but asked me a question that sounded oddly serious. Where's your father? I pointed to Dad's office and he took off through the door. I heard him say, Jim, your daughter was hiding behind furniture to change clothes. Combined with these visibility rules you mentioned, dad came out confused at first. She knows the rules about doors. Rob shook his head. Jim, she was hiding behind furniture to change. That is not okay. You're making her feel unsafe the way.

I took everything that's mine when my roommate asked me to move out. So I was living with this girl, Megan, who I thought was my friend. We've known each other since freshman year. And when she said she found this perfect apartment and wanted me to sign the lease with her, I jumped at it. Five months of splitting everything, 50, 50, doing dishes like good little roommates, never fighting over anything. Then one random Tuesday, I get this text while I'm at my job at the campus bookstore. Hey, we need to talk when you get home. That's never good, right? So I'm driving back thinking maybe she wants to talk about whose turn it is to buy toilet paper or something stupid like that. But when I walk in, she's sitting on our couch with this weird serious face he starts with. So I've been thinking and I already know I'm screwed. She tells me she doesn't think living together is working out and that she already talked to our landlord about me moving out by January 1st. I'm just sitting there like, what the hell? Because we literally never fought. I paid my half of everything on time. I cleaned up after myself and I even bought all the good stuff for our place. She's acting like I'm some nightmare roommate who's been making her life miserable. I don't argue because honestly, why would I want to live with someone who doesn't want me there? So I Tell her fine, I'll start looking for a new place. She seems relieved like she was expecting me to throw a fit or something. That night I'm lying in bed thinking about how I need to pack everything and that's when it hits me. I look around our apartment and realise I bought literally everything that makes it nice. 50 inch TV mounted on the wall. Mine, the leather couch were always watching Netflix on. I saved up three paychecks for that thing. The coffee maker, the good plates instead of paper ones, the router for our internet, even the freaking shower curtain. Next morning I tell Megan I'll be taking all my stuff when I move out. She just says, okay, like it's no big deal. I don't think she really thought about what that meant. I spent the next two weeks apartment hunting and found this decent one bedroom across town. On moving day, I rented one of those big U Haul trucks because I knew I'd need it. Megan wasn't even home, which was probably for the best. I started with the obvious stuff like my clothes and my desk. Then I unplugged the t V and carefully took it down from the wall. I wrapped up the coffee maker, packed all the dishes I'd bought from target and loaded the couch onto the truck with help from my buddy Jake. The router was the last thing I grabbed. I unpacked all the Ethernet cables and took The whole setup. As I'm walking out with it, I realised she's going to have zero internet until she gets her own. But here's the thing that.

I humiliated my disabled sister at school so I destroyed his entire sense of identity. When my little sister Lena got diagnosed with Ms, she didn't cry. She just looked at me and said, I guess I won't beat you in races anymore. She said it with a smile. Can you imagine a 12 year old girl knowing her body is betraying her and still trying to make me feel better? So naturally I became her personal security guard, walking her to school, carrying her books, telling her dumb jokes to make her laugh on hard days. But I wasn't ready for Jason. Jason was the kind of teenage parasite that grows in a locker room and feeds off axe body spray and misplaced confidence. Captain of the basketball team, hair like a shampoo commercial, rain like overcooked broccoli. I was walking Lena to class one day when she dropped her books. Her hands were shaking. Ms does that. Before I could help, Jason and his buddies walked by laughing. He pulled out his phone and said loud enough for everyone to hear, dude, is she glitching? Someone reboot her. I froze. Lena turned bright red and then Jason topped it off by uploading it to his story with the caption error 4:04, dignity not found. The school took it down too late. The damage was done. Lena didn't talk for 3 days. I didn't sleep for 7. See there this thing people don't understand about revenge. It's not about Anger. It's about patience. And I've got the patience of a monk who's just been ghosted. Step 1, confusion. I got access to Jason's locker. Don't ask how. Let, let's just say the janitor smokes menthols and owes me a favor. Every couple of days. I moved things around, switched his notebooks, swapped one shoe for a size smaller, took out his lunch and replaced it with tuna that had been sitting in my garage for a week. He thought he had early onset dementia. I just smiled when he walked by muttering, I swear I packed my red folder. Step 2, sabotage. Jason took ADH meds. Nothing crazy, just enough to keep him focused. I swapped them with over the counter melatonin. Suddenly he was nodding off in history like a narcotic cat that teachers noticed. They didn't think drugs. They thought he was lazy. His grades dropped. College scouts stopped calling. Shame. Step 3, psychological erosion. Jason lived with his grandma because both his parents peaced out when he was in middle school. She was sweet, the kind of grandma who knits ugly sweaters and gives you those hard candies no one actually buys. I ran into her at the pharmacy, helped her carry her bags, complimented her ugly sweater. She called me a nice young man. I called her Nana. Boom, Instant trust. Then I planted the seed. Jason's been acting a little off lately, huh? Talking to himself a lot. She nodded slowly and said, I've Noticed that, too. She took him to a doctor. The DOC upped his meds. I kept swapping them. The result, he started hearing things, whispering, humming. At one point, he said the school lockers were laughing at him. He punched one, broke his wrist, cried in the nurse's office. Step 4, identity removal. I hacked into a student portal, changed small things, wrong birthday, switched his emergency contact from his grandma to a number I bought at a gas station. Then I forged a school psych report stating Jason might be suffering from dissociation. Next thing you know, Jason gets pulled from class and is forced into a mental health evaluation. He passed barely, but now every teacher looked at him like he was a ticking time bomb. In the final nail, I broke into his room while he was out, moved furniture around, rotated his posters, replaced a photo of him and his grandma with a nearly identical one, but with slightly different outfits. It drove him insane. He screamed at her one night that she was in on it. She cried. He got sent to a psych ward for evaluation. He didn't come back. A week later, his grandma bumped into me outside a grocery store, said Jason wasn't himself anymore. I said, maybe he never was. She just nodded, sighed, and handed me a bag of those disgusting candies. Oh, and Lena, she started smiling again, drawing again, talking again. As for Jason, he went from being The king of the school to being a ghost in a hospital gown who doesn't know if the voices in his head are real. And the best part, he still doesn't know who did it. He just knows someone did that. Paranoia, it'll live rent free in his head until the day he dies. And me, I sleep just fine. After all, some glitches can't be fixed.
NA

Made my pregnant sister in law cry when she kept asking why I changed my name. My brother is married to Haley and they're expecting a baby together. Last year, I officially changed my first name from Evelyn to indie, which was a nickname form of my original middle name. My parents gave in after realising how serious I was about being indie and how I was not warming up to or growing into Evelyn. My brother and Haley want an older vintage name for their baby. And Haley asked me about five months ago why I disliked Evelyn enough to change it. At the time, she brought up how popular the name has become and how vintage is back. I told her I didn't like vintage names me. They sound really old fashioned. I said the popularity didn't influence my decision. She wanted to know my reason for disliking older names and why I liked something like indie instead. I didn't mind her asking the first time. She brought it up again a week later and asked the same question, pressing more about why. She asked a third and a fourth time. I gave her the same answer and asked her why she kept asking. I told her my answer wasn't going to change. By the seventh time she asked, she admitted she was worried her baby would hate having an older name and wanted to figure out what she could do to prevent what happened with me happening To her, she also said she'd like me to rethink my name because she thought Evelyn was beautiful and she was sad I had chosen something like indie over it. I asked her to stop so many times already and I even asked my brother to step in. He told me I needed to understand it was the hormones. I can easily say she has asked me this more than 25 times by now. I'm not exaggerating that number either. Two weeks ago when she brought it up again, she said she felt I had made a mistake changing my name and that 30 year old me wouldn't be so against Evelyn. I told her 30 year old me can deal with it if that happens. She told me I didn't really have a good reason to like the name indie and that it seems like the kind of name someone young likes but not someone older. Then yesterday happened and I kind of lost my temper. She started asking the same stuff again and the baby is almost ready to be born, so I know it's coming to an end. But she asked me to really think about why and help her because she couldn't figure out what she'd do differently than my parents did. Then she said they really shouldn't have let me change my name so young. I snapped. I told her to stop asking me the same question because my answer won't change. And her comments Are not going to change my mind. I said I don't like old fashioned names. I think they're awful and I'm sick and tired of hearing how much better they supposedly are and having her try to make me find a reason she finds acceptable. I told her just like she hates indie, I hate Evelyn and she needs to let it fucking go already. She burst into tears and my brother got so mad at me. My parents were also like, why did you have to speak to her so harshly?

Daughter tried to ban her gay siblings from her wedding, so I refused to walk her down the aisle. I've got 5 kids. This is about three of them. Casey, Alex, and Tom. Casey, my 26 year old daughter, is getting married this winter. She's been with her fiance, Max, for about four years now. He's from another country, and with the currency difference, his family can't really afford to contribute to the wedding and also afford the travel costs. So I offered to cover the majority of the wedding expenses. No problem. She's my little girl. I've always dreamed of walking her down the aisle. It was supposed to be one of those proud, emotional dad moments you never forget. Then last week, two of my kids, Alex and Tom, came over with their families. We were catching up, talking about life, and naturally, the wedding came up. I casually asked if they were excited, thinking we'd all be there together for the big day. That's when they both got quiet. They hadn't been invited. At first, I figured maybe Casey hadn't sent out all the invitations yet. Maybe it was some mailing mix up. But then my oldest daughter, who's also there, said she had received her invite already. Same with my youngest, and both of them had been invited with their partners and their kids. So I called my sister to check, and yep, she and her whole family had been invited weeks ago. That's when I Knew this wasn't some oversight. Casey had specifically left Alex and Tom out. Now, here's what makes this even more painful. Alex is non binary and married to a man. Tom is gay, also married with adopted children. And Casey has always been supportive. She stood by them when they came out. She used to call herself their fiercest defender. We're not some rigid, divided family. We're close. Or at least we used to be. So I called her and I asked her why, Max's family isn't comfortable with non traditional couples. It's against their culture. And she hopes I'll understand. Understand? No. Absolutely not. I told her straight up, if she's okay excluding her own brothers, who've done nothing wrong, just to make her fiance's family more comfortable, then I'm not walking her down the aisle. I'm not paying for the wedding either. Let Max's family, with all their backward opinions, pay for it. I told her, if your family suddenly doesn't fit into your picture perfect day, then maybe we're not part of that picture at all. Called me an asshole and hung up crying. My other kids are all on my side. Even my wife, who usually tries to stay neutral, was heartbroken. She adores our son's in law. Loves those kids like they're her own grandkids. She doesn't support Casey's decision at all, even if she's trying to stay open. In case our daughter eventually wakes up and realizes how messed up this Is. But as of now, I'm not budging. I'm not rewarding exclusion and cowardice, and I sure as hell won't smile in a tux pretending it's all okay.

My grandmother asked me, do you wear that bracelet I sent you every day? My stomach sank. What bracelet? She pulled out her phone and showed me a receipt. 3,000 dollar custom gold bracelet with your birthstone delivered four months ago. I'd never seen it in my life. My mom suddenly got very interested in her coffee cup. Dad started scrolling through his phone like nothing happened. The air in the restaurant felt thick with tension. Mom, I said slowly, did you, you sign for a package addressed to me? Her face went red. We thought it was a mistake. Grandma sends so many things. A mistake? Grandma's voice could cut glass. I had it engraved with his name. And track the delivery myself. I watched my parents exchange that look, the same guilty look they've been giving each other for months. Whenever grandma brought up gifts or money, I thought I was being paranoid. But now everything was starting to make sense. Show me the tracking information. Dad interrupted, trying to sound authoritative. Grandma scrolled through her phone. Delivered to your front door on March 15th at two forty seven PM signed for by Leora Hensley. She looked directly at my mom. That's you, isn't it, Leora? My mom's hands started shaking. I, I don't remember every package that comes to the house. You don't remember a 3,000 dollar piece of jewelry? Grandma's eyebrows shot up. That's when I noticed my sister's new tennis bracelet sparkling on her wrist. The Same design, the same stones, the same everything. My stomach dropped. I'd seen Alara wearing it for weeks, bragging to her friends about how she'd treated herself after getting good grades. Alara's idea of treating herself was usually a five dollar coffee, not luxury jewelry. Alara, I said, staring at her arm. Where did you get that? She yanked her sleeve down faster than I'd ever seen her move. I, um, saved up for it. Alara works part time at a smoothie shop, making $12 an hour. She spends most of her paycheck on makeup and clothes. There was no way she had $3,000 saved. How long did you save? I pressed, feeling my anger building. Like a few months, she mumbled, not making eye contact. A few months of smoothie shop money bought you a 3,000 dollar bracelet. Mom jumped in. Alara's been very responsible with her money lately. Really? I turned to my parents cause last month she asked me for $20 for gas money. The month before that, she needed $50 for textbooks. Just last week she was complaining about being broke. Dad cleared his throat. Lauren, you're being dramatic. Maybe Alara got a bonus or from a smoothie shop. I cut him off. Alara, what's the most expensive thing you've ever bought with your own money? She fidgeted with her napkin. I don't know, maybe my phone case, which cost like $30. The math wasn't mathing and everyone at the table knew it. Grandma leaned forward. Her eyes locked on Alara's bracelet. Show me that bracelet now. I don't wanna take it off, Alara said, her voice getting smaller. It might fall.

My brother kicked me out over his wife's lies. Now they're homeless with kids and I refuse to let them back in my life. When I was 22, I inherited our grandmother's house, a beautiful Victorian with enough space for my brother and his family to stay while they saved for their own place. They moved in with their two kids, promising it would only be temporary. Just six months, my brother assured me, will be out of your hair before you know it. His wife despised me from day one. She'd make snide comments about how I decorated, complained that I was too loud when I came home from my nursing shifts and acted like I was invading her space in my own house. She'd rearrange my kitchen without asking, throw away my mail, claiming it was junk, and lecture me about proper household management while I was paying all the bills. The passive aggression escalated weekly. She'd use my expensive shampoo, then deny it when confronted. My leftovers would disappear from the fridge and she'd claim she thought they were communal food when I started labelling everything with my name. She complained to my brother that I was being petty and territorial. I tried talking to my brother about her behaviour, but he always made excuses. She's stressed about money. She's not used to living with other people. You're being too sensitive. Every conversation ended with him defending her and dismissing my concerns. The breaking point came six Months later, I arrived home exhausted from a double shift to find her screaming at me in the hallway. She claimed I've been stealing money from her purse and eating her food from the fridge. Both accusations were ridiculous. I made decent money and kept my own groceries clearly labeled. You've been sneaking into our room, she shrieked, her face red with manufactured rage. I know you took $40 from my wallet last Tuesday. I stared at her in disbelief. I worked 12 hour shifts. When exactly would I have time to rifle through your belongings? Don't lie to me, she spat. I, I have proof. My brother stood behind her, silent as she launched into a tirade about how I was jealous of their family and trying to sabotage their marriage. When I tried to defend myself, she burst into tears and ran to their room. That night, my brother knocked on my door. His face was stone cold, a look I'd never seen directed at me before. We need to talk, he said. He told me his wife had been documenting everything. Times I allegedly took money instant. This is where I supposedly threatened her when he wasn't around. Photos of missing food items. None of it was true, but he believed every word. She'd created a detailed log with dates, times and descriptions of my supposed crimes. You're toxic and you're tearing our family apart, he said. We're done enabling your behavior. I stared at him in Disbelief. This was the same brother who'd cry.

I asked my brother not to bring his girlfriend to my wedding. My brother Jake has this girlfriend named Becca who literally cannot stand not being the centre of attention for 5 minutes. Every family dinner, every holiday, every gathering, she finds a way to make it about her. Last Thanksgiving, she announced she was pregnant right when my dad was about to carve the Turkey. Turns out she wasn't even pregnant. Just wanted to see everyone's reactions. So when I was planning my wedding to my fiance, Ryan, I knew I had to do something about the Becca situation. This was going to be my one day, the one day that was supposed to be about me and Ryan starting our life together. I called Jake about three months before the wedding. What's the most creative way you've ever followed your parents rules? Just to annoy them. My parents were incredibly strict about screen time when I was growing up. One hour a day, no exceptions, no negotiating. My mom would literally set a kitchen timer when I logged on. When that thing rang, I had 30 seconds to shut everything down or I'd lose screen privileges for a week. Didn't matter if I was saving a game, watching a movie or in the middle of a school assignment. Time was time. So at 14, I found a loophole. The rule said very specifically, one hour of screen time. That was the phrase. No qualifiers, no details, just screen time. So I decided to maliciously comply in the most annoying, obnoxious way I could think of. I started using my one hour in the most unproductive, mind numbing and absolutely ridiculous ways possible. I'd boot up the computer, then spend 20 full minutes just staring at the loading screen of a game I never actually played. Or I'd open Microsoft Word and type complete gibberish random strings of letters like d, F, F, J, class, Jeff, ol Kashi while making over the top sounds of excitement. Wow, this is so fun, I'd say dramatically. Best screen time ever. Sometimes I'd open up paint, draw one pixel and then sit back and admire it like it was the Mona Lisa. My mom got confused at first. She peeked in during one of these Sessions and asked if something was wrong with the game. Nope, I replied cheerfully, just enjoying my screen time. It only got weirder from there. I watched the Windows defragmentation tool. I mean, watched it like it was a nature documentary. Oh look, block 42 just moved. I'd narrate in fake excitement. The breaking point came one afternoon when my dad walked into the kitchen and found me sitting cross legged in front of the microwave. I wasn't cooking anything meaningful, just heating up a mug of water, timer set for 15 minutes. And I was staring at the digital display completely zoned in like I was watching the series finale of my favorite show. My dad blinked. What are you doing using my screen time? I said innocently, this is a screen, right? I didn't even blink, just kept watching the numbers tick down. 1342, 1341. That was the beginning of the end. I kept pushing it, sat in front of the washing machine while it.

voice_to_text: While hiding in the back of class, my mentally ill teacher asked, did you all call your parents goodbye? My girlfriend, Molly, put her hand under my desk. And please, Missus Dodson, you have to legally let us go. Missus Hy Dodson was crying now with mascara running down her cheeks. I'm sorry, but if I let you all run out of the class, the gunman might get you. We need to wait. I looked at Molly and tried to keep my voice steady. Don't worry, babe, I'm going to figure out a way out of this. Missus Dodson had kept our entire class trapped in the room. She'd been acting strange all week, but today she locked the door during last period because she sensed a warning. Missus Dodson suddenly screamed and pointed at the door there. Did you hear those gunshots? Everyone get down. We all looked at each other confused, but Missus Dodson was shaking and clutching a rosary to her chest. She heard it all, 20 of us to the back corner of the room furthest from the windows. She started praying in Latin while we huddled together. Some kids were crying. Others were texting their parents frantically. The school had probably already called wondering where we were. Basketball practice had started two hours ago. Drama rehearsal was happening without half the cast. This is Datson. I have an idea, I said, interrupting her prayer. How about you let us out through the window since we're Only on the first floor and we can all escape and get help. She shook her head violently. No, the government has friends outside. They'll shoot all of you the second you climb out. I won't let you leave. She started going around hugging each student and telling them she loved them. Kids were flinching away from her touch. This woman who usually graded papers with perfect posture was now wild eyed and sweating through her cardigan. Bradley was the class troublemaker who usually slept through lessons, stood up and crossed his arms. Missus Dodson, you're so insane that you make me want to actually do my homework. Let us out, you crazy witch. School dismissal was four hours ago. Her face twisted into something ugly. The only dismissal you're going to have is straight to hell. I should let you out of the classroom and let the gunman unload on you. Fine, then let's do it. Bradley walked toward the door. Missus Dodson immediately crumbled. I'm sorry, sweetie, you know I can't let you leave here. I have to keep the door locked so I can protect you all. While she was focused on Bradley and trying to pull him back to the group, I saw my chance. Her keys were hanging from her belt loop. I carefully reached over and unclip them, trying not to jingle the metal. Molly saw what I was doing, created more distraction by fake crying loudly. I crawled toward the door, staying low. Like we were actually in danger. I didn't realize till later that we really were. My hands were shaking as I found the right key. The lock clicked open and I yanked the door handle. Run, I shouted. All 20 students rushed for the door at once. Missus Dodson screamed and tried to grab people, but we pushed past her. We ran down the hallway and burst through the front entrance into the parking lot where police cars were everywhere. The cops had their hands on their weapons until all they saw it was just a bunch of terrified teenagers. They immediately asked us what happened. Our teacher went insane and trapped us in there for four hours. I told the nearest officer. He nodded grimly. We're sorry we took so long. We just got the call about you guys. After we searched in Missus Dodson's house, you won't believe what we found. Full story on channel link below.
