voice_to_text: Realize that someone was all bark and no bite. I was 12 when my stepdad Mark gave me a cute nickname and that was a lazy n word. You see, for two years straight, Mark had one rule. I wasn't allowed to sleep. While my white siblings could sleep from eleven PM to 7:00am, I was only allowed to sleep from 12:00am to 4:00am. Luckily, I didn't even have to set an alarm clock because every morning at 4:00am, Mark would burst into my room with a flashlight in my face checking if I was ready to do my character building chores. This include it's scrubbing bathrooms, organizing the garage, prepping breakfast for when his boys woke up. But that wasn't even the worst part because if I made any sort of noise, I'd lose privileges. The privilege just in question, eating enough food, drinking enough water. And since my mom worked 12 hour night shifts as a nurse, she never saw any of it. Mark had this whole philosophy about modern kids being soft. When I was in Afghanistan, he'd start every lecture. We functioned on two hours of sleep for weeks. Kids today can't even handle getting up early. I'm sure you can guess why. His rules only applied to me. By month 3, I was practically schizophrenic with how much I was hallucinating, shadows moving in my peripheral vision, hearing my name when no one called. I'd fallen asleep on the toilet twice at my desk, dozens Of times and once while standing in the shower. The other black kids at my school started calling me the raccoon N word because of the dark circles under my eyes. My grades made like a girl's chest during puberty when from A's to D's, all because I couldn't stay conscious long enough to finish tests. Teachers thought I was on drugs and said I fit the stereotype. Even the counselor pulled me aside ask if everything was okay at home. The breaking point came during midterms. I literally fell asleep standing up during my history presentation, face planted right into the whiteboard. Twenty minutes later, the school nurse called my parents and Mark showed up in his veterans cap like he was on a rescue mission. This is what I'm talking about, he said, shaking his head in the nurse's office. No self control. I've tried everything, structure, discipline, consequences. Some kids just don't want to succeed. The counselor ate up every word. I don't blame you, Mark. Most white folk wouldn't even bother trying to civilize a kid like this. You're fighting genetics here. I tried telling my mom when I got home, but she was exhausted after a double shift and Mark was right there, arm around her shoulders. He's exaggerating, Mark said calmly. Teen boys are dramatic. Just teaching him discipline, bruh, I only get 4 hours of sleep, I managed to whisper. Mark laughed. See what I mean? The kid can't even keep his lies. Straight. My mom just sat there saying nothing. Plus, didn't your guys ancestors used to spend all day in the cotton field? Anyway, you should be used to this by now. He then threw his head back and cackled. That's when I realized my mom was too scared of Mark to defend me. I wanted to call CPS, but I knew Mark would just sweet talk his way out of it. So instead I did something I never done before. I went through my mom's jewelry box to find my dead dad's old phone there, found his brother Jerome's number. I texted him on my phone and asked if he wanted to go on a run with me at 4:00am. Mark would be at his peak performance by then. When he agreed, I felt a chaotic excitement fill my veins. So on Thursday night, I made sure to be extra lazy at dinner, dozed off twice, knocked over my water. Mark's eye twitched with anticipation. Looks like someone needs extra motivation tomorrow, he said. His boys snickering. At 4:00am sharp, the flashlight hit my face. But this time Mark brought props, a bucket of ice water and an airhorn. He was so excited to abuse me that he didn't even hear the front door open. Rise and shine, you lazy n word, he cheered. Today we're trying something new since you can't seem to be disciplined. He was then interrupted by the sound of my bedroom door creaking open. What The f did you just call my nephew? My uncle's voice bellowed through the house. Behind him, my cousins Desean and Tyrell. Mark's flashlight swung toward them, his face draining color. This.

50 pound gym bro picked a fight with me to impress a girl, not knowing I was a taekwondo black belt. At 5 7 and 140 pounds, I wasn't exactly the most intimidating. Drunk guys at bars always picked me when they wanted to look tough in front of women. So when I saw this 6 2 gym bro marching over to where I was chatting with a pretty brunette, I already knew how this would go. He wedged himself between us, his massive frame completely blocking me out. Didn't even look at me, just turned his broad back like I was furniture. Let me get you a real drink, beautiful, he said. Flag down the bartender, not whatever this little guy was boring you with. She glanced around his shoulder at me, clearly uncomfortable. Actually, we were just. Trust me. He cut her off, placing a protective hand on the bar in front of her. Eating a wall. You need someone who can actually take care of you. He ordered her a martini without asking, then finally acknowledged my existence with a dismissive glance. You can go now, buddy. When I didn't move, he shifted his weight, using his size to push me further down the bar. The edge of the counter dug into my ribs. Still, I stayed put, sipping my beer. He'd expected me to scurry away by now. He turned to me fully for the first time, looking me up and down with theatrical disgust, asked If I I was deaf or something. When I calmly said I was just finishing my drink, his hand shot out and swiped my glasses off my face. They clattered across the bar. Everything went blurry. He made jokes about me not being able to see up to his height. Told the girl maybe that's why I hadn't gotten the hint. I stayed still, breathing normally. 10 years of training had taught me the most important lesson real fighters don't fight in bars. Much liability. Too much to lose. My instructor certification, my gym, potential lawsuits, all gone over some drunk idiot. I reached for my glasses with measured movements. He slid them further away with one finger, told me to leave them. I walked around him to retrieve them, keeping everything neutral. When I sat back down with my glasses, he spun around to face the entire bar and announced loudly that we had a creeper situation. His voice boomed over the music as he pointed at me with his beer bottle, claiming I've been bothering this nice lady for an hour. The brunette tried to protest, but he interrupted, putting a possessive hand on her shoulder that made her flinch. Told everyone not to worry, he had it handled. His buddies at a corner table started laughing and shouting. Someone asked if I was in middle school. He grinned and turned to the bartender, suggesting I should be carded again because I looked about twice. The brunette pulled Away from his hand, but he kept talking over her, telling her she didn't have to be polite anymore. Half the bar was watching now, some people whispering, shooting me, suspicious looks. My reputation at this place where I've been a regular for two years, was being destroyed in real time. Then he decided to demonstrate my weakness. He grabbed my wrist, suddenly, holding it up for the bar to see, while comparing it to his 12 year old nephew's arms. I didn't resist, keeping my breathing steady as he squeezed harder, his thumb pressing into the pressure point. He yanked me off the bar stool, effortlessly, spinning me around to show the girl what would happen if real danger showed up, then shoved me back against the bar. Not hard enough to be considered assault, but enough to make his point. The edge dug into my spine. He stood there waiting, telling me to push back, show her I was a real man. I stayed relaxed, hands at my sides, no aggressive stance, nothing that could justify what he wanted to do. His face darkened at my non reaction, called me pathetic. He turned to the girl, explaining this was why she needed someone like him around, painted scenarios of what could happen with me just standing there, doing nothing if he was actually dangerous. The brunette stood up, said she was leaving. He grabbed her wrist, immediately, insisting he'd walk her to her car because the streets weren't Safe. Her voice was firm, but I could hear the fear underneath. When she told him to let go, he tightened his grip slightly, still smiling, saying he was just trying to help. She tried to pull away, but he held firm, told her to relax. He was just being a gentleman. His grip tightened enough to make her gasp. She was getting genuinely scared now, panic in her voice as she pushed against his chest with her free hand. That's when something shifted in his eyes. The drunk bravado turned into something ugly.

What family tradition ruined your family? My mother is the most baby obsessed psycho I've ever met. Starting when I was 8 years old, she made me and my sister Daniela wear these pregnancy simulation suits for hours every single day. 20 pounds of sand strapped to our stomachs while we practice breathing exercises and watch birthing videos. If we complained about back pain, she'd add more weight and tell us, real mothers don't whine. She even made us practice breastfeeding with these baby little dolls that would cry if you didn't hold them right. While I spent every session plotting my escape, Daniela embraced it as if it was her one true purpose. She'd waddle around the house with perfect posture, rubbing in her fake belly and talking to it out loud. By the time she turned 16, she was begging mom to let her be a practice surrogate for her infertile work friends. And when she turned 18, Mom threw her a massive party, not for graduating high school, but for signing her first surrogacy contract. Everyone was calling her a blessing and an angel, while I sat in the corner feeling like I was at a livestock auction. Within three years, Daniella had carried three babies for three different couples. Each time she came home from the hospital, mom would parade her around town like she'd won a Nobel Prize. Look at my generous daughter giving the gift of life. Meanwhile, I was getting a biomedical degree. Volunteering at women's shelters and learning about bodily autonomy. But none of that mattered. Such a waste of a perfectly good uterus. Mom would tell anyone who'd listen. Her sister has blessed three families, while this one hordes her fertility for herself. The most terrifying part was watching Daniela deteriorate after her fourth pregnancy. At 22, she could barely walk without pain, her hips were destroyed, she had constant infections, and her hair was falling out in chunks. When I tried to talk to her about it, she grabbed my hands with tears in her eyes. Maria, this is what I was made for. My body is a vessel for miracles. Why can't you understand that? That's when I knew she was gone. So I played along just enough to keep mom off my back. Told her I was considering pregnancy, wore looser clothes to family events, even googled fertility clinics in front of her, all while secretly taking the LSAT and applying to law schools across the country. Lol. I specialized in reproductive rights and medical ethics, spending years helping women escape forced pregnancy situations. By 28, I was finally making a difference. So when mom invited me to Daniela's Celebration dinner, I figured it was just another pregnancy announcement. Boy, was I wrong. Turns out it was an effing intervention. Sweetie, you're not getting any younger, mom announced while Daniela sat beside her belly swollen with pregnancy. No. 5. So I've taken the liberty of starting your fertility Treatments. Before I could respond, she pulled out a syringe filled with hormones. Just a little boost to get those eggs flowing. I jumped back, but Daniela grabbed my arms from behind. Please, Maria, just try it. I've already found the perfect couple for your first baby. I screamed and fought, but mom was already coming at me with the needle. That's when I noticed the other syringes on the table. They've been planning this. Mom punched the needle into my thigh. I felt the cold liquid burn through my muscle. Within minutes, my vision blurred, and my ovaries felt like they were on fire. Through the haze, I heard mom on the phone. Yes. Started the protocol. She'll be ready for harvest in two weeks. That's when I realized this wasn't just about family pressure anymore. This was trafficking. I woke up in the ICU with ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome so severe, they nearly had to remove everything. My mom stood towering over me. We only brought you here because we wanted to save your womb, was the first thing she said. I pressed the red button for the nurse. We took one look at my mom and escorted her out to perform private examinations. As soon as we were alone, I felt even worse because she wrapped her arms around me and asked if I was okay. I broke down crying because the whole thing.

Off my toxic friend group by creating a fake emergency to see who would actually show up. So I've been feeling like the backup friend for months. I planned this whole thing at Dave and Buster's and invites two weeks early. The day of, I'm sitting there alone at a table for seven. One by one, the cancellations rolled in. Emma had a family thing. Tyler forgot he had to work, just said her car wouldn't start. But here's the kicker. I saw Tyler's Instagram story later that night. He was at some house party with people from our group, including Jess, whose car had mysteriously started working. That's when I decided to test them. I crafted this message about how my mom was in the hospital after a car accident and I was scared and needed someone to drive me there because I was too shaken up to drive. I sent it to our group chat at seven PM on a Thursday. First response came from Emma an hour later. Oh, no, hope she's okay. Keep us updated. No offer to help. Tyler hearted the message. That's it. Just hearted it like it was a funny meme or something. Just texted me privately saying she would help but her boyfriend had the car. Brad said he was at work until late. Two others never even responded. Six people I'd called my best friends for four years and when I needed them most, they all had excuses. But here's where it gets interesting. I have this coworker named Alex who I'd only hung out with a few times outside work. He barely knew me beyond small talk about weekend plans. I decided to text him the same message just to see what would happen. This guy dropped everything, called me immediately, said he was leaving his girlfriend's apartment right then to pick me up, showed up at my door 20 minutes later with snacks and a phone charger, asking which hospital and if I needed anything else. I felt so bad I almost came clean right there. Instead, I told him my mom was okay, that it was just a Scare and false alarm. He was genuinely relieved and said he was glad to help anytime. Meanwhile, my so called best friends were still posting TikToks and Snapchat stories like nothing happened. The next day in our group chat, everyone asked how my mom was doing. I said she was fine. Thanks for all the support. The sarcasm went right over their heads. Emma even had the nerve to say that's what friends are for with a heart emoji. I started pulling back after that, stopped initiating conversations, stop suggesting plans. Guess what happened? Nothing. They literally didn't notice I was gone. Three weeks passed before anyone texted me directly and it was only because Tyler needed someone to cover his shift at the pizza place where we both worked. Last weekend was the breaking point. I saw on Instagram they all went to this escape room place we talked about going to for months, the same place I'd suggested multiple times and got shut down. There they were, all six of them posting stories with captions like squad goals and best friends forever. So I made my decision. I started a new group chat called Real Friends Update with just Alex and two other people who'd actually shown they cared. I posted about moving on from fake friendships and finding people who actually value you.

50 pound gym bro picked a fight with me to impress a girl, not knowing I was a taekwondo black belt. At 5 7 and 140 pounds, I wasn't exactly the most intimidating drunk. Guys at bars always picked me when they wanted to look tough in front of women. So when I saw this 6 2 gym bro marching over to where I was chatting with a pretty brunette, I already knew how this would go. He wedged himself between us, his massive frame completely blocking me out. Didn't even look at me, just turned his broad back like I was furniture. Let me get you a real drink, beautiful, he said. Flag down the bartender, not whatever this little guy was boring you with. She glanced around his shoulder at me, clearly uncomfortable. Actually, we were just, trust me. He cut her off, placing a protective hand on the bar in front of her, creating a wall. You need someone who can actually take care of you. He ordered her a martini without asking, then finally acknowledged my existence with a dismissive glance. You can go now, buddy. When I didn't move, he shifted his weight, using his size to push me further down the bar. The edge of the counter dug into my ribs. Still, I stayed put, sipping my beer. He'd expected me to scurry away by now. He turned to me fully for the first time, looking me up and down with theatrical disgust, asked If I, I was deaf or something. When I calmly said I was just finishing my drink, his hand shot out and swiped my glasses off my face. They clattered across the bar. Everything went blurry. He made jokes about me not being able to see up to his height, told the girl maybe that's why I hadn't gotten the hint. I stayed still, breathing normally. 10 years of training had taught me the most important lesson, real fighters don't fight in bars. Too much liability, too much to lose my instructor certification, my gym, potential lawsuits, all gone over some drunk idiot. I reached for my glasses with measured movements, slid them further away with one finger, told me to leave them. I walked around him to retrieve them, keeping everything neutral. When I sat back down with my glasses, he spun around to face the entire bar and announced loudly that we had a creeper situation. His voice boomed over the music as he pointed at me with his beer bottle, claiming I've been bothering this nice lady for an hour. The brunette tried to protest, but he interrupted, putting a possessive hand on her shoulder that made her flinch, told everyone not to worry, he had it handled. His buddies at a corner table started laughing and shouting. Someone asked if I was in middle school, grinned and turned to the bartender, suggesting I should be carded again because I looked about 12. The brunette pulled away. From his hand, but he kept talking over her, telling her she didn't have to be polite anymore. Half the bar was watching now. Some people whispering, shooting me suspicious looks. My reputation at this place where I've been a regular for two years was being destroyed in real time. Then he decided to demonstrate my weakness. He grabbed my wrist, suddenly holding it up for the bar to see while comparing it to his 12 year old nephew's arms. I didn't resist, keeping my breathing steady as he squeezed harder, his thumb pressing into the pressure point. He yanked me off the bar stool, effortlessly spinning me around to show the girl what would happen if real danger showed up. Then shoved me back against the bar. Not hard enough to be considered assault, but enough to make his point. The edge dug into my spine. He stood there waiting, telling me to push back, show her I was a real man. I stayed relaxed, hands at my sides, no aggressive stance, nothing that could justify what he wanted to do. His face darkened at my non reaction, called me pathetic. He turned to the girl, explaining this was why she needed someone like him around, painted scenarios of what could happen with me just standing there doing nothing if he was actually dangerous. The brunette stood up, said she was leaving. He grabbed her wrist immediately insisting he'd walk her to her car because the streets weren't safe. Her voice was firm, but I could hear the fear underneath. When she told him to let go, he tightened his grip slightly, still smiling, saying he was just trying to help. She tried to pull away, but he held firm, told her to relax. He was just being a gentleman. His grip tightened enough to make her gasp. She was getting genuinely scared now. Panic in her voice as she pushed against his chest with her free hand. That's when something shifted in his eyes. The drunk bravado turned into something ugly.

Off my toxic friend group by creating a fake emergency to see who would actually show up. So I've been feeling like the backup friend for months. It started when I got really sick with the flu last winter. I'm talking fever, can't get out of bed sick. I texted our group chat asking if someone could bring me soup or medicine from the store. Radio silence for 3 hours. Then finally, Emma responds with, Oof, feel better. And that's it. But two days later, when Brad wanted people to come help him move his couch, four of them showed up immediately. I started paying attention after that. When I'd suggest hanging out, I'd get excuses. When anyone else suggested something, suddenly everyone was free. During conversations, they talk over me or just ignore what I said completely. At restaurants, they'd split the Bill evenly, even though I always ordered the cheapest thing because I was broke from college. The final straw was my birthday last month. I planned this whole thing at Dave and Buster's and invites two weeks early. The day of, I'm sitting there alone at a table for seven. One by one, the cancellations rolled in. Emma had a family thing. Tyler forgot he had to work, just said her car wouldn't start. But here's the kicker. I saw Tyler's Instagram story later that night. He was at some house party with people from our group, including Jess, whose car had mysteriously started working. That's when I decided to test them. I crafted this message about how my mom was in the hospital after a car accident and I was scared and needed someone to drive me there because I was too shaken up to drive. I sent it to our group chat at seven PM on a Thursday. First response came from Emma an hour later. Oh, no, hope she's okay. Keep us updated. No offer to help. Tyler hearted the message. That's it. Just hearted it like it was a funny meme or something. Just texted me privately saying she would help but her boyfriend had the car. Brad said he was at work until late. Two others never even responded. Six people I'd called my best friends for four years and when I needed them most, they all had excuses. But here's where it gets interesting. I have this coworker named Alex who I'd only hung out with a few times outside work. He barely knew me beyond small talk about weekend plans. I decided to text him the same message just to see what would happen. This guy dropped everything, called me immediately, said he was leaving his girlfriend's apartment right then to pick me up, showed up at my door 20 minutes later with snacks and a phone charger, asking which hospital and if I needed anything else. I felt so bad I almost came clean right there. Instead, I told him my mom was okay, that it was just a Scare and false alarm. He was genuinely relieved and said he was glad to help anytime. Meanwhile, my so called best friends were still posting TikToks and Snapchat stories like nothing happened. The next day in our group chat, everyone asked how my mom was doing. I said she was fine. Thanks for all the support. The sarcasm went right over their heads. Emma even had the nerve to say that's what friends are for with a heart emoji. I started pulling back after that, stopped initiating conversations, stop suggesting plans. Guess what happened? Nothing. They literally didn't notice I was gone. Three weeks passed before anyone texted me directly and it was only because Tyler needed someone to cover his shift at the pizza place where we both worked. Last weekend was the breaking point. I saw on Instagram they all went to this escape room place we talked about going to for months, the same place I'd suggested multiple times and got shut down. There they were, all six of them posting stories with captions like squad goals and best friends forever. So I made my decision. I started a new group chat called Real Friends Update with just Alex and two other people who'd actually shown they cared. I posted about moving on from fake friendships and finding people who actually value you.

Have a friend who used to be your everything. Y'all were always talking, laughing at dumb stuff, venting, being weird together, making the most unhinged inside jokes that nobody else would get. And now they're just gone. Not even gone like we grew apart, but, like, replaced. Like they found a new group and suddenly forgot you existed. And they swear they still care. But the I'm going to sleep early is getting old. Especially when I see you online, in games, in calls with your new little friend group. Like, bro, I'm not stupid. I see the green dot. I see the whole friend list active. Don't lie to me and say it's nothing. You just stopped choosing me. And what hurts more is feeling like I'm just a backup now. Like I'm being kept around just in case the new group drops you or switches up. Like I'm the in case of emergency friend. I'm not a fostering safety net. You used to need me. Now I'm just convenient when you're bored. And I see it, I feel it, and it sucks. But you know what? I'm done begging for space in your life. I'm done waiting for a text back just to see you on Facetime with the new crew. I'm done being loyal to someone who already left me without saying a word. So, yeah, it hurts. It hurts like hell. But I'm not gonna sit here and cry over someone who doesn't miss me. I'm Gonna wipe my tears, put on lip gloss or chapstick, whatever. And remind myself I'm not the problem you fumbled. I was a real one. And when that new group starts acting funny, when you remember what it felt like to have someone who actually cared, just know this friendship doesn't do returns.

voice_to_text: I asked my brother not to bring his girlfriend to my wedding. My brother Jake, has this girlfriend named Becca who literally cannot stand not being the center of attention for 5 minutes. Every family dinner, every holiday, every gathering, she finds a way to make it about her. Last Thanksgiving, she announced she was pregnant right when my dad was about to carve the Turkey. Turns out she wasn't even pregnant. Just wanted to see everyone's reactions. So when I was planning my wedding to my fiance, Ryan, I knew I had to do something about the Becca situation. This was going to be my one day, the one day that was supposed to be about me and Ryan starting our life together. I called Jake about three months before the wedding. Hey, so about the wedding, I started. I need to ask you something kind of awkward. What's up, he said. And I could hear him eating cereal in the background. I, I really don't want Becca there. I know that sounds harsh, but she always makes everything about herself and I just can't deal with that stress on my wedding day. The line went quiet for like 10 seconds and Jake exploded. Are you serious right now you're uninviting my girlfriend from your wedding? I'm not uninviting her because she was never invited in the first place. The invitation was just for you. That's the same thing. We've been together for two years. She's basically family. I. Tried to explain that it wasn't personal, that I just wanted one drama free day. But Jake wasn't having it. He said if Becca couldn't come, then he wouldn't come either. I told him that was his choice. Hope think he changed his mind? He didn't. But here's where it gets crazy. The day of my wedding, I'm getting my makeup done in the bridal suite when my cousin Madison bursts in. Uh, you need to see this, he says, shoving her phone in my face. It's Becca's Instagram story. She's posted like 15 videos of herself getting all dressed up, doing her makeup, picking out jewelry. The caption on the last one says, can't wait to celebrate love today with a bunch of heart emojis and the location tagged as our wedding venue. My heart drops. He's coming anyway. Madison nods. Jake's outside right now arguing with your dad about it. He says he changed his mind and decided to bring her. I'm standing there in my wedding dress, half my makeup done and I have to deal with.

Friends think I'm the innocent one. Wait till they find out what I do for a living. Seven years since graduation, and these women still had me mentally catalogued as the virgin who cried during health class. Lena took it upon herself to arrange a reunion for our high school friend group. I was curious what everyone had been up to, so I went. Big mistake. Second I walked in. Oh, my god. You look exactly the same. Still our innocent baby. They handed me an actual juice box while they opened three bottles of wine. We got you apple juice since you probably don't drink, Ashland said. Like I was 12. Sit here, sweetie. She pointed to the floor. All of them took the couch and chairs. Every single seat except the floor. So there I was, 25 years old, sitting cross legged on Lena's carpet, holding a juice box while they clinked wine glasses above my head. They really thought I was the same shy bookworm from high school. Sure, ladies. Whatever helps you sleep at night. They started playing Never Have I Ever. But stopped. Actually. Wait. She won't have done anything. Ashley nodded to me, and they all laughed. I sipped my juice box. They told relationship stories, then caught themselves. Oops, forgot innocent ears were here. More laughing. Lena actually covered my ears during one story about her honeymoon. I'm 25 years old, and this grown woman covered my ears. They asked me to grab More wine from the kitchen. We need to discuss something real quick. I knew what this was. I walked slow, came back to sudden silence. They've been talking about me, obviously. We were just saying you'd be perfect for Lena's cousin. He's also. Ashley paused. Inexperienced. They all nodded like they'd solved world hunger. But wait, it got worse. Lena took my phone. No phones during Girls Night. You're always so anti social, reading your little books. My phone literally had 57 unread Instagram notifications. But sure, Lena, I'm anti social. We're going to Ashland's Bachelorette next month, April said. But it might be too much for you. The stripper stuff would make you so uncomfortable. They all agreed I'd be traumatized. Remember when she didn't even know what a thong was? That was freshman year. Eleven years ago. I leaned over to grab my juice box from the side table and saw Ashland's phone lit up next to it, the notification preview at the top. Adults only. No Virgin Mary. April. She actually believes the cousin thing. LMAO. I was about to say something when Lena's boyfriend Mark came home with one of his friends, Cooper. Ashlyn practically ran to stand next to Cooper. Nice to see you again. I wondered how often she was invited over, if she recognized him. Lena introduced me as the most innocent person she knows. Mark barely looked at me. Then his neck snapped to look again. His eyes went wide. Really wide. He pulled out his phone. Type something quick, and his face went from confused to shocked. Holy. Mark showed Cooper his phone. The girls stopped talking. What's wrong? Lena asked. Mark looked at me, then at Lena, then back at me. Your innocent friend is. He couldn't finish. Just turned his phone around. Whatever was on that screen made Cooper's jaw drop. No way. No way. He started frantically googling something. The girls tried to see, but Mark pulled the phone back. She. There's a special guest at Denver Con and Seattle. And Cooper kept scrolling, eyes getting wider. This can't be her, Lena said, trying to grab Mark's phone. She doesn't even wear makeup. But Mark and Cooper were having their own conversation now. Both staring at their phones, then at me, then back at their phones. The one from TikTok, Cooper whispered. 3 million views, Mark confirmed. His eyes went huge. Is that. The girls were getting angry. What are you looking at? Ashlyn demanded. Cooper turned red. Actually

Did faking it actually work out for you? I pretended to be my cousin, the substitute teacher for a day and accidentally got my dream job. I was 19, broke as hell, and still waiting to hear back from community college. My cousin Tyler was a substitute teacher who sometimes paid me to drive him around since his car was trash. One Tuesday morning, he calls me, freaking out. Dude, I just rear ended someone. I'm supposed to be at Westbrook Middle School in 20 minutes. If I miss another day, they'll cut me from their sub list. I was eating cereal in my pajamas. That sucks, man. Wait, he said you still have my school I D. From when you helped me move those boxes last month? Yeah, why? I'm serious. Let's go pretend to be me. Take attendance. Keep them quiet. It's just study hall. I laughed. You're insane. Please. They won't even check. Most subs just sit there anyway. It's one period. Something about the desperation in his voice got to me. Plus, I needed money. I threw on Tyler's spare button down shirt that was way too big and drove to the school with his laminated badge. The front desk lady barely looked up. You must be the sub for Miss Peterson's class. Room 2 13. Here's your clipboard. I walked down that hallway trying to look confident while my heart was pounding. The kids were loud, but not crazy. I took attendance, reading names off The roster. When they asked where their teacher was, I said she had a family emergency and today was independent study. Can we work on homework? This girl asked, absolutely, I said, having no clue what else to tell them. For an hour, I just walked around pretending to supervise while they did whatever. Some kid asked me about math, and I said I'd get back to him. Another wanted to use the bathroom, and I let, like, five kids go because I didn't know the rules. The bell rang, and a whole new group of kids walked in. Nobody had told me there were multiple periods. I panicked, but tried to play it cool. Same routine independent study day. The projector wasn't working, so sorry, no video today. I made them read silently and told them I'd be grading papers instead. I just stared at Tyler's lesson plan book, trying to figure out what I was supposed to be doing. Third period came, then fourth. I was making it up as I went. When kids got too loud, I'd say stuff like, remember, this affects your participation grade, even though I had no idea how grading worked. During lunch, I hid in an empty classroom and texted Tyler updates. He kept saying, you're doing great. Just get through the day. Fifth period, this kid asked me about the Revolutionary War assignment. I panicked and said, what do you think the most important battle was? Then I made them debate It. While I googled stuff on my phone under the desk. By sixth period, I was actually getting comfortable. These kids weren't that different from my little brother and his friends. I started a trivia game about random stuff, and they were actually into it. Then the assistant principal walked in. My

Secret ruined your friendship. I was 15 when my crush, Lucia, pulled me aside after chemistry class. We've been close since sixth grades. I need you to promise me something, she whispered. Her pretty eyes not meeting mine. For a moment, I thought she was going to ask me to the dance. I've been working up the courage for weeks. But something in her voice made my chest tighten. Anything I said, that's when she told me about Friday, how she'd been planning it for months. The teachers who ignored her cries for help, her parents who only cared about her grades. She taking her mom's gun from the locked drawer. The next day she was going to publicly end her life. She planned it all out, a live stream during third period when Miss Lillian would be teaching, when Mister Cole would be in the faculty lounge, when everyone who'd failed her would be watching. She'd make sure they'd see, make sure they'd carry it forever. But not you, she said, squeezing my hand. Don't watch. You're the only one who ever really saw me stood there frozen, feeling her fingers intertwined with mine. Something I dreamed about for months, but not like this. Never like this. Lucia, you can't, I whispered. It's the only way they'll learn. She's the only way things will change. That night, I didn't sleep. I stared at her Instagram, scrolling through photos where her smile never quite reached her eyes. Had I missed It the way she'd stopped eating lunch, how she wore long sleeves even when it was warm. The poem she'd started posting, beautiful but dark. So dark I thought about Miss Lillian who was tough but had three kids at home. Mr Cole who was new and trying his best. The other students who'd see it happen live. The trauma that would ripple through our school like a stone dropped in still water. But Lucia trusted me. She'd held my hand. She'd chosen me to confide in. Wasn't that worth something? By the time three a. M. Hit, I was typing and deleting texts to. What if I was overreacting? What if she hated me forever? What if I lost the only girl who'd ever made me feel like I mattered? Then I imagine the alternative, her empty desk and chemistry. Her parents at a funeral instead of graduation. A live stream that could never be unseen, all because I stayed silent. 5:00am, I called the sewer's light prevention hotline. They connected me to the police. My voice cracked as I explained everything. The officer's tone grew urgent asking for details. I wished I didn't have. Lucia's full name, her address, the exact time she'd mentioned you're saving her life, the officer said it felt like I was ending it. They got to Lucia at 7:00am just as she was setting up her phone in her bedroom. Pills were already laid out. The note was already written. The local news Called it a mental health crisis intervention. They interviewed our principal, who promised better resources, more counselors, real change. They never used our names, but Lucia knew. She didn't come back to school for two months. When she did, she wouldn't look at me, wouldn't answer my texts. Her new friends formed a protective wall around her in the hallways. I heard whispers that I betrayed her, that I violated her trust, that I only did it because I couldn't handle rejection. The school did change. They hired two new counselors, started a peer support program, trained teachers on warning signs. Everyone said I'd done the right thing, but I felt like I'd lost everything. Three years later, on graduation day, I found a note in my locker. I instantly recognized Lucia's handwriting. What I read made my heart drop full.

I guess that's it. That's all you're gonna say, huh? Uh, after all this time I call you and you have nothing. Yeah, this is weird. Like I don't really know what you want from me. Well, I would like some answers to start. What happened? Why did you leave me the way that you did on our wedding day? Um, I guess it's a little complicated. I can't really talk about it. Justin. What you did to me and all my friends and and our families, I mean, was awful. You owe me some kind of explanation. Look, I'm I'm sorry. Okay. I mean, did you leave me for a guy? Just tell me. No, no, it's nothing like that. I promised I wouldn't talk about it. What do you mean you promised? Who did you make a promise to? I can't talk about it. I can't tell you what happened. All I can say is I feel terrible. I really do. But I can't I can't I can't tell You, Justin, that's bullshit, okay? You're a liar. And I don't understand why you would go through all of that trouble to get engaged and, and plan a wedding with me. I mean, you have to admit that you leading was not just cold feet. It was a lot more than that. So I deserve to know what the promise is. Who the hell you promise what? Because you not get on an altar and promise me anything. So you better give me some answers. Alright? But you can't, you can't tell him I, I said anything. Okay? Who do you, who are you talking about? Who can I tell? I, I don't know what you're talking about. Who is he?

voice_to_text: Father always treated me like I wasn't his real daughter, so I made sure he found out on Father's Day that he was right. When mom married Garrett, I was 8 years old and desperate for a father figure. My biological dad had walked out when I was 3, leaving behind only a box of photos and unpaid child support. Garrett seemed perfect at first. He fixed our broken faucet, taught me to ride a bike and never missed my school place. But everything changed when my half brother Colton was born. Suddenly, I became the unwanted stepchild. Garrett would buy Colton expensive toys while telling me my allowance was earned, not given. At family dinners, he'd brag about Colton's first steps while dismissing my honorable achievements. When relatives visited, he'd introduce Colton as my son and me as my wife's daughter. The worst part was how he'd punish me for things Colton did. When Colton broke the living room lamp, I was grounded for not watching him properly when he drew on the walls, I lost my art supplies for setting a bad example. Mom never intervened. She was so grateful to have a husband again that she pretended not to notice the favoritism. By high school, I'd accepted my role as the family scapegoat. I worked part time jobs to pay for my own clothes and saved every penny for college. Garrett made it clear I wouldn't receive help with tuition. That money was reserved for Colton's future. Everything changed during my senior year when I needed medical records for a scholarship application. While searching through mom's filing cabinet, I found my birth certificate under father. It listed someone named Pierce Buchanan, not unknown. Like I'd always been told. Pierce Buchanan wasn't some deadbeat who abandoned us. A quick internet search revealed he was a successful architect living two hours away. His company website showed a man with my exact nose and stubborn cowlick. I found his phone number and called, hands shaking first you can and speaking. Hi, I managed. This might sound crazy, but I think you're my father. My name is. Oh, my god, he interrupted. I've been looking for you for 15 years. We met the following weekend at a coffee shop. Pierce explained how mom had vanished while he was deployed overseas with the National Guard. When he returned, she'd moved and changed her phone number. He'd hired investigators, but she'd covered her tracks. Well, I never stopped looking. And showing me a folder filled with investigator reports. I've been paying child support to a state account this whole time, hoping it would reach you somehow. Those unpaid child support checks, mom and Garrett had been collecting them for years. Pierce was nothing like the deadbeat mom had described. He was kind, successful and genuinely interested in my life. He'd saved every penny of child support in a college fund, enough to cover four years at any university I chose. For months, I Kept our relationship secret while planning my revenge. Pierce helped me gather evidence of the diverted child support. We documented every payment, every forged signature, every lie. Father's Day arrived and Garrett expected his usual Celebration. Colton had made him a clay mug.

So you're telling me you. You. You, a girl with a degree and everything, who passed all these, you know, tests and everything like that, you want to go out with a guy like me? A guy who works on cars all day and doesn't have much of an education? Oh, yes. Yes, that is. That is what I'm telling you. That I did not ask you out because you were or were not a mechanic. Just because you were really kind to me and I thought it might be nice to get to know you better. Hmm. I don't know, Vicky. I mean, you. You're telling me all this now, and it sounds great, but once. Once I finish your car and you're asking me for the 20% discount on. On your brakes and your wheel and all that, it's just. Oh my god, no. You know what? How about. How about you finish the car, I pay for the car, we're done with the whole car situation, and then we go out? Yeah, that's. That's great, but, you know, do you have another car that you need to work on? Oh my god! Come on, Chris. Hey, Chris. No, no, Chris, I only have one car. Are you willing to go out with somebody that only has one car? Yeah. Chris, would you go on a second date with Vicky? We'll pay for it. Come on, man, this is one more date. If you say no, this will Be the only dumb thing that you do. Ricky, you're telling the truth. You really like me for me? Yes. Yes, I like you for you. Enough to go on the radio and say, can we please go on another date? Yeah. I doubt she'd put all this effort in just to get a little bit of a discount on her car work. Chris. I mean, are you kidding? We had a really. I mean, I had a really nice time. I really enjoyed spending time with you. I thought, gosh, this is so nice. Maybe we should do this again. I didn't think, gosh, this is so nice, we should do this again so I can get something for my car. I mean, who knows? I don't know. It's just a second date. But I would really like to go on one so we can hang out some more. I mean, I had a good time, too, but that's. That's why I'm so skeptical. Skeptical? Well, life is risky, Chris. Come on. Yeah. All right. I'll go out with you again. You'll do it? Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. All right! Awesome. Congratulations, Vicky. You got your second date. Great. Thank you. Oh, my god. You're welcome. I love the second date. I'm already planning your guys's marriage in my head.

Doctors, what patient made you go, how are you even alive? I had an eight year old diagnosed with type 1 diabetes. Without insulin, she'd be dead in six months. I called the mother in to explain the situation. When I, I told her, she was totally relaxed. Oh, I know about the diabetes. The other doctor mentioned it last week. We're handling it naturally, though. No insulin needed. I thought I misheard her. Your daughter needs insulin to live. Her pancreas doesn't work anymore. She will die without it. The mother smiled. We're doing carrot juice therapy instead, 60 ounces a day. Diabetes is just toxin build up in the pancreas. The juice flushes it out. She said it like she was explaining a recipe. I tried showing her the test results. Her blood sugar is 680. She could slip into a coma any moment. The mother stood up and helped her daughter to her feet. Well, thanks for your opinion, but we're good. The carrot cleanse takes three weeks to work fully. We're only on week two. I blocked the door. You can't leave. She's in diabetic ketoacidosis. She needs emergency treatment. The mother laughed. This is why people don't trust doctors. You create fake emergencies. Move or I'm calling security on you. She pushed past me with her barely conscious daughter. After she left, I immediately called my supervisor and hospital legal. We needed an emergency ethics meeting. A child was going to die within an hour. We had social services, the chief of pediatrics and legal on a conference call. The mother had been flagged at three other hospitals. Each time she left when doctors mentioned insulin. I explained the situation. She's giving her type 1 diabetic daughter only carrot juice. The kids in active ketoacidosis. She'll be dead in weeks, maybe days. Legal said without immediate danger, we couldn't force treatment. The chief suggested we call the mother for a formal care meeting, make it sound routine. When I called, she was surprisingly cheerful. Oh, a second opinion? Sure. I love educating doctors about natural healing. She came back that afternoon with a rolling suitcase. Inside were printed Facebook posts, blog articles and a Powerpoint on her laptop she set up like she was giving a business presentation. Let me show you how Big Pharma created the die diabetes lie. She actually had slides. Slide 1, Insulin is made from GMO bacteria. Slide 2, diabetes didn't exist before 1920. Slide 3, every culture has a vegetable that cures diabetes. Chief of pediatrics interrupted. Ma'am, your daughter's blood sugar was 680. She's dying. The mother clicked to her next slide. That's exactly what they want you to think. Look at this graph I made. Couple days later, the school called 9, 1 1. The daughter had collapsed in the cafeteria, completely unresponsive. When they arrived, I recognized her immediately. The orange tinted skin was unmistakable. Blood sugar was 1,100. She was in a diabetic coma. The Mother rushed in 20 minutes later carrying her suitcase of documents. She fainted because they gave her school lunch instead of her juice. That processed food is poison. The kids started seizing right there on the gurney. Foam.

To dated someone out of your league. How did you do it? My ex, Ashley, thought our relationship was charity work. Every time we went somewhere together, she'd find ways to remind me I'd never find someone like her again. It started with her introducing me as just a friend at bars. When guys hit on her, she'd let them buy her drinks, then mention she had a boyfriend after. You should see their faces when I point to you. She'd laugh later. The shock is hilarious. The worst was when she just disappeared one Saturday. No text, nothing. Then I saw her Instagram story. Ashley on some yacht wearing basically a string bikini, sitting on some guy's lap while he popped champagne. Videos of her dancing with a bunch of rich dudes, them doing body shots off her stomach. Best day ever. With location tag, Miami Beach. We live in Jersey. When she came back Sunday night, sunburnt and hungover, I was furious. Where the f were you? She rolled her eyes. Tom invited me to his yacht party last minute. It was a networking opportunity. Tom was some crypto guy who'd been dming her for months. You went to Miami without telling me? She laughed, actually laughed. It was last minute, babe. These chances don't come often. When I showed her the videos of her grinding on those guys, she shrugged. It's a boat thing. Everyone was dancing. Don't be so uptight. You're in a relationship, I yelled. Yeah. And I came back, didn't I? She ruffled my hair like I was a child. I could have stayed in Miami. Tom has this insane condo. He wanted to fly me to Ibiza next week. She pinched my cheek. But I came back to Jersey to my little computer nerd, my anxious overthinker who's mad about a boat party. She kicked off her heels and collapsed on my bed. I looked past all these red flags with rose colored glasses until the one year anniversary incident happened. I planned everything perfectly just for her on our anniversary. Flowers in hand, champagne in my car, reservation at her favorite restaurant. I was about to knock on her apartment door to surprise her when I heard voices through her open window. Ashley and her friends, all Instagram model types who made fun of me whenever they visited. Ash still don't get it. Her friend Jenna was saying, why are you with him? You could have literally anyone. I stepped closer to the window, still holding the roses like an idiot. Ashley laughed. You want to know a secret? He'll never leave me, ever. I could do anything and he'd take it. I have complete freedom. I go to Miami. He waits. I hang with my exes. He deals with it. Tom keeps flying me places. Brad takes me to dinner. But this one, she laughed again. He worships me, like actually worships me. But don't you want someone better? Another voice asked. Eventually, yeah. But you know how Brad destroyed my confidence when he cheated with that bartender? This one looks at me like I'm God. He tells me I'm perfect every morning, begs me not to leave him. I need that right now. I heard them all giggling. Once I feel like myself again, I'll find someone on my level. But for now, he's exactly what my ego needs, like therapy but free. They all burst out laughing. I stood there, flowers in hand, and knew something had to change. She needed me for her ego. Time to take away her supply. I spent the next two weeks planning exactly how to.

video_description: Won't even tell you they changed your schedule üò≠üòÇ #retailproblems #managersbelike
voice_to_text: Hey, Alex, do you want more hours this week? I actually want less. School just started, so I don't want to work more than 25 hours a week. I need you to at least keep doing your 35 to 39 hours a week. Then where's my raising benefits? That's basically full time. 40 hours is full time. You only work 39, you don't get any benefits. Either way, I need less hours. I can't keep working six days a week. I have classes on Tuesdays and Thursdays, so I would appreciate it if I could be off those days. Only full time employees get a set schedule. Since you're part time, I can't guarantee anything, but I'll see what I can do. Fine, but I'm telling you now, if I'm scheduled on Tuesday or Thursday, I'm calling in sick. Are you sure you can't be here during school? You can't tune in on a zoom or something? No. No one wants to work these days. Hey, I overheard you asking Alex if you wanted extra hours. I'm willing to take them if they're available. Are you part time or full time? Full time. You probably already have enough hours. I'm actually only scheduled to come in three days and work 25 hours this week. That's why I'm willing to pick up any extra hours. Maybe next week. We can't afford to give you any more hours this week. Hey, Alex, let me know if you want more hours, alright? I Want less? Wait. Would you wanna switch schedules? Yes. Hey, Frankie, put me down. I mean, put Alex down for those extra hours.

My girlfriend said, I need a real man in front of our friends, so I just smiled and left. This morning, my phone exploded with 32 missed calls. It happened at Connor's birthday party. Lauren stood up during dinner and announced to our entire friend group, I've been seeing someone else. I need a real man, not a kindergarten teacher who makes 30 K a year. Everyone went silent. Then Connor actually started clapping. Finally. We've all been saying, you deserve better. The whole table nodded like they'd rehearsed this. I just smiled, put down my fork, and walked out. No drama, no begging. What? They didn't know. I've been teaching kids during the day, but spending nights getting my pilot's license. My broke teacher savings account actually had 180 K from cryptocurrency investments I'd made 3 years ago. But here's the real kicker. My uncle had been battling cancer for months. He owned a small aviation company that did scenic tours and flight training. Two days before Connor's party, he'd asked me to take over the business when he retired. The company was worth 1.2 million, debt free. I've been keeping it quiet while I finished my commercial pilot certification. Lauren knew about my uncle's business, but thought it was just some tiny operation with a couple old planes. She had no idea about the government contracts, the corporate partnerships, or the fact that we were expanding into helicopter tours next year. The night she humiliated me, I called my Uncle and said yes to everything. We started the paperwork immediately. I'd also been secretly applying to international schools. Teaching abroad had always been my dream, but Lauren constantly shut it down, saying it was unrealistic and running away from responsibility. The next week, I put in my transfer request to teach at an international school in Dubai. Posted one photo on Instagram. Me in the cockpit of a small plane with the caption new adventures. Lauren's new real man. Turns out he was married with two kids. His wife found their texts and posted everything on Facebook, tagging Lauren's workplace. She got fired from her marketing job for the drama. The guy's wife also sent screenshots to Lauren's parents, were mortified their daughter was involved with a married man. Meanwhile, my Dubai teaching position came with an 80 five k salary, free housing, and I started a weekend flight instruction business. But the real money came from taking over my uncle's company. Within two months, I'd expanded to corporate charters and landed a contract with a luxury resort chain worth 400 k annually. Connor started following my Instagram again after seeing photos of me flying over Dubai skyline. Even posted a comment, dude had no idea you were doing all this. Tanya from our friend group sent a DM. We all feel terrible about that night. Too late for fake friendship. And even faker.

After Dad's funeral, my family threw my stuff out on the lawn, changed the locks, and said, this house belongs to us now. Get out. I said nothing. Their faces turned pale when the notary revealed the truth. See, my stepmom Cynthia and her twin daughters, Brittany and Ashley, had moved in when I was 12. Dad always treated them like princesses, while I got hand me downs and endless chores. Blood isn't everything, Chloe, he'd say, whenever I complained about the obvious favoritism. The twins got new cars at six. Teen, I got a lecture about being grateful they got college funds. I got told to figure it out yourself. By the time I turned 18, it was clear I wasn't welcome anymore. College isn't for everyone, sweetie, Cynthia cooed, flashing that fake smile. Maybe try community college. There's a nice apartment complex downtown that takes monthly renters. So I left. I worked two jobs. Diner waitress by day, hotel cleaner by night, and clawed my way through nursing school. Six years of exhaustion, but I graduated with honors. I barely visited home every holiday invitation felt more like pity than family. Still, I built my own life. A job at the regional hospital, a small starter house, even a steady relationship with a fellow nurse named Thomas. Life finally felt stable. Then last year, dad was diagnosed with early onset dementia. Suddenly, my phone lit up non stop. We need help with Dad, Cynthia begged. One late night, You're the nurse in the family. You understand this medical stuff. When I came back, the site, it broke me. Dad barely recognized me. The house was filthy, his meds unorganized, while the twins partied by the pool and charged spa trips to his cards. He looked scared, like a child left alone. When I suggested professional caregivers, Cynthia's mask slipped. We're family, Chloe. We can handle our own. Besides, do you know how expensive those people are? They couldn't handle anything. On my next visit, I found dad wandering outside in his pajamas at 3:00am. Neighbors had called the cops. Inside, the air stank from his accidents. No one cleaned up. Britney live streamed makeup tutorials while Ashley planned her next shopping spree. This is neglect, I told Cynthia. Her eyes narrowed. Don't you dare lecture us. Where were you the past 10 years? Now you swoop in like you're better than us. That night, I made a decision. I quit my job, broke up with Thomas, and moved back home. For eight months, I became Dad's full time caregiver. Every morning, I bathed him, dressed him, and fed him. I kept his meds straight, comforted him during episodes, and listened when he had lucid moments. He'd tell me stories about mom, who passed away when I was little. I'm sorry, sweetheart, he whispered. One afternoon, his eyes finally make clear. I wasn't fair to you. Cynthia convinced me treating everyone equally meant giving them more because they weren't Really? Mine. But you were always my real daughter. The twins hated me for it. They wind I was too controlling and making them look bad. All while draining his savings on vacations. When I confronted Brittany, she just smirks. Dad wanted us to be happy. He's not going to live forever, so we might as well enjoy it now. His decline was brutal. I
