I lost my shit and screamed at my girlfriend to get out of my house after what her stepbrother did. My girlfriend, Taylor and I were both 20 and things had been going pretty solid between us for about eight months. She had this stepbrother, Ethan, who was 23. And honestly, the few times I'd met him before, he seemed like a normal dude, maybe a little too friendly, but nothing that set off major alarm bells. Two weeks ago, Taylor asked if Ethan could come hang out at my place for a few hours. She said he was bringing pizza and beer and since my parents were visiting my aunt for the weekend, I figured why not? My little sister Mia is 15 and she was just gonna stay upstairs doing homework anyway. So they showed up around 7. Ethan had this huge grin and two cases of beer. We started drinking and playing video games, just chilling on the couch. Everything was normal for like an hour. Taylor was curled up next to me. Ethan was cracking jokes about the game and I was thinking this was actually pretty fun. Then Ethan said he needed to use the bathroom. I pointed down the hall to the one on the first floor. Taylor and I kept playing and I didn't even notice how long he'd been gone until we heard yelling upstairs. My blood went cold. Mia never yells. We both jumped up and ran upstairs and I found My sister standing in her doorway crying, like full on sobbing. Ethan was right there in the hallway looking all flustered and red in the face. I immediately asked Mia, what?

My sister called a family meeting at Mom's kitchen table, and I already know this is about my daily visits. You visiting mom every single day makes me look like a bad daughter, she says while scrolling through her phone. You're babying her. She's only 72 and you're acting like she's some martyr. It's creating an unhealthy codependency. I read about it in my therapy group. Then she drops it. New rule you visit once a month just like me, or I'm changing mom's locks. I already talked to a locksmith. And don't even think about making copies. I'm getting those special locks that can't be duplicated. Get mom for backup. But she just shrugs and says whatever we think is best, though she does quietly add that she enjoys the daily visits. Classic mom avoiding conflict. I noticed she puts her keys in the refrigerator, but I don't say anything because what's the point? Fine. I tell my sister once a month. But when this goes wrong, remember, this was your idea. Week one without my daily visits and the neighbor calls me at work. Your mom was outside at 3:00am looking for her cat. Thing is, mom doesn't have a cat. Never has. I want to rush over, but my sister already threatened to change the lock, so I call her instead. The neighbors being dramatic, she says. Haven't had time to check myself, but Mom's fine. Week 2, mom calls me crying that someone stole all her Food. My sister checks, text me a photo of a full fridge like I'm the crazy one. Doesn't notice it's all expired. The milk dated three weeks ago. Week 3 gets worse. The bank calls because mom tried to withdraw 30,000 in cash for the nice man fixing my roof. There is no man. There's no roof damage. My sister still insists I'm overreacting. Stop hovering. She can manage her own money. After the bank incident, I can't help myself. I drive by Mom's house anyway. Her newspapers are piling up. I leave groceries on the porch and run before my sister can find out. I keep my distance like she demanded. Then mom shows up at my house one morning. She walked here. That's eight miles. In her slippers. Where's your father? She asked me. Is he picking me up? Dad's been dead five years. My sister says she's just having a bad day. The grocery store calls next. Mom's been there four hours, putting items in other people's carts, telling everyone she's waiting for her husband. The manager says she's been returning the same item to different aisles over and over. My sister arrives first, and I hear her frustration over the phone. Mom, stop being difficult. Mom's response breaks me. I'm sorry, miss, but I don't know you. When I finally get there, mom immediately relaxes when she sees me and grabs my hand. Oh, good, you're here. That angry lady keeps following me. A week later, Three towns over, police find mom at a McDonald's. She. She's been there since morning, telling everyone she's waiting for her kids after school. She thinks it's 1987. She keeps asking the female officer if she should wear her red dress to see Tom sell it tonight because he likes when I show a little leg. When my sister shows up, mom backs away from her. I don't go with strangers, but she sees me and lights up. Oh, thank god. This woman keeps claiming she knows me. My sister's crying now. Mom, please. I'm your daughter. Mom turns to me. Whisper, that woman seems angry. Is she bothering you? The doctor's appointment mom missed three times finally happens because I drive her there. He pulls us both aside after the brain scan. How long has your mother been showing signs of dementia? My sister actually laughs. She doesn't have dementia. The doctor turns his computer screen toward us. She's stage 4. These symptoms have been building for at least a year. And she's lost 15 pounds. My stomach drops. We didn't notice under her cardigan. My sister's still arguing when he asks who's been managing her care. No one. I mean, my sister used to visit daily, but I made her stop. I told her it was unhealthy. Codependency. I read about it online. The doctor's face changes completely. You stopped her care routine. Why? The doctor looks straight at my sister. Your sister's daily visits were probably the Only thing keeping her stable without routine and familiar

When did extreme parenting nearly cost them everything? My parents were obsessed with this article they'd read about teenage sleep cycles and peak growth hormone production. At 15, I had the most humiliating bedtime of anyone I knew. 7 p m. Sharp. No exceptions. While my friends were doing homework, studying for tests, or just living normal teenage lives, I was lying in the dark, listening to the world continue without me. It didn't matter if I had a chemistry exam the next morning or a group project. You. Mom would physically take my textbooks away at six forty five PM and march me to my room. Your health is more important than anything, she'd say. While dad would at his favorite line about how the teenage brain needs 12 hours of sleep for proper development. I'd failed three tests this semester alone because I couldn't study. And my teachers were starting to think I didn't care about school. The worst part was hearing my Xbox notifications going off every night at 9 p m. When my friends logged on to play together. They'd given up inviting me months ago. My parents had installed blackout curtains, removed all electronics from my room, and even put a baby monitor. Yes, a baby monitor at 15, to make sure I stayed in bed. So I started getting creative. First, I tried the classic pillow under the blanket trick. But the baby monitor's night vision caught me sneaking out immediately. Then I discovered That if I position myself just right, I could hide under my desk in the monitor's blind spot and use my phone with the brightness all the way down. But mom figured that out when she did a random wellness check. Ten PM. After that, they started taking my phone at six thirty PM, too, so I got more desperate and smarter. They installed a smart lock on my door that would alert their phones if it opened after seven PM. I Learned to pick it with a Bobby pin. They put tape on the door frame to see if I'd left. I Learned to carefully remove and replace it. This went on for months, an exhausting war of attrition where I was fighting just to have the base freedom. Then one fateful night, I'd finally won a small victory. My parents had been at a dinner party and came home exhausted, going straight to bed without their usual final check. I waited until I heard dad snoring, then carefully positioned myself under the desk with my phone, ready to finally join my friends online for the first time in forever. I was just about to text them when I smelled something wrong. A sharp chemicals smell that made my nose tingle. At first I thought maybe I was imagining it from being cooped up in my room too long, but it got stronger. Then I recognized it. Gas. Natural gas. Like when mom had accidentally blown at the Pilot Light last year. My heart started racing as I crept to my door and carefully opened it. The smell hit me like a wall. The entire hallway reeked of it. I ran to the kitchen and saw the problem immediately. One of the burner knobs was turned to the on position, but there was no flame. Gas had been pouring into our house for who knows how long. My hands shaking, I turned off the burner and opened the kitchen window, then ran to my parents'room. Mom

Wife confessed during a family dinner that she always wished she married my best friend. So I packed my things and left, but now she's begging me to come back. Last Sunday at my in law's house for their 30th anniversary dinner, everything seemed perfect. My wife Emma was helping her mom arrange flowers while I watched the game with her dad. My buddy Josh was there, too. He's been like family since college, always invited to everything. The whole extended family was there, maybe 20 people total. Emma's cousins, her weird Uncle Dave who likes vintage spoons. Her grandmother, who still asks when we're having kids even though we've been trying for three years. After dinner, her Aunt Linda starts this thing where everyone shares their sliding door moments. Those what if scenarios that keep you up at night. Everyone's going around the table sharing cute stories. Her cousin Sarah talks about almost moving to Japan to teach English. Uncle Dave mentions nearly buying Bitcoin in 2,010. Her brother Tom jokes about almost joining the military instead of becoming an accountant. Normal, harmless stuff that gets people thinking. Then it's Emma's turn. She's had a few glasses of wine, and she gets this dreamy, distant look in her eyes, like she's somewhere else entirely. Honestly, she says, looking directly at Josh across the table, I sometimes think I should have dated Josh instead of Mark back in college. We just click so naturally, you know, the entire table goes Dead silent. Her dad literally chokes on his coffee and starts coughing violently. Her mom drops her fork with a loud clatter. Her grandmother's mouth falls open. I'm sitting right there like a complete idiot, watching my wife of eight years fantasize about my best friend in front of our entire family. Josh's face goes bright red. He starts stammering something about how that's not appropriate. But Emma just keeps going like she's in some kind of trance. We have so much more in common than Mark and I do. Josh actually listens when I talk about my art projects. He gets my sense of humor. He remembers little things I say. Sometimes I wonder if I settled too quick. That last part hit like a freight train. Settled? After eight years of marriage, two miscarriages, buying our first house together, and me working overtime to pay for her art supplies. I settled. I excused myself to the bathroom. But really, I just sat in my car for 20 minutes trying to process what had just happened. My hands were shaking. I called my brother Mike, but couldn't even form words to explain. When I came back inside, everyone was pretending nothing happened, making awkward small talk about the weather in Emma's mom's new garden. But the damage was done. You could cut the tension with a knife. We drove home in complete silence. 45 minutes of pure hell. The next morning, I packed a bag and went to my Brother's place. Without saying a word to Emma. I just couldn't look at her. Here's where it gets really messed up, though. Josh calls me that afternoon, absolutely panicking. His voice is shaking on the phone. Turns out Emma had been texting him for months. And I mean hundreds of messages. She'd been telling him how unhappy she was in our marriage, how she'd made a mistake choosing me, how they were meant to be together. The whole time, I thought we were working through our fertility issues. She was planning her escape. Josh shows me some of the text. When we meet up, I think about you. When I'm with Mark. Do you ever imagine what our life could have been like? I married the wrong person. And I'm finally ready to admit it. The worst part. Josh had been telling her to work on our marriage this whole time. He'd been trying to talk her out of these feelings, suggesting couples therapy, telling her she was just going through a rough patch that all marriages face. Emma's been showing up at my work every day this week, crying in the parking lot about how it was just a stupid comment fueled by wine. She keeps saying she didn't mean it.

When did your girlfriend's family realize you weren't just a bartender? I'm 32 and my girlfriend's parents still think I'm pouring cheap beer at some dive bar. Last week her mother cornered me in their kitchen while my girlfriend was upstairs. She pressed $300 in my hand and whispered for gas money. I know those tips can't be much. My girlfriend comes from old money and I started working at 14. Her parents never miss a chance to remind me where I belong. We've been together two years, but every family dinner felt like a job interview. I was failing. Last night was her father's retirement party. Three hundred guests at the country club. At the entrance, her mother looked at my watch and frowned. The coat check had a lost and found if you need something more appropriate. It was a ten thousand dollar Rolex. She assumed it was fake. During cocktail hour, her mother dragged me around. This is Doctor Morrison, Judge Williams, then me. This is my daughter's boyfriend. He works in the service industry. Her Aunt Patricia asked what exactly I did. Before I could speak, her mother said, he pours drinks beer, mostly downtown somewhere. Patricia touched my arm sympathetically and asked about my career goals. Her father intercepted me by the bar. You parked in the member lot. Staff and vendors use the back entrance. The guard mentioned your car doesn't have a member sticker. I drove a hundred thousand dollar Mercedes. He assumed I'd stolen the spot. Then he pulled up his phone. There's a management training program at this restaurant chain. Six week course. I know the regional director. He showed me the application. Thirty five thousand to start, but it's steady. At dinner, they put us at table 23, near the service station. Her parents sat at the head table under a chandelier. Her father gave his retirement speech. He thanked his colleagues, praised his children's accomplishments. When he mentioned my girlfriend, he said, still waiting for her to find someone worthy of the family name. He stared at me while the room chuckled. After dessert, her parents ambushed us by the restrooms. Her mother had printed emails from her friend's husband. He owns several franchises. Fast food. But management track. 40,000 to start. My phone exploded with notifications. 50 messages, then 100. Major supplier threatening to pull out of tomorrow's contract signing. Monday morning, her father announced. Eight sharp. He's expecting you. Don't be late or hungover. The texts kept coming. My business partner, our attorney. The Japanese distillery representatives were furious about something. Five million dollar exclusive import deal about to collapse. Silence that. Her mother snapped. This is about our daughter's future. My girlfriend snatched the papers and ripped them up. He doesn't need your help. Listen to her. Her mother said to me. So desperate to defend you, she's become delusional. This is what you've reduced her to. Her father leaned in, his breath thick with scotch. Real men don't let their women pay for dinner. How often does she cover your rent? Her mother already had her phone out. I've been talking to my attorney. There are ways to protect her trust fund from certain types of people. Someone with ambition, her father added. Someone with education. Someone who doesn't smell like beer. And desperation. I excused myself to handle the crisis. When I returned, her mother was showing my girlfriend photos. Remember Christopher? Harvard Law, just made partner. He still asks about you. That's when Mister Fitzgerald stood up from his table near the stage. Everyone knew him. He'd been supplying restaurants in the city for 40 years. Excuse me, he called out, walking straight toward me. Are you Daniel? Her parents exchanged amused looks. Her father actually laughed. This is just the boyfriend. He tends bar somewhere downtown. He's Daniel Reeves, my girlfriend said, standing up. He owns Vintage Proof and the Sterling Room. Fitzgerald's face lit up. You're

What's the funniest thing your little girl did after tasting wine? So this actually happened at our house last month, and I still don't know whether to laugh or feel guilty. We were having a simple dinner. Spaghetti salad, nothing fancy. I had my usual glass of red wine sitting next to my water. My daughter, she's 7, tiny and adorable, but sneaky as hell, kept staring at my glass. I thought she was just curious, like always. Well, I turned my head for literally three seconds to grab more sauce, and when I look back, the glass was halfway to empty. She had taken two Big Gulps before I even realized what was happening. Her face scrunched up immediately, like she tasted vinegar. She coughed, smacked her lips, then started laughing. She said, Mommy, your grape juice is. Is dizzy. It's socks juice. She couldn't even find the words. She just kept pointing at her head and saying, brain, go. At first I panicked, like, oh, my god, my child just drank wine. But then she stood up and started wobbling around the table. Not like a cartoon drunk, just clumsy, tripping over her own feet. She put her hands on her hips, pointed at her dad, and slurred, daddy, you. You got pizza face. My husband froze, then started laughing so hard he almost spit his water out. Then she sat back down, rested her chin on her hands, and looked at me super serious. She said, Mommy, I love you, but your juice tastes like. Like toilet grapes. I swear I didn't know whether to laugh or hide under the table. My son was dying, tears rolling down his cheeks. The funniest part was how she tried to keep talking, but her words kept getting mixed up. She said, I'm not drunk, I'm. I'm funned. Fun funned up. Then she clapped for herself like she invented a new word. A minute later she whispered, Shh! The dog is my best friend. Don't tell daddy, and then she burst into random giggles. We gave her water right away and made her sit on the couch. She held the cup with both hands and said, this is boring juice. Bring the funny juice. I told her absolutely not, but she kept repeating it like a chant. Funny juice, funny juice. She eventually leaned back and started humming to herself all off key, like she was singing a secret song only she could hear. About 10 minutes later she just blurted out, sometimes I don't brush my teeth, I just lick the toothpaste. My son screamed, I knew it! I could didn't even stop laughing. It was like the wine unlocked her honesty button. She confessed to hiding candy wrappers under her pillow and stealing her brother's Legos. Every time she said something, she'd giggle and go, oopsies, don't ground me! After a little while, the drowsiness kicked in. She curled up on the couch holding her stuffed bunny and Mumbled Mommy, no more sock juice. Promise. Then she added, almost whispering no more toilet grapes. They made my tongue go zig zag.
NA

I got upset because my son didn't talk to me but talk to my wife. My son Tyler is 8 years old. And until last month, he talked to both of us just fine. But then something changed and he started only talking to my wife, Emma, when he needed something. If I asked him a question, he'd walk over to Emma and whisper the answer to her, then she'd tell me. It was driving me crazy. At first, I thought maybe I did something wrong. Did I yell at him? Was I too strict about his bedtime? I kept asking Emma what was going on, but she just said Tyler was going through a phase and it would pass. But after two weeks of this, I was getting really frustrated. The breaking point came when Tyler scraped his knee falling off his bike in our driveway. I ran over to help him up, but he pushed me away and ran straight to Emma, who was watering plants by the front door. He was crying and pointing at his knee but wouldn't let me near him. Emma cleaned him up and put a Band Aid on while I just stood there feeling like garbage. That night, after Tyler went to bed, I confronted Emma. I told her this wasn't normal and something was seriously wrong. She kept saying it was just a phase, but I could tell she was hiding something. Her voice got all shaky and she wouldn't look Me in the eye. Finally, I said if she didn't tell me what was going on, I was going to take Tyler to see a therapist because this behavior wasn't normal for an 8 year old. That's when Emma broke down crying. She told me that three weeks ago when I was at work late, Tyler had walked into our bedroom while she was changing clothes. Instead of just telling him to knock next time, she freaked out and yelled at him saying he shouldn't see mommy without clothes.

Talk about people who self diagnose themselves like, no, Emily, you do not have 4 different mental disorders just because you saw a TikTok that said if you breathe sometimes and also blink, you might have ADHD. Congratulations. That's called being a human. Look, I get it. Mental health awareness is hella important. It's amazing that people are talking about it more openly now. But here's the problem. Scrolling through hashtags at 2:00am is not the same thing as a professional evaluation. Google is not your therapist. ID Labs, tests are not your psychiatrist. And that one influencer who talks about their symptoms in a story time, definitely not a doctor. When everyone just casually slaps a label on themselves, it waters down the real struggles people actually face. Like someone living with legit OCD is out here battling life every day and then some dude is like, oh my God, I'm so OCD. I color code my closet. No, you're not OCD. You're just organized, my guy. And even with depression, just because you're feeling a little sad one week does not mean you have depression unless you're diagnosed. I don't want to hear it. You're free to self pity in private. But self diagnosing is probably one of the most selfish and attention seeking things you can do. Faith out.

I was in the cafeteria when the assistant principal announced, is Jose still at lunch? My class teacher responded, yes, he's here. My boy Oscar nudged me. Dude, what the hell did you do? That's when we heard it. BRR! Helicopters were filling the school yard. Attention, all students. Return to your classrooms immediately. This is a lockdown. Everyone ran at once. Miss Kelly's hand was digging into my arm. Jose, has anyone unusual tried to contact you recently? What? No. She pulled me away from the windows just as the helicopter noise became deafening. The lights went out. My phone buzzed with a text from an unknown number. Everything's going to be okay. I promise. Someone behind us muttered, maybe it's I C E. The principal spoke again to all staff and students. Code yellow. I repeat, code yellow. Counseling staff to designated areas. A spotlight swept across the windows. Everyone dropped to the floor. Miss Kelly pushed me under a table, her radio crackling with voices I couldn't understand. Mister Doran appeared out of nowhere, shirt soaked with sweat. Jose, get to the conference room now! I followed him out, trying to look normal while my heart was beating out of my chest. The hallways were full of cops. One cop looked directly at me, and his hand moved to his gun. Mister Doran stepped between us. He's with me. One cop spoke into his radio as we passed. I caught two words. Package secured. My mind went Straight to the bag of Mary Jane that I kept in my locker. But I played it cool. More cops ran past toward the gym. Someone shouted about medical equipment, head trauma, but we kept moving. Mister Doran's hand was firm on my back, pushing me forward. Jose, just so we're clear, you haven't been involved in anything illegal, right? Sometimes kids from your background get mixed up in things. Before I could respond, he opened the conference room door and shoved me inside. The room was dark except for the emergency lights. Miss Kelly followed us in. Click. The door locked. Just the three of us. She sat down across from me. There were tears streaming down her face. I had to fight back nervous laughter. Jose. Her voice cracked. Honey. That word made my blood freeze. Teachers don't say honey unless something terrible has happened. There's been an accident. The helicopters were still circling outside this morning at the warehouse where your dad works. A shelving unit collapsed. Your father was. She stopped, took a shaky breath. He didn't make it. Jose, I'm so sorry. I started laughing. This is a crazy prank, even for you, Mister Doran. I saw the helicopters, the police officers, they locked eyes with each other. And I saw Miss Kelly nod like she was silently agreeing to give the full explanation. Turns out the principal was calling for me right when a student had fallen through the gym skylight during maintenance. Coincidence? That made everyone think the helicopters and manhunt were connected to me. It felt like someone had drained all the color out of my heart. I curled up into a ball and started rocking back and forth uncontrollably. I was an orphan. Someone else entered the room, a woman with a clipboard and a blazer that screamed social worker. She started talking about emergency placement, foster care. I grabbed my vape from my pocket, not even caring that Mister Doran was standing right there. Miss Kelly rubbed my back while I heaved. Well, the social worker said, looking at her clipboard, this is what happens when these immigrants don't follow simple safety rules. She shook her head. Your people need to learn that. Excuse me? I looked up, tears still streaming. Mister Doran cleared his throat. What she means is these accidents are unfortunately common in certain communities. Even Miss Kelly nodded. I didn't want to be the one to say it, but, Jose, your people just don't follow safety rules. It's always the same with them. I've seen it 100 times. The social worker continued filling out forms. At least with foster care you'll be in a more stable environment.

My siblings and I sat at dinner when our father smiled and asked, ready to compete for the upstairs bedroom? Again? I stared in shock. Again? I don't want to compete. Oh, sweetie, mom said, reaching across the table to pat my hand. The monthly room assignment builds character. Winners get the master suite. Losers get the basement. My younger brother, Marvin, pushed his food around his plate. My sister Bianca, wouldn't even look up. We've been doing this for three months since we moved to this house. The basement had exposed pipes, no heat, and spiders that dropped from the ceiling at night. Bianca won last month with her debate trophy. Dad continued, pulling out his notebook. So she keeps the room unless one of you beats her achievements this month. The chicken tasted like cardboard in my mouth. This is insane. Other families don't do this. Mom smile tightened. Other families raise weak children. We're raising winners. That night, Bianca came to my basement corner, where I'd hung sheets for privacy. I'm sorry, she whispered. I didn't want to win, but sleeping down here made me sick last time. It's not your fault, I said, but the words felt hollow. Marvin had already stopped talking to both of us. The next morning, dad posted the point chart on the refrigerator. 10 points for A's, 20 for sports victories, 15 for volunteer hours, even five points for who said good morning first. I watched Marvin set his alarm for Four a m. Just to beat us to the kitchen. By week two, Bianca started hiding my homework. I found it crumpled in the trash after getting a zero. Marvin put a dead spider in my backpack during lunch, making me scream in front of everyone. We stopped eating together. Stop helping each other with assignments. Three kids living in the same house, acting like enemies. Look at that competitive spirit! Dad beamed. One morning, after Marvin and Bianca physically fought over who got to take out the trash for points. Mom took photos like it was something to be proud of. My grades started slipping from the stress. I couldn't sleep in the freezing basement, constantly checking for spiders. Bianca developed anxiety attacks. Harvin started pulling out his hair, leaving bald patches. He tried to hide under hats. The monthly meeting came like an execution. We sat in the living room while our parents tally points on their laptops. Bianca, 78 points. Marvin, 81 points. Mom paused dramatically. And Marcus with 92 points. I'd won by doing extra shifts at the food bank, sacrificing sleep I couldn't get anyway. Bianca burst into tears. Marvin threw his notebook at the wall and stormed out. Pack your things, dad said cheerfully. You get the master suite. I stood up slowly. No. The room went silent. Mom smile froze. Excuse me. I'm not moving upstairs. I'm staying in the basement. Dad's face turned red. You earned that room. You're moving up there. Tonight you turned us against each other, I said, my voice shaking. Bianca cries herself to sleep. Marvin won't even look at us anymore. We used to be best friends. You're being dramatic, mom said, but her voice wavered. That night, I dragged my mattress to the basement's main area. Bianca found me there an hour later with her sleeping bag. Marvin appeared in the doorway with his pillows. Without speaking, we built a fort with our mattresses, the way we used to when we were little. I sabotaged your science project, Bianca confessed in the darkness. I know, I said. I deleted your essay. I put laxatives in both your lunches, Marvin whispered. We started laughing. Horrible. Broke

What happens when the ugly duckling becomes prettier than the swan? My older sister London was always the pretty one because she hit puberty first and got the good genes. When I turned 14, I begged my parents for money for skincare products since my face was breaking out everywhere. Paris, you're too young for expensive products, London said, examining her perfect complexion in the mirror. Maybe when you learn to wash your face properly. My skin was basically a minefield of cystic acne, blackheads, and scars from picking. London skin glowed like she had a filter on in real life. She made me wait outside the bathroom every morning while she did her 45 minute skincare routine, straightening already perfect hair while I stood there with toothpaste dripping down my chin. When guys came over to study, she'd parade rue in her cutest outfits, telling them about my pizza face and how I used to eat glue in kindergarten. Natural beauty can't be bought, she'd tell her parents when I complained about needing dermatology appointments. Paris needs to learn that personality matters more than looks. The worst part? She'd leave her expensive products all over the bathroom. Half used bottles of retinol and vitamin C serums she'd abandon for the next trending thing, but somehow I was the one wasting money. London loved reminding me how I'd never get asked to prom. You'll probably die a virgin, she'd laugh. Some of us are just meant to be beautiful. High School ended. London went straight to working at the mall because she wanted to get discovered as a model. Translation she thought her looks would carry her through life. She spent every paycheck on tanning packages and highlights, living for the weekend parties. I went to community college, worked at a pharmacy where I Learned about ingredients. Saved every penny for a dermatologist. London would Snapchat me from clubs while I was studying chemistry. Why are you wasting your Friday night? She'd text. Oh, wait, not like anyone's asking you out anyway. I'm investing in my future. I'd respond, you're just jealous you can't get into the VIP section. After two years, I transferred to state school for nursing. Started understanding how skin actually worked. Learned about retinoids, chemical exfoliants, moisture barriers. Started seeing changes. London kept baking and tanning beds twice a week, sleeping in her makeup after nights out, living on vodka sodas and whatever guy was buying her dinner. She was still gorgeous at 22, but the foundation was getting thicker, the filters working harder. By 25, I had clear skin for the first time in my life. Proper routine, consistent habits, monthly facials. I saved for London. Had her first Botox consultation. Convinced the nurse practitioner missed something when she said it was sun damage, not expression lines. Last month was our cousin's wedding. I walked in feeling confident for once. Hair healthy from years of no heat styling. Skin glowing from retinol and sunscreen. Body Strong from consistent exercise. London cornered me at the cocktail hour. Paris. Oh, my god. What happened to you? Her voice had that desperate edge she used when she needed something. Thanks, London. Just taking care of myself. No, seriously, what are you using? What's your dermatologist's name? Did you get something done? She grabbed my face, turning it side to side in the light. I need to know everything. The

What's the most awkward favor someone has ever called in? My college roommate Derek saved my life sophomore year. I've been drunk at a party and decided to climb onto the frat house roof to impress a girl. When I slipped, Derek caught my arm just as I was going over the edge. Three story drop onto concrete. I would have died. You owe me big time, he'd said, pulling me back up. One day I'm gonna need something huge, and you better deliver. I figured he'd ask me to write his thesis or loan him money after graduation. Normal stuff. Instead, seven years later, I get a call at 2 a m. Remember that favor? Derek's voice was strained. Yeah, of course. What do you need? Long pause. I need you to be my boyfriend at my family reunion this weekend. I laughed, thinking it was a prank. Good one, man. I'm serious. I've been telling my family I have a boyfriend for two years. His name is Jake. You're Jake now? Turns out Derek had come out to his ultra conservative family, but softened the blow by saying he was in a committed relationship with a successful doctor. Doctor part was true. I'm an ER physician. The boyfriend part, not so much. I'm straight, married with a kid on the way. Derek, I can't pretend to be your boyfriend. I don't even know how to. You saved my life. Now I'm asking you to save my relationship with My family. My grandmother is 94. This might be her last reunion. She keeps asking when she'll meet Jake. The desperation in his voice got me. What about my wife? What do I tell Sarah? Tell her the truth. Tell her everything. Sarah thought it was hilarious. You literally owe him your life, babe. Toby, Jake for a weekend. That's how I found myself at a massive family reunion in Ohio, holding Derek's hand while his aunt Martha grilled me about our love story. Derek had created an entire fictional history. How we met at a medical conference, first date at an Italian restaurant, even what I supposedly said when I first told him I loved him. The worst part was his cousin Brandon, who kept trying to set me up with his friend. If things don't work out with Derek, he'd whisper, call me. Everything peaked at the talent show. Apparently, Jake had promised to perform a couple's dance routine with Derek. I can't dance at all. We stumbled through three minutes of what was supposed to be a tango while 60 relatives filmed it. But the real awkwardness came when grandma pulled me aside. I know, she said quietly. My blood went cold. Know what? You're not really dating my grandson. She patted my hand. Derek's actual boyfriend posted on Instagram yesterday from Cabo. But you're a good friend for doing this. Are you going to tell anyone? She's smiled. I'm 94, sweetheart. I just want my grandson. To be happy. If he needs this little show to feel comfortable, that's fine. But next reunion, tell him to bring the real one. Derek finally brought his actual boyfriend to Christmas dinner that year. Turns out his name really is Jake, which LED to a very confusing introduction when they explained I was the other Jake from the reunion. We're still friends. Sarah still calls me Jake sometimes just to mess with me. And yes, that Tango video went viral in the family group chat. I'm never living it down.
NA

My boss said I shouldn't work above my pay grade, so I worked at exactly my pay grade. I've been at this company for three years. When Donald completely humiliated me during a big meeting in front of everyone I worked with. Maybe we could save time by changing how we handle these reports. I suggested holding up this diagram I'd spent my whole weekend making. Let's not work above our pay grade, shall we, Tom? He said with this condescending laugh that made everyone uncomfortable. Your entry level, not management. You need to learn your place. Do what you're paid to do, nothing more. He moved to the next slide like he hadn't just insulted everything I'd done. Stay in your lane, Thomas. I set down the marker quietly. Okay, then. Staying in my lane it is. He practically glowed with satisfaction. See how easy that is? Everyone just doing their assigned tasks, no overstepping. The very next morning, April from accounting showed up at my desk with her usual panic. Thomas, can you fix this spreadsheet real quick? You always know how to handle these things. I kept typing without looking up. Sorry, that's above my pay grade. Tech support handles that stuff. But you've literally always helped me with this. Donald made it clear yesterday that I need to stay in my lane. Call I T. Her face went through three different expressions before settling on disbelief. That afternoon, Donald himself appeared with his laptop, looking stressed Need you to polish these slides for tomorrow's big presentation. I didn't even glance at the screen. That's design work, Donald. Above my pay grade. His left eye started Twitch. You've been doing my slide since you started here. Which was wrong of me. You were right yesterday. I was overstepping. This presentation is critical. Then you should probably do it yourself. Or hire someone. He stood there for a full minute before storming off. The real fun started when the new guy arrived. Sandra from HR brought him to my desk. Thomas always trains our new people. He's the best at explaining everything. I looked up briefly. Training is a supervisor job. Not in my job description. Sandra looked like I'd spoken in a foreign language. But you've trained the last five people we hired. Which was me working above my pay grade. Donald corrected that behavior on Monday. The kid, it stood there clutching his folder, looking lost. So who's supposed to train me? Someone at the appropriate pay level. Donald materialized within 15 minutes, looking furious. What's this about refusing to train, Kevin? Training isn't in my job description. We don't have anyone else who knows everything. That sounds like a management problem. His face turned red. Thomas, be reasonable. I'm being exactly what you told me to be. Thursday at 4:47 p m. Donald rushed over in full panic mode. Emergency important. Client needs updated numbers for their 5:30 call. I was already packing my bag. My hours are 9 to 5. This can't wait until tomorrow? Overtime requires authorization and higher pay rate. Thomas, don't do this. I'm doing exactly what you instructed. Staying in my lane. I logged off while he stood there speechless. The contract is worth 2 million. Sounds like something management should handle. Friday's department meeting turned into a complete

My sister removed my seven year old daughter's hair, leaving her bald. Now you really look like your loser father. While my nieces were laughing. The next day her account was frozen and the bank for closed on her house. For three years, I've been financially supporting my younger sister Jessica to her divorce. I paid her mortgage, utilities, groceries, everything so she and her daughters wouldn't struggle. Jessica worked at a hair salon, but barely made enough. Over time, I noticed her attitude. She never said thank you, only criticized our life. If we bought a car, she'd say we were showing off. If we took Isabella on vacation, she'd complain that some of us aren't so lucky. Isabella, my daughter, has always been sweet with long, shiny brown hair. Sometimes she'd come home saying Aunt Jessica scolded me or Aunt Jessica said my dress was ugly. Those comments bothered me. Everything changed one Saturday. Isabella was invited to a friend's birthday party and wanted to look like a princess. I decided to take her to Jessica for a special haircut. I called and said, make Isabella look like a princess. I'll leave extra money. Jessica responded dryly, alright, leave her with me, but don't come too late. I dropped Isabella off at Jessica's house. Isabella was happy in her pink dress and sparkling shoes. I kissed her forehead and said I'd be back in a few hours. When I returned at five PM, I heard heartbreaking crying as I approached. I heard Jessica shouting, now you look like your father's failure. Bald and horrible, just like him! Then came laughter, Jessica's laugh and her daughter's giggles. I slammed the door open. Isabella was sitting in a chair with her head lowered. At her feet was a pile of hair, scattered like trash. When she lifted her face, my world collapsed. She was completely bald. Called Jessica had shaved her head, leaving not a single strand. My little princess had red eyes from crying, her face filled with shame. Jessica stood beside her with a razor, laughing. Her daughters were pointing at Isabella, mocking her look. She looks like an egg, Sophia said, laughing. How ugly! Added Lucia. I hugged Isabella tightly. She clung to me, shaking and threw her sobs. Said daddy, why did she do this to me? I just wanted to look pretty. What did you do to my daughter? I roared at Jessica. She stopped laughing, but didn't seem sorry. Calm down, Antonio, it was just a joke. I told her I was giving her a modern cut. She looks unique, she said with a mocking smile. A joke? You shaved my daughter's head! You humiliated her! She shrugged. Don't be dramatic, it's just hair. Plus that girl is always showing off with her long hair. Like my daughters aren't as beautiful. She's a 7 year old girl who wanted to feel pretty. You did this out of envy! Jessica exploded. Don't come at me! With envy crap. You're always showing off your perfect life while I'm struggling alone.

My wife gave me silent treatment for 20 days. So on day 21, I made it permanent. 20 days of silence. That's what my wife decided I deserved after I suggested she help with household responsibilities instead of treating me like her personal butler. But here's the thing about playing the silent treatment card. Sometimes the other person decides they prefer the quiet. I finished a 12 hour shift and walked into what looked like a tornado hit our kitchen. Did. She's piled high. Take out containers scattered everywhere. And her on the couch scrolling through her phone. I made the apparently unforgivable mistake of saying, hey, think you could give me a hand cleaning up before dinner? The look she gave me could frozen hell over. Excuse me? I work, too. I'm not your maid. I never said you were. I thought we could tackle this together since we both live here. That's when she stood up, grabbed her purse, and delivered the line that would define the next three weeks. Figure it out yourself. And don't expect me to talk to you until you learn some respect. Front door slammed so hard it rattled the windows. When she came back two hours later, I thought we'd have a normal conversation. I was wrong. She walked past me like I was invisible and went straight to the bedroom. Day two rolled around and still nothing. I tried the reasonable approach. If I came across wrong yesterday, we should talk. She poured her coffee, walked past me, and left for work without acknowledging I existed. By day 5, I realized what this was. This wasn't about dishes or respect. This was control. She decided freezing me out would make me grovel and apologize for something I shouldn't apologize for. Day 7 was when something clicked. I was eating a sandwich, watching her perform her silent tantrum routine, and I started laughing. Here was a grown woman who thought giving me the cold shoulder was going to break me down. Instead, it was showing me exactly who I'd married. By day 10, the house had gotten remarkably peaceful. No arguing about whose turn it was to take out trash. No passive aggressive comments about the dishwasher. No dramatic sighs when I wanted to watch sports. I was starting to see the upside. Day 15 brought reinforcements. Her sister called asking if everything was okay because my wife seemed stressed. Told her everything was fine. I was giving my wife the space she'd requested. When her sister tried to dig deeper, I said, she knows how to end this anytime she wants an adult conversation. But here's what she didn't realize during her tantrum. I was using this time to think about what my life had become and what I wanted it to be. Day 20 arrived with her pacing around like a caged animal, looking at me with this.

My own mother abandoned me at the airport when I was just 15, all to enjoy a luxurious vacation with her new husband and his kids. You can figure it out. She shrugged. I stood there watching her walk away with her perfect little blended family, dragging their matching designer suitcases toward the gate. She didn't even look back. Not once. I had $23 in my pocket, a dead phone charge charger, and absolutely nowhere to go in this massive airport. That's when I remembered the business card tucked in my wallet. The one with the fancy logo I've been carrying around for three years. My Aunt Sarah's restaurant card. The sister my mom had been bad mouthing my entire life, calling her a jealous failure. Sarah's a pathetic loser, mom always said. She's jealous of our success and stability. Buddy, don't believe anything she tells you about our family. But standing there alone in JFK Terminal 4, watching families rush past me with their vacation excitement, I figured I had nothing left to lose. I found a payphone. Yes still exist in airports. And dialed the number with shaking fingers. It rang twice before a warm, professional voice answered. Bella Vista restaurant. This is Sarah speaking. Aunt Sarah, it's Maya. I'm. I'm in really big trouble right now. The silence lasted forever. Then, in a completely different tone. Baby girl? Maya, where are you? Are you safe? What happened? I started crying. Right there in the middle of the Busy terminal. Mom left me at the airport. She took her new husband and his kids on vacation to Hawaii and just abandoned me here. What terminal are you at? I'm coming to get you right now. You don't understand. I'm at JFK in New York. You're all the way in Chicago. I can't ask you to. Maya, Honey, listen to me carefully. I have three successful restaurants now. I'm not the broke failure your mother told you I was. Exactly where you are. I'm getting on the next available flight. Four hours later, I watched a confident woman in designer jeans and a cashmere coat rush through the arrivals gate, scanning the crowd frantically. She looked exactly like mom, but her eyes were kind instead of cold. When she spotted me, she started running. I've been waiting 10 years for the phone call, she whispered, hugging me so tight I could barely breathe. I've tried reaching you so many times, but your mother blocked every single attempt. To ride to her luxury hotel suite was completely surreal. Sarah explained everything while ordering room service. How she built a successful restaurant empire from nothing. How she been sending birthday cards and Christmas gifts that mom apparently threw away unopened. How she'd even hired a family lawyer once to try for visitation rights. Your mother told everyone in our family

My wife asked me to leave our home. I didn't argue. I just closed our joint accounts and changed the locks instead. Last Tuesday, I received divorce papers from my wife, Natalia, after four years of marriage. But she didn't deliver them herself. Her new boyfriend, Gabriel, showed up at my doorstep with the envelope. Natalia wants you out by Friday, he told me with arrogant, confident. Find somewhere else to stay. I looked at this guy, who'd clearly been sleeping with my wife, and simply replied, okay. He probably expected me to break down or punch him. Instead, I closed the door and started making calls. First to my lawyer, then to the bank. What? Gabriel and Natalia didn't know the house was solely in my name. I bought it before we married with inheritance money and never added her to the title. Gabriel had been living there for a month while I was away for work. Natalia claimed he was an acquaintance going through tough time. Complete lie. When he demanded I find somewhere else to stay. He was trying to kick me out of my own house. By Wednesday morning, I changed all the locks. That afternoon, I canceled Gabriel's access to everything. Netflix, Spotify, Amazon Prime. He'd even added himself to my 90 Dollar Family Gym membership. Canceled that too. Thursday night, Gabriel appeared, banging on the door. What the hell is going on? Why did you change the locks? Cause this is my house. I Replied from inside, Natalia can get her things, but you have to leave. She's my partner. Now we're together. Perfect. Go be together somewhere else. His tantrum was epic, screaming that I was vengeful that he had rights. Meanwhile, I recorded everything. I texted Natalia, you have 48 hours to collect your belonging. Gabriel is not welcome here. Her response you can't do this. Gabriel lives here now. Check the property title. He's nowhere on it. The next morning, Gabriel's lawyer showed up, claiming Gabriel had tendency rights because as he'd lived there over 30 days. I showed him the recording of Gabriel screaming that he was there as my wife's partner, not a tenant. There's no lease, no rent payments, no contributions, I explained, showing the property title with me as sole owner. The lawyer went pale and left quickly.

When did your wife realize you weren't just an unemployed? Twitch chatter. Sarah came home from her 12 hour hospital shift to find me in the same spot at my computer. Twitch stream on one monitor, spreadsheets minimized on the other. She dropped her bag with that familiar exhausted sound. Mike, eight months. You've been unemployed for eight months watching gamers play Fortnite? My mom keeps asking if you're depressed. I quickly switched tabs as she approached. Just keeping myself busy. Busy? You're watching someone build a virtual house. She saw my chat messages and actively participating. This isn't a hobby anymore. It's an addiction. What she didn't see were the other tabs supplier emails from China, Shipping trackers, customer service responses. The Twitch streams were just background noise while I managed orders, adjusted Facebook ad campaigns, and negotiated with suppliers about delayed shipments. My sister's husband just bought a rental property, Sarah continued. Meanwhile, I'm telling people you're between opportunities. Truth was, my dropshipping business was finally profitable after 6 months of testing products. Gaming accessories of all things. Mouse pads with LED edges, custom keyboard caps, able management systems. Stuff I found by watching what streamers complained about. Can you at least come to dinner tomorrow? Pretend you're trying. Her family dinner was torture. Her brother described his new BMW. Her father offered me a pity job at his hardware store. Again, Sarah deflected questions about our future, saying we were figuring things out. Maybe he could drive For Uber, her mother suggested. Loud enough for me to hear. Everything unraveled because the doorbell camera notification. Sarah was showing her sister our ring footage to prove our neighbor's dog kept getting in our yard. She scrolled too far back and saw something odd. Delivery drivers. Dozens of them. Every single day. Mike, why are so many packages coming to our house? Her sister leaned in. Are you shopping addicts? Is that why you're broke? Their returns, I said quickly. But Sarah kept scrolling. The packages were being picked up, not dropped off. Different drivers collecting them. What the hell is this? I couldn't hide it anymore. Opened my laptop and showed her the Shopify dashboard. 300 orders this month. Inventory spreadsheet showing zero stock because everything shipped directly from suppliers to customers. You're selling things? Gaming accessories. Mouse pads, mostly. She stared at the revenue numbers. Last month was my best yet. Enough to cover our mortgage twice. But you don't have any products here. They ship from the supplier. I handle marketing and customer service. I showed her the Facebook ads running in the background, the email campaigns, the abandoned cart sequences. This. This is real money. I opened the business checking account. Six months of deposits from Shopify. Not fortune, but solid middle class income from selling LED mouse pads to gamers. Why didn't you tell me? Remember when I tried explaining dropshipping? You said it was a pyramid scheme for people who watch too many YouTube gurus because you explained it while watching someone play Minecraft at 2:00am, her sister was reading over her shoulder. Wait, he's been running a business this whole time? Sarah scrolled through customer emails, reviews, the business registration, tax documents, everything legit, just invisible. I've been telling everyone you're unemployed. I cried to my therapist about supporting you. I know my dad offered you minimum wage out of pity. I make more than his offer in three days selling mouse pads. Her phone started buzzing, family group chat exploding as her sister shared the news. Her dad asking how online selling actually worked. Her mom confused about what dropshipping meant. Why all the secrecy, though? It wasn't supposed to be secret. But every time I tried explaining, you'd see me on the computer and assume I was wasting time. Eventually, I stopped trying.

My best friend told me I was too clingy and needed to get my own life, so I did exactly that. Penny cornered me at lunch Monday, Monica and Christina flanking her like bodyguards. Jenna, this is an intervention, she announced. Monica snorted. You text me literally every five minutes. You waited outside my math class yesterday, even though yours is across campus. You got weird when I went to Monica's sleepover without you. She crossed her arms. It's honestly embarrassing. Monica's best friend has her own life, her own friends. They're independent. You're, like, obsessed with me or something. Christina laughed. No offense, but it's giving desperate. Penny shrugged. You need to get your own life and stop making me her entire personality. I felt my face burn, but looking at Penny's expression, I realized she was serious. Had I really been that bad? After my parents divorced, penny was my rock. Maybe I'd held on too tight. Maybe I depended on her too much emotionally. I'm sorry, I said quietly. I didn't realize I was making you uncomfortable. Starting Tuesday, I gave her exactly what she asked for. No morning texts. Said they were too much. I saw her in the hallway and just smiled instead of running over. She wanted space. At lunch, I accepted the Art Girls invitation to sit with them. They've been asking for weeks, and I'd always said no to stay with penny. They were genuinely excited to have me. Finally, Lorelai said, We've been wanting to be friends forever. But you were always with penny. They were so welcoming, teaching me their inside jokes, including me in their group chat. Thursday morning hurt the most. We bought tickets together weeks ago for the school's talent show. Front row seats to support our friends band. I sat there alone, saving her seat with my backpack until the lights dimmed. She never came. During intermission, I saw her Instagram story. She was at Starbucks with Monica and Christina, laughing over Frappuccinos. The caption read, so much better than boring school events. My eyes burned with tears. I wouldn't let fall. She'd known and didn't show up. And worse, she seemed happier without me. I deleted the text I'd started typing, asking where she was. She wanted space, and clearly she was thriving with it. After the show, I joined the drama club, something penny had always made fun of. When Romeo from drama asked if I wanted to practice lines after school, I said yes. Immediately. I posted a selfie with him captioned new drama partner with heart emojis. Penny viewed it in 10 seconds, but didn't like it. Lorelai invited me to a party Friday. Penny will be there, too, she mentioned. At the party, I stayed with my new friends, but kept checking on penny discreetly. She was with Monica and Christina by the pool. When Monica loudly said, at least you finally got rid of your stalker. I pretend ended not To hear penny laughed along with them, that stung. But if that's how she felt, I'd respect it. Everything crashed down Tuesday. I was heading to art club when I heard someone crying in the bathroom. Harsh, painful sobs. My heart knew it was penny before my brain did. Soph, are you okay? I asked softly through the door. Leave me alone, Jenna. I don't want to guilt you into caring about my problems. What? Penny, please let me in. The door unlocked. I look destroyed. Mascara streaking, eyes swollen. My parents are getting divorced, she whispered. Dad's been cheating for months. I found out Sunday night. My heart broke. I pulled her into my arms, feeling her whole body shake. She told me through gasps how she'd wanted to call me Sunday night when her dad moved out, but Monica had convinced her not to be a hypocrite. How she'd seen my Instagram.

What's the most ridiculous rule your parents made that completely backfired? Last summer, my parents decided we needed a technology free family bonding road trip to Yellowstone. They announced this planet dinner looking way too proud of themselves. No phones, no tablets, no Nintendo Switch, dad declared. We're going to reconnect as a family and appreciate nature. My 16 year old sister Denki and I just stared at them in horror. A week long road trip with no electronics? They might as well have suggested we travel by covered wagon. But what if there's an emergency? Denki asked, already plotting. We'll have our phones for emergencies only, mom said. But they'll be locked in the glove compartment. The night before we left, Denki and I held an emergency sibling meeting. We were not going down without a fight. Operation Digital Rebellion is a go! She whispered, pulling out a duffel bag full of contraband electronics. We spent hours hiding devices throughout our luggage. Denki sown a secret pocket into her pillow for her phone. I hollered out a thick book and stuffed my Nintendo Switch inside. We even hit a portable charger inside a bag of trail mix. Day one started with Dad's enthusiastic announcement. Isn't this great, kids? Look at all this beautiful scenery. Let's play the license plate game. Wow, dad, A Nebraska plate! Riveting. Denki deadpanned while secretly texting her boyfriend through her pillow. By hour three, mom was getting suspicious because we were being unusually cooperative. About her car games. Little did she know, I was playing Pokemon under a blanket while pretending to nap. You kids seem awfully quiet back there, she said, turning around. Just enjoying the family bonding, mom, I said, quickly shoving my switch under my fake book. Denki had gotten creative with her rebellion. She downloaded audiobooks and was listening through earbuds she threaded through her hoodie strings. Every time mom asked her a question, she pretend to be deep in thought about nature. By day two, we'd established an elaborate system. Denki would be the lookout while I game, then we'd switch. We communicated through coughs and sneezes. That meant parents incoming or coast is clear. The funniest part was when dad stopped at this scenic overlook and insisted we all take a family photo. While he was setting up his camera, Denki was frantically trying to finish a level on her hidden phone game. Denki, Smile! Dad called out, just a second. I'm appreciating the natural beauty, she said, thumbs flying across her screen. Our rebellion reached peak chaos on day three when we discovered the hotel had terrible Wi-Fi. Denki had a complete meltdown because she couldn't upload her secret vacation selfies to Instagram. The bathroom has better no! She whispered to me during dinner. So there we were, taking turns hiding in the hotel bathroom, desperately trying to get one bar of service while our parents thought we had digestive issues from the road trip snacks. You Kids have been spending a lot of time in the bathroom, mom observed suspiciously. Must be all that healthy trail mix you packed, I said innocently, while Denki was literally sitting on the bathroom floor trying to connect to Wi-Fi. Day 4 brought disaster. Dad decided to surprise us with a spontaneous hike and grabbed our backpacks to carry water bottles. That's when he discovered Denki's secret phone charging station she'd set up using the car's USB port. What is this?
NA
NA

Brother got me kicked out. Now my, he wants my house. When I was 16, my gaming obsessed brother Tyler convinced my parents I was taking up too much space in our cramped three bedroom apartment. He'd been complaining for months that he needed my room for his elaborate gaming setup. My parents sat me down one evening and basically said I had two weeks to find alternative living arrangements. The reasoning, I was almost 17, practically an adult and Tyler needed space to pursue his passion in gaming and they genuinely believed he was going to become the next big twitch star. I was devastated but had nowhere to go. My girlfriend Emma's parents noticed I'd been spending more time at their house and eventually asked what was going on. When I explained the situation, her mom immediately said I could stay stay with them as long as I needed, no questions asked. Emma and I got serious fast. Living under the same roof will do that to a relationship. When we turned 19, I proposed with a ring. I'd saved six months for working overtime every weekend. Parents were thrilled. They basically raised me for two years anyway and considered me their son. At 23, we finally had enough saved for a down payment on a small two bedroom house, nothing fancy. We spent every weekend renovating, learning YouTube tutorials, making mistakes and fixing them. Meanwhile, Tyler was still living with my parents in his gaming paradise. He Dropped out of community college after one semester, claiming his streaming career was about to take off. College was just holding him back. Three years later, he was still grinding away at maybe five viewers on a good day, sleeping until two PM, gaming until 4:00am, ordering Doordash with my parents money. My parents occasionally texted generic holiday messages or shared Facebook posts about family, but otherwise, we had zero relationship. Last month, my mom showed up at my house completely unannounced. I hadn't seen her.

Have you ever had to block someone all because your parents said so? My parents were so worried about me dating a skater boy, they couldn't imagine he'd be the reason I'm still alive today. A few nights ago, my parents found out about my skater boyfriend, reggis, when his message popped up on my screen at dinner. I love you, too. Who the heck are you talking to? My mom shouted, glaring at the screen of my phone. You're 14. No dating until you're 30. We were very clear. Dad pulled up Reggis's Instagram on his own phone. Escape border? Really? This is who you're risking your future for? I tried to reason with them, but they refused to listen and forced me to block him everywhere, right there, over dinner. You'll thank us when you're in college, mom said while I sobbed. My friends tried passing messages between us at school, but my parents found out and threatened to call their parents. Eventually, everyone gave up, except for Greggus. Greggus showed up mysteriously in my valorant lobby. Hey, Mel. It's been a while, he said, his voice breaking. I miss you, Mel. I know we're not supposed to talk, but let's at least play like we used to. We started meeting in the lobbies every day after that, just playing and chatting about normal things. School friends, my strict parents. He never once tried to convince me to sneak around or meet up in person. He never complained. About my parents or tried to turn me against them. When I vent about how unfair they were being, he'd actually defend them. Sometimes they're just scared, Once my older sister got mixed up with some bad people in high school. Parents get paranoid. He still cared about me in all the ways that mattered. When I failed my chemistry test because I couldn't focus, he spent three hours teaching me balancing equations over discord. When my grandmother got sick, he stayed up until 3:00am just listening to me cry. You can always reach me here, he promised. I don't care what time it is. Mom almost got us once when she walked by while discord was open. I clicked to my game lobby just in time. Homework break? She asked. I nodded and switched back to my essay, my heart pounding so hard I thought she'd hear it after she left Greg's message. Maybe we should stop. I don't want to get you in trouble, but I couldn't lose him again. He was the only person who I could rely on. And thank god I didn't lose him, because a couple of days later, my friend Sarah and I got caught up in some shady business. It was supposed to be a normal Saturday night sleepover. Her parents went out for their anniversary, leaving us to watch movies and eat junk food. I was on the phone messaging Gregus on discord when Sarah's older brother Joshua came. Home from college, completely wasted with two other friends, Sarah immediately tensed up. baby sis and baby girl. He winked disgustingly. He and his friends sat beside us on the sofa, placing his arm over my shoulder, constantly whispering things like, I know you're not as innocent as you act, and your parents don't have to know. I pushed his face away and stood up, glaring. Can you stop? Sarah was almost crying, begging me not to make him mad. He gets mean when he's drunk. She was, just ignore him and he'll pass out soon. But when Joshua grabbed my waist and tried to pull me onto his lap, I grabbed Sarah's arm and ran to the bathroom. Quickly locking the door, he started pounding on it, laughing with his friends about how I was playing hard to get and needed to loosen up. Sarah hopped into the tub, hugging her knees to her chest. I patted my pockets, realizing I had left my phone in the living room. Soon the knocks on the door became angrier. Hitting the door harder, jiggling the handle aggressively, Sarah meekly handed me her phone.

Roommate trashed my car because I wouldn't write his essays, so I made sure he never graduated. Brian thought college was a four year party with a diploma handed out at the end. I was just a nerdy roommate who'd somehow help him pass his classes. We weren't paired by choice. Housing lottery put us together freshman year. The football player and the scholarship kid. From day one, he made it clear what he thought of me. Seriously? You're studying on a Friday night? He'd laugh. This is college, man. You're supposed to be making memories. His memories involved coming back at 3:00am, stumbling into my desk, and. And occasionally vomiting near my backpack. Things shifted in October when he realized he was failing economics. The coach had warned him, maintain a 2.5 GPA or get benched. Hey, you're good at this stuff, right? He dropped his textbook on my keyboard. I need help. I agreed to tutor him, explain supply and demand curves created practice problems. He nodded along, then asked, so can you just write my paper for me? I've got a game this weekend. I refused, offered to review his draft instead. He laughed like I. I told a joke. Come on, nobody will know. I'll pay you. I can't do that, I said. It's academic dishonesty. We could both get expelled. His smile faded. Whatever, man. Thought you were cool. After that, our fragile roommate peace collapsed. He'd invite friends over when I had exams. Accidentally Spill drinks on my notes, hide my alarm clock. Before important classes, I started spending more time at the library, coming back only to sleep. I was working two part time jobs alongside a full course load. Midterms came. Brian failed economic specta. Got benched for two games. One morning, I woke up to find him staring at me, eyes bloodshot. You could have helped me, he said. Now coach says I might lose my scholarship. I tried to help. I replied, you wanted me to do it for you. Then came the real breaking point. I saved for two years to buy my first car. A used Honda with 120,000 miles. Nothing fancy, but it meant I could live off campus next year. The morning after Brian received his final warning from the athletics department, I found my car with all four tires slashed. Loser scratched into the door. Windshield crack. Campus security said they couldn't.

The dumbest prank you ever pulled that spiraled out of control. My older sister is super jumpy. Like she gets scared if the toast pops up too loud. So when I found out she'd been watching creepy sleepwalking videos all week, I saw my golden opportunity. One night I stayed up late and waited until I knew she was asleep. Then I slowly opened her bedroom door, walked in barefoot with my eyes half closed and started mumbling random garbage like the bees are listening. They can smell light. She's screamed full panic. I pretended to snap out of it like I didn't know what was going on. And the next morning I told her I had no memory of it. That's what really got her. She was convinced I was actually sleepwalking. So I did it again the next night. This time I stood at the end of her bed holding a spoon and just went spread, I am the serial. I was holding myself from bursting out laughing. After that, she started locking her door. So I got creative. I'd rattle the doorknob or just whisper her name through the air vent until she freaked out. I kept telling her I didn't remember any of it. My acting was elite. She even started filming me to prove it was real. But I would just delete the videos when she wasn't looking. It became this little war. Honestly, it was the most fun I'd had in weeks. I never Meant to actually scare her, just mess with her a little. But then one night she ran into my room looking pale and said, I need to show you something right now. I followed her down the hall thinking it was just another one of her overreactions. she opened her phone and pulled up a video from the night before. The footage showed her room in the dark and a figure slowly pushing the door open. Me or someone that looked like me. I watched the figure step into her room, stand completely still for a full minute, then start whispering. But it wasn't gibberish this time. It was my name. Over and over, whispered slowly, almost like then it tilted its head and said, I know you're awake. That's when the video cut out. I tried to laugh it off and said, okay, I admit it, that one was actually kind of good. But she didn't laugh. She looked at me and said, that wasn't from last night. That was from the night you slept over at Sam's house. My stomach dropped. I'd spent that night two neighborhoods over crashing on my friend's couch. I pulled out my own phone to double check the text. There it was, a message from me at 11:08 saying, crashing here tonight. Tell mom that video was recorded at 203:00am. I stared at the screen and tried to find some logical explanation. Maybe someone was messing with us. Maybe she faked The whole thing. But then she said, I didn't want to tell you, but a few nights ago I saw you standing in the hallway. I called your name and you didn't answer. You just walked into the bathroom and never came out. When I checked a minute later, the light was off and the room was empty. That was the part I couldn't explain because I remembered.

You talk to your parents anymore? My parents discovered I wasn't their biological child when I was 16, not through some dramatic DNA test, through my little sister's science project. She was doing genetics homework, mapping out eye colours and couldn't make our family tree work. Brown eyes plus brown eyes can't make blue eyes, she, he said, pointing at me. Mom went white. Dad started stuttering about recessive genes. That night I heard them screaming through the walls. Mom admitted she had an affair 17 years ago. Dad wasn't my father. The man who raised me, taught me to ride a bike, helped with homework for 16 years, suddenly looked at me like I was a stranger. The change was immediate and brutal. Dad stopped coming to my baseball games. When I try talking to him, he'd respond with one word answers or just leave the room. Mom kept insisting nothing had changed, but he'd flinch whenever dad was cold to me. Then came the comparisons. Every family dinner became a catalog of how my sister and I were different. Look how naturally athletic Sophie is, dad would say, watching her throw a ball. She gets that from me. The implication hung in the air like poison. They started treating me like a house guest. My curfew got earlier while my sister stayed the same. My allowance got cut because money is tight. But Sophie got new clothes whenever she asked. When I brought it up, mom said, I Was being dramatic. The worst part was watching them rewrite history. Photos of me got moved to the back of albums. My baby pictures disappeared from the mantle. Dad started telling stories about Sophie's milestones while pretending mine never happened. It was like they were erasing 16 years. My breaking point came during Christmas. Extended family was over and Uncle Mike asked about my college plans. Dad said, well, he's not really academic like Sophie. Different genetics, you know, he said genetics like it was a dirty word. That's when it clicked. Didn't just learn I wasn't blood related. They decided I wasn't family. So I made a choice that destroyed them. I found my biological father. His name was John Sins. He lived three states away, had no idea I existed. When I called him, he cried, actually cried. Said he'd wondered about my mom for years, hoped she was happy. Two weeks later, John drove 400 miles to meet me. He brought photo albums of his family, told me about my half brother who played baseball like me, showed me pictures of my real grandmother who had died the year before. But here's what broke my parents. John didn't just accept me, he celebrated me. Within a month, he'd driven back twice more. He came to my games, met my friends, me car shopping for my 17th birthday. My parents watched this man give me everything they taken away. Dad became obsessed, calling John a stranger, trying to Steal his son. Mom begged me to stop seeing him, said it was destroying our family. I told them they'd already destroyed it. The night they decided biology mattered more than 16 years of love. The final blow came at graduation. Both my family showed up. John sat in the front road.

I announced that my dad's not paying my college tuition. my dad has always been the super cheap guy who acts like he's loaded but penny pinches everything. Like we're talking about a man who buys generic cereal and then pours it into name brand boxes so the neighbors think we eat the good stuff. He drives a BMW that's literally held together with duct tape and prayers. He parks it at the front of the driveway so everyone can see it anyway. I'm a senior in high school and college application season is here. All my friends are talking about where they're applying and their parents are stressing about tuition costs. Meanwhile, my dad keeps making these weird comments about how I better figure out my future because money doesn't grow on trees. But he never actually said he wouldn't pay for college, so I just assumed he would. Big mistake. I applied to my dream school and got accepted with a partial scholarship. I was so pumped and ran downstairs to tell my parents. My mom was excited and started crying happy tears, but my dad just looked at me and said, that's nice, honey. Hope you can afford it. I was confused and asked what he meant. He shrugged and said college was my responsibility now that I was becoming an don't. I felt my stomach drop. This man had literally never told me I'd be paying for college myself. We'd never had that conversation. I Was so angry and hurt that I decided to be petty about it. If you wanted to embarrass me, I'd return the favor. The next week was my 18th birthday party at our house. All my relatives were there, plus some family friends and neighbors. My dad loves showing off in front of people, so he was in his element, talking about his successful business and giving everyone financial advice. That's when I struck. During the cake cutting, I stood up and tapped my fork against my glass like I was making a toast. Everyone got quiet and looked at me. I smiled real big and said, thanks, everyone, for coming to celebrate with me. I just wanted to share some exciting news about my future. My dad looked proud, probably thinking I was about to thank him or something. I got into my dream college with a scholarship, which is amazing, because my dad just told me he's not helping pay for my education at all.
