Have you ever became a restaurant regular and didn't even realise it? So I'm going through this absolutely soul crushing breakup with my boyfriend of three years. You know, the kind where you can't eat, can't sleep, and your friends are tired of hearing about it. I start going to this 24 hour diner at like 2:00am because I literally cannot sleep. It's one of those old school places with cracked vinyl booths and fluorescent lights that make everyone look dead. First night, I order coffee and pancakes and just sit there scrolling through my ex's Instagram like the masochist I am. The waitress, this woman in her 50s with kind eyes, just keeps refilling my coffee without saying anything. Second night, same thing. Third night, she finally asks, rough patch, honey? I nod and try not to cry into my syrup. By the end of week two, I'm there every single night at exactly 2:00am. Same booth, same order, same pathetic scrolling routine. That's when she sits down across from me. Alright, sweetie, you've been here 14 nights straight crying into pancakes. What's his name? And I just break. I tell her everything. How he cheated, how he moved in with her immediately, how all our mutual friends picked. She listens to every word while bringing me free pie. The next night, she introduces me to the cook. Hank, this is Pancake Girl. She's having serious boy troubles. Hank, this massive guy with tattoo sleeves, looks at me and Goes. What kind of idiot breaks a heart like that? Then he makes me these incredible chocolate chip pancakes shaped like a heart. Soon, the whole night shift knows my business. There's Madison, the other waitress, who gives me brutal but honest dating advice. Cameron, the dishwasher, who barely speaks English, but always pats my shoulder and says, no cry, Mija. Even the manager, Frederick, starts checking on me. They give me a nickname, pan.

Dads, what's the craziest bet you've ever made with your son? My teenage son kept bragging about how he could outeat anyone. Every dinner came with the same speech about his legendary stomach. What Logan didn't know was that I grew up with four brothers in a house where food disappeared faster than Halloween candy. His boasting amused me until his 16th birthday party. I'd spent all morning grilling burgers for his friends when I overheard him telling everyone, my dad thinks he's some grill master, but wait till you see me crush these burgers. His friends laughed. I didn't. After the party, while cleaning up, I casually mentioned the local diner's burger challenge. Finish their 5 pound monster in 30 minutes. It free. Plus your photo on the wall. I could destroy that challenge, Logan said without looking up from his phone. Twenty bucks says you can't. He finally looked up. Only 20? Weak, dad. Fine. If you win, I'll let you take my vintage Mustang to prom. The car was my pride and joy, a 1967 fastback that I'd restored myself over five long years. Same car I proposed to his mother in. Logan nearly dropped his phone. For real. You never let anyone drive it. And if you lose, I continued, you have to come to work with me every Saturday this summer. No video games, no sleeping in. Just learning what real work looks like. I own a construction company. Logan had been avoiding real labor. Like it was homework. His mother thought I was being too hard on him, but I knew he needed to learn some grit. Deal, he said instantly, sticking out his hand. We shook on it, and I saw a flicker of doubt in his eyes, but it vanished just as quickly. That Friday, we walked into Geek Big Joe's Smokehouse. The place was packed with the usual crowd of truckers and locals. Conversations hushed when we approached the counter. The burger challenge was legendary in our small town. The

My dad's been watching the same VHS tape every night for the past 12 years. I just found out the horrifying reason. Ever since I was 9 years old, my dad would go into the living room at exactly 11:05 p m. Every single night and put a tape in his old Panasonic. He wouldn't talk, blink, or even eat dinner until the tape was finished. But to make things even more strange, he would always tell me to never watch the tape or to disturb him while he was watching it. I used to think it was something inappropriate, like cornhub. So one night when everyone was sleeping, I snuck into the living room to check the tape and found that it wasn't anything. All the footage showed was some random static for a full hour. I decided to just head back to sleep and didn't think much of it. And for the next 12 years, he never missed a single night. Not on holidays, not when he was sick, and not even when he broke both of his ribs. Every night he would go on the couch and watch the tape like his life depended on it. And I'm starting to think it did because of what happened last night. I was just playing with my meat while my mom was making dinner when we heard my dad yelling for help in the shower. We immediately rushed over to him and took him to the ER. But the Whole ride there. He kept pointing at his watch, which read 10:30. I assumed he was just worried about missing his little tape and just told him that it was okay to miss one day. But after 15 minutes in the ER, the doctors told us that he needed to stay overnight for some blood work. So we told the doctor that we'd come tomorrow and went back home. By the time we arrived back home, it was already 11:15. So I told my mom good night, and she went upstairs into her bedroom. But right as I was getting into mine, I saw the tape sitting right next to the TV. It was already half ejected into the Panasonic. So I went over to take it out when I heard some scraping in the hallway. It sounded like nails were dragging across the car. And when I looked around to see what it was, nothing was there. I thought I was just hearing thing. But the second I turned back around to take the tape out, the TV turned on by itself. But this time, the video wasn't static. It showed a creature walking through a long hallway. What made it even more creepy was the fact that the house layout looked identical to mine. I just stared at the screen, praying that this creature was gonna vanish.

Former homeless people. What's the darkest thing you've ever seen? During that time, I was extremely skinny and constantly hungry. I had finally saved up enough change to buy myself a sit down meal at this small diner on the corner, something I hadn't done in months. The smell alone was overwhelming, like fresh toast and eggs. And warm. I walked in and barely made it three steps before the owner came storming over. He didn't even ask what I wanted. He just told me to leave. Said he didn't want me scaring the other customers off or making anyone uncomfortable. His voice was loud enough that everyone turned to look at me. Some of them even nodded along with him. I didn't argue. I was used to this. So I went back outside and sat down on the curb, trying not to let it get to me. About 10 minutes later, this very well dressed woman walked by with a small group of people. He was wearing this expensive coat and heels that probably cost more than I'd made in a year. As they passed, she stopped and handed me a folded hundred dollar Bill. I couldn't believe it. For a second. I thought it was fake, but it was real. I looked up at her, stunned, and the people she was with praised her for being so kind. I thanked her about a dozen times and she smiled and told me to stay safe as they walked off. I felt something I hadn't felt in a long time. Hope. That money meant I could get a motel room for a couple night, maybe even a hot shower and a proper bed. But about 30 minutes later, she came back alone. She stormed up to me, all that warmth gone from her face. She held out her hand and demanded the money back. Said she needed it, that she hadn't meant to give me that much. Tried to reason with her, but she didn't want to hear it. She kept saying I had no right to her generosity, that I should be grateful. She even looked at me. I hesitated, but I handed the Bill back. Then she kicked over my cup of coins, scattering everything I had on the sidewalk. I asked her why she was doing this, why she was being so cruel. She looked down at me with disgust and said people like me were what's wrong with the country. That she only gave me the money to look good in front of her clients.

Poor people who have dated rich people. What did you learn? I dated a billionaire's daughter, and her dad taught me the most important lesson about money. When I first met Sarah's family, I was just a mechanic working at a local garage. Her dad owned hotels across the world, and their house looked like something from a movie. At family dinners, everyone talked about their private jet gets a million dollar watches, while I sat there in my twenty dollar target shirt, feeling like an alien who'd crash their party. I started making excuses to skip family events, but Sarah insisted I come to her dad's birthday dinner. That night, her dad invited me to his office. I thought this was it. He was going to offer me money to leave his daughter alone. Instead, he asked about my work. I started talking about fixing cars, expecting him to be bored, but his eyes lit up. Turned out, before his success, he'd worked as a mechanic too. For the next two hours, we talked about engines and restoration projects. As I was leaving, he said something I'll never forget. You know why I like you? Everyone in this house asks me about my money. You're the only one who talks to me like I'm just another guy who loves cars. A month later, he helped me open my own auto shop. Not because I asked, because we share the same passion. Now I run the most successful luxury car Restoration business in the state. And every Saturday my billionaire father in law comes by in old jeans to help me work on classic cars. Sometimes the richest people are the ones who never make you feel poor.

People who worked for multi millionaires. What crazy things have you seen? I work as a maid for one of the wealthiest families in America, and they raised their kids like I've never seen before. I was taken aback by this question because I came prepared with potential responses that would explain why I desperately needed this job. But I didn't know how to answer it, so I was just honest and responded with myself. He hired me on the spot, and I started the next day. My major tasks for the day were to deep clean the washroom, prepare lunch and dinner, then pick up his son and daughter from high school and cook them dinner. I got my groceries, deep cleaned everything, started food prep, and waited for the kids at the school. This was when I noticed something was off. They're enrolled in public school. I met the children again after briefly meeting them in the morning and asked what extracurricular activities they needed me to drop them off to. I know for a fact that wealthy families always enroll their kids in spin classes, music lessons, and foreign language classes. I'd probably be tracked down if I revealed how much money goes into those classes. These parents usually make sure their kids receive an education. You Definitely can't afford. You can imagine my surprise when the wealthiest 16 year olds in America told me, we don't have any extracurriculars. We study at home. After eating dinner, they disappeared into their rooms and stayed there the whole day. Before I left, I asked their father why he didn't enroll his kids in any extracurricular classes. In his fashion, all he told me was, the school system sucks. Yeah, no, I wasn't buying it. Sure, the school system sucks, but he wouldn't send his kids there if it meant they were set up for failure. My daughter weaponized custody court against me for years, so I let her win everything she wished for. My daughter Kelsey, Learned early that crying got her whatever she wanted. When she was 12, she sobbed to her teacher that I wouldn't let her have a phone, and suddenly I was a mean dad. At 13, she cried to her mom about my strict bedtime rules and got to stay at her house more. By 14, she was crying to judges about fake bruises. The phone incident happened first. When Kelsey turned 12, she wanted the latest model, but I told her to bring her grades up first. The next day, she sobbed to her teacher that I was isolating her from friends. The counselor called me in and lectured me about teenage social development. I left that meeting, forced to buy her a phone immediately. A year later, the bedtime battle started getting serious. I set lights out at 10 on school nights. Kelsey called her mom crying that I was treating her like a baby. Her mom, who only cared about child support checks, filed for modified custody. The next week, she stood in court talking about her daughter suffering under my control. She never mentioned Kelsey's grandma Mother's Education Trust fund waiting for her. The judge increased her time from weekends to half the week. Then came the bruises, when everything changed forever. Kelsey showed up to court with marks on her arms. At 14, she claimed I grabbed her during an argument about failing grades. I watched her cry and peek at the judge through her fingers. Her mother held her close and glared at me with disgust. The judge ordered supervised visits that same day. Three years passed before Kelsey made her final move. She decided at 17 that she wanted to drop out of school completely. I told her education wasn't optional in our family. Two days later, police arrested me at work. She had filed a report claiming years of psychological torture and food withholding. She said I stole from her grandmother's education trust fund. Then she told the detective, he gets weird when he drinks. He comes into my room at night and sits on my bed. I haven't touched alcohol since my brother died from liver failure. I sat in that jail cell and realized she would never stop escalating. The system believed her tears every single time. Something cold settled in my chest. I stopped feeling hurt and started thinking clearly. If she wanted freedom from me, she would get it. The charges were dropped for lack of evidence after three days. I hired a new lawyer.

When did you use someone's exact words from 20 years ago to destroy them? I became a parent at 7 years old, the day I realized my sister Eve would starve if I didn't learn to cook. Our parents worked 18 hour days and treated the office like their real home, while I Learned to pack Eve's lunch in the specific blue container she needed and her sandwiches into perfect triangles. By 9, I could forge their signatures perfectly and knew exactly how to calm her meltdowns. By 16, I scheduled her doctor visits and set alarms to give her medicine on time. Eve would fall asleep by the front door waiting for them to come home, rocking with her weighted blanket. And I'd carry her to bed at midnight, whispering that I'd always be there, even if they weren't. So when Stanford accepted me, I stared at the letter, knowing I couldn't leave her alone for two more years of high school. She caught me crying and grabbed my shoulders. You have to go. I don't like when you're sad, she said, rocking slightly. Parents suddenly appeared when they heard Stanford's name, actually proud for once and lecturing me about opportunities I couldn't pass up. But I told them I couldn't leave Eve alone, not when she needed someone who understood her routines and could advocate for her at school. For the first time in years, they actually look at me, and I watched something break in Mom's face. Oh, god, she whispered. You've been doing our job since second grade. All this time working to afford the best life for you two, and we haven't even been here to live it with you. Dad couldn't look at me when he finally spoke. Starting tomorrow, being here comes first. And for three beautiful months, they became the best parents. Dad Learned Eve's morning routine, mom attended parent teacher conferences, and they both showed up to her sophomore year orientation. Eve called me at Stanford listing every dinner detail they used. The smooth plates. Dad didn't mix her foods. Mom turned the TV volume to 16, not 17. They and photos of themselves at her art showcase. And Eve's smile in those pictures made the homesickness worth it. She even called one night. Very serious. I have a boyfriend, mom, and dad like him. He helps me at school. I felt grateful hearing her sound happy about normal teenage things. But when I came home two years later for her graduation, I realized she was living anything but a normal.

Poor people who have dated rich people. What did you learn? My girlfriend Paula thought $30 was a lot for dinner until she started dating me. When I took her to Ruth's Chris Steakhouse for our third date, she panicked looking at the menu prices and whispered that maybe we should go somewhere cheaper. I grew up with wealth, but Paula grew up sharing a two bedroom apartment with her mom and three siblings. She worked two jobs through high school just to help with bills. The first time I picked her up in my B M W, she joked that my car cost more than her entire childhood home. Early in our relationship, she'd get nervous when I wanted to treat her to nice things. She'd insist on using coupons at restaurants or suggest we just get coffee instead of dinner. One time, I surprised her with a three hundred dollar coat she'd been eyeing. She cried and tried to make me return it, saying it was too expensive. Things got tense when I invited her to my parents annual Christmas party. She spent weeks stressing about what to wear, finally settling on a dress from target that she got on clearance. When we arrived, my mom greeted us wearing head to toe Gucci. Paula squeezed my hand so tight I thought she might break it. During dinner, my dad casually mentioned buying a new vacation home in Aspen. Paula nearly choked on her wine. Later, she overheard my Aunt asking my mom if I was really serious about dating someone from that background. My mom just sighed and said she hoped it was just a phase. Paula ran to the bathroom crying. When I found her, she said maybe we were too different and should break up. That's when I knew I had to show her what really mattered to me. The next day, I sold my BMW.

Dads, what's the most expensive accident your kid has ever caused? It was 2:00am when my phone rang. My 16 year old son's contact flashed on the screen. Every parent knows that middle of the night call means trouble. Dad, his voice trembled. I messed up. Are you hurt? My heart pounded so hard I could barely hear his answer. No, but, um. I crashed the car. I threw on clothes while he explained he'd taken my Mercedes without permission to impress some friends. Now it was wrapped around a tree on Lakeside Drive. Stay where you are, I'm coming. The scene was worse than I'd imagined. My 87 thousand dollar car, the one I'd worked overtime for three years to afford, looked like a crushed soda can. The front end was completely demolished, airbags deployed, glass everywhere. Tyler stood beside it, shoulders hunched, eyes red. Two police officers were writing something on clipboards. Mister Harrington, one approached me. Your son was going approximately 65 in a 35 zone. Breathalyzer came back clean, but we're issuing citations for reckless driving, taking a vehicle without consent, and violating provisional license restrictions. I nodded numbly. You're lucky, son, the officer told Tyler. Three feet to the left and you'd have hit that concrete barrier instead of the tree. After the officers left, I just stared at my car. My beautiful car that I'd only owned for eight months. Dad, I'm sorry, Tyler whispered. Get in the tow truck. I said flatly. The Silence on the ride home was suffocating. The tow truck driver kept glancing nervously between us

My manager always called for a 20 minute team meeting after work. Unpaid, so I finally had enough. When I started working at this tech company, I thought I'd hit the Jackpot. Good pay, decent benefits, and a team of only 10 people. I was the newest guy, so everyone else was basically my senior. First day on the job, everything seemed normal until 4:55 p. M. Rolled around. Alright, everyone, log off your computers. My manager, Dave announced daily team meeting in conference room B. I figured this was part of the job. We'd clock out at 5:15 p. M. After the meeting. Which meant an extra 2.5 hours on my paycheck every two weeks. Easy money for just sitting and listening, right? Wrong. When my first paycheck came, I stared at it confused. 80 hours exactly. No overtime, no extra time for those daily meetings. I pulled aside two of my co workers, Jason and Amy, during lunch. Hey, do you guys get paid for those after work meetings? I asked. Jason laughed bitterly. Dude, we've been doing this for three years. Nobody gets paid for those. Dave says it's team building and essential communication. Amy added, making air quotes, but HR won't classify it as work time. That afternoon at 4:55, Dave did his usual routine. Log off, everyone. Meeting time. I followed everyone to the conference room like a sheep. Dave droned on about quarterly goals and client satisfaction scores. Same stuff. He could have put In an email at exactly 5:00 p m. I stood up. Sorry, Dave. I need to be somewhere important, I said, grabbing my bag. 10 pairs of eyes stared at me. Dave looked.

My brother sold my car while I was deployed, so I sold his entire future. I've been overseas for 8 months. My 2,018 Honda Civic fully paid off, sitting in my parents driveway with a car cover and explicit instructions to my family, don't touch it. I get back, jet lagged and exhausted, ask my dad where my car is. He goes quiet. You need to talk to your brother. Turns out Derek had been using again. Oxy, then fentanyl, then whatever he could. Get my car title from my room, forged my signature, and sold my car to some dealer for $8,000. Spent it all in two weeks. When I confronted him, he didn't even apologize. Just said, it's just a car, man. You'll get another one. Like I hadn't worked double shifts for 2 years to buy it. Like it wasn't my only way to get to work. Derek was three months away from graduating pharmacy school. Yeah, pharmacy school. A drug addict studying to dispense drugs legally. He'd already landed a job at CVS starting at $65,000 right after graduation. That's when I realized Derek hadn't just stolen my car. He'd stolen my trust. So I decided to return the favor. First, I called the school's academic integrity office, told them I was concerned about a student with substance abuse issues who might be cheating. Had Derek's student ID from old family photos, knew his class schedule from overhearing him on calls. I didn't lie. I just Asked question. What's your policy on students with drug dependencies? How do you verify academic honesty during take home exam? They started an investigation not because of anything I said, but because Derek was already on their radar. Turns out his grades had been suspicious. Perfect scores on exams. He never studied for assignments that looked professionally written. Phase 2 was his job offer. I looked up CVS's corporate hiring policies online, found their drug testing requirements and background check procedures. Then I made an anonymous call to their HR department. I'm calling to report that one of your recent hires might have a substance abuse problem. I said I thought you should know before he starts handling controlled substances. They thanked me for the tip and said they'd follow standard protocol.

Parents, when did your child's partner win you over? I didn't want to like Elliot. When my daughter Abigail brought him home during her junior year of college, all I saw was trouble. Tattoo sleeves, motorcycle boots, and that easy charm that screamed heartbreak waiting to happen. My husband Dave warmed to him immediately. Men and their motorcycles. But I kept my distance. Mom, please give him a chance, Abigail pleaded after that first awkward dinner. He's studying engineering. The tattoos are just art. I'm just looking out for you, I said, though what I meant was, you're too young to know what's good for you. For two years I maintained what Dave called my polite frost. Whenever Elliot visited, I noticed things. We always wash dishes without being asked how. He looked at Abigail when she spoke, as if memorizing her words. But I refused to be won over by surface gestures. When they announced their engagement after graduation, I smiled tightly and said congratulations while thinking, too young, too soon, too different. The weekend before their wedding, I found myself alone with Elliot in our kitchen. Abigail and Dave had gone to pick up her dress from final alterations. Need help with dinner? He asked, rolling up his sleeves. I'm fine, I said automatically. Then, unable to help myself, tell me why I should believe you're good enough for her. He sat down the glass he was holding. I'm not, he said simply. But I'll spend my life Trying to be. I wanted to dismiss this as more charm, but something in his voice stopped me. The wedding came and went. They moved three hours away for Elliot's job. Abigail started law school. I called weekly listening

She ran from our wedding when her ex showed up. Four years later, she walked into my office with tears in her eyes. Her ex, Nate, walked into our wedding ceremony, and Vanessa dropped her bouquet. She looked at me, then at him, then ran out of the church in her wedding dress. Two hundred people watched her climb into his Porsche while I stood there holding both rings. Her mom screamed, Vanessa, what are you doing? She didn't even look back. That night, her sister called. She's already at Nate's penthouse. My stomach turned. They'd been texting for months while she helped me taste wedding cakes. The morning of our wedding, he'd sent, I'm outside. Choose him or choose me. She chose him. Two weeks later, she was in Cabo posting sunset photos while I was returning wedding gifts alone. Then our friends picked sides. They make sense together. They all knew about Nate's money. His dad owned half the city's commercial real estate. The penthouse alone was worth 10 years of my salary. Every mutual friend suddenly had plans. When I called, my best man admitted we. We all saw this coming. That destroyed me more than anything. But here's what nobody expected. I channeled every ounce of humiliation into the LSAT and scored 99th percentile. Got into law school with a full ride. Three years of pure rage fueled studying. Slept four hours a night, memorized every case about hidden assets. Morrison and Associates recruited me because I'd become obsessed with one thing. Learning exactly how rich people hide money during divorces. My professors called it unhealthy. I called it motivation. While I was becoming their best forensic analyst, Nate was buying Vanessa a yoga studio. They got married in Bali. The wedding cost more than my entire education. Instagram showed me everything. Private jets, designer everything. A life I could never give her. But I knew something they didn't. Rich people always betray each other eventually. Four years later, I heard her voice outside my office. My boss was saying, our best

My coworker kept stealing my lunch, so I made him the talk of the holiday party. The first time my lunch disappeared, I figured it was an honest mistake. The second time, a coincidence. By the fifth time, it was unmistakably theft. My homemade Italian sandwiches, carefully packed salads, leftover pasta, all vanishing from the company fridge, despite clear labels with my name, Alex Marino, do not eat. I tried everything. Labelled containers with red warning stickers, used an insulated bag, even left passive aggressive notes in the breakroom. Nothing worked. HR was useless. Without proof, we can't accuse anyone. Security cameras, privacy concerns, and common areas. They suggested I keep my lunch at my desk. Why should I adapt to a thief? One Tuesday, I added a small camera to my desk plant angled toward the breakroom door. By Wednesday afternoon, I had my culprit, Derek Williams, Marketing Director, one pay grade above me, friend of the CEO, on camera. He casually strolled in at 12:15, opened the fridge, scanned its contents, then deliberately selected my container. No hesitation, no confusion. He even smirked slightly before walking out with my chicken pesto sandwich. Confronting him directly seemed risky. Outranked me. And office politics at Patterson and Burke heavily favored management. Filing another HR complaint would lead nowhere. I needed something more memorable. My opportunity came with the announcement of the annual holiday party theme. Patterson Burke Family Feast, a potluck where executives would judge dishes in various categories. Got a five hundred dollar gift card and company wide recognition. Derek, according to office gossip, prided himself on his culinary expertise. He won the appetizer category three years running with his secret family recipe. Buffalo Chicken Dip. Perfect. For the next two weeks I let him take my lunch without complaint. Each meal more tempting than the last. Aromatic curry. Gourmet.

When did the high school legend become a legend? At my school, it was Marcus Chen. Everyone just knew he was going to make it big someday. He was the kind of guy people pointed to and said, that one, he's going places. Captain of the basketball team, straight A student, and somehow still the most grounded, humble person you'd ever meet. But what made Marcus legendary wasn't just his skills on the court. It was how he treated people. He wasn't just admired, he was respected. Genuinely, the guy knew everyone's name. Not in a fake politician way, either. He remembered little things. If you mentioned your grandma was sick and passing, he'd ask how she was doing a week later. If you were struggling in class, he'd sit with you at lunch, walking you through the assignment like it was no big deal. He made you feel like you mattered. And came senior year, and with it something none of us expected. Mister Patel, our math teacher, was diagnosed with cancer. He was one of those rare teachers everyone liked. Strict but fair. Always willing to help, even if it meant staying late. We found out his insurance wouldn't cover the experimental treatment he needed. Words spread quickly. The mood at school changed overnight. Everyone felt it. The very next morning, Marcus got on the PA system. Calm and direct. This Saturday, we're hosting a charity basketball tournament. $5 to watch, 20 to play. All proceeds go to Mister Patel's treatment. Bring your friends. Let's pack the gym. No Pep rally? No.

My childhood friend broke my heart for the dumbest reason. Two years later, I walked into his family's house as his brother's fiance. It was the last day of high school senior year, the day I planned on confessing my feelings to my childhood friend Jeremy. Before I could, Taylor, the pretty senior everyone wanted to date, cornered me by my locker after third period. Her smile was sweet, laced with bitterness. I need to stop hovering around Jeremy, she said, flipping her gorgeous blonde hair over her shoulder. He doesn't want you around. I felt my cheeks burn. Yes, he does. We're friends. He doesn't mind it. Oh, let's go ask him. Before I could protest, she grabbed my wrist and dragged me across the cafeteria where Jeremy sat with his basketball teammates. Everyone was watching. She dropped my arm by the entrance and hopped over to them. My. My heart pounded as she put on her sweetest voice, practically purring as she leaned against his chair. Hey, I've been wondering, she said, playing with his shoulder, is Sarah your girlfriend or what? Everyone at that table laughed. Sarah, the nerd with the braces? Are you dating her, man? One of his teammates asked. I would never go out with her, he said, loud enough for the nearby tables to hear. We're not even friends. She just likes doing homework. Oh, that's cold, they said, bursting into laughter. Taylor glanced back at me with a smirk that said everything. I ran straight to the bathroom, where I locked myself in a doll and cried until my eyes were too swollen to hide. Ever since we were little, we've been best friends. We studied together, played together, went on family trips. We even made matching friendship bracelets at summer. And the way he looked at me when it was just the two of us. I really thought he'd fallen for me, too. But after that day in the cafeteria, I disappeared from his life completely. I took different hallways to avoid him. I ate lunch in the library. I stopped coming to Sunday dinners, telling my mom I had too much homework. He started dating Taylor the day after, hurting me. Eventually, I had the courage to return all of his stuff. Everything he had given me over the years. I made sure to go when he'd be at practice. But when I walked into

I pretended to not receive an offensive gift. My husband's sister Rachel, has always been one of those people who thinks politics is her whole personality. Like, she literally cannot have a conversation without bringing up whatever conspiracy theory she read on Facebook that morning. During family dinners, she'd corner people and lecture them about voter fraud or whatever, while everyone else just wanted to eat their mashed potatoes in peace. I Learned pretty early on to just excuse myself whenever she started going off. My husband warned me when we got married that his family was intense about politics, but I figured I could handle it. I was wrong. Things got really bad during election season last year. Every family gathering turned into Rachel giving speeches about how the country was going to hell. She'd send these long text chains to the family group chat with links to weird websites and videos. I muted that chat after she sent a 47 message rant at 3 in the morning the week before the election. I was making dinner when our doorbell rang. I opened it and there was a package sitting there with my name on it. No delivery guy in sight, which was weird because usually they at least wait for you to grab it. The return address said it was from Rachel. I brought it inside and set it on the kitchen counter. My husband was working late, so I figured I'd wait for him to get home. Before opening it, something about getting a random package from Rachel just felt off. When he finally got back around 9, I showed him the box, he looked at the return address, and his face just fell. He goes, oh, no, what did she do now? We opened it together, and inside was this massive political flag with some really offensive stuff written on it. Like, genuinely nasty, hateful messaging that I'm not even going to repeat. There was also a note that said something like, thought you might want to show your true colours finally, with a winking face drawn.

But not with traditional heat. These contained ghost pepper extract. Tasteless at first bite, then gradually building to face melting intensity. The morning of the party, I placed my usual lunch in the fridge. A sample of these meatballs with extra sauce, clearly labeled Alex's lunch. Final test batch for party. Do not eat. Like clockwork, Derek took it at 12:15. At 12:27, I heard commotion from the marketing department. Derek, sprinting to the bathroom, face crimson, eyes watering, emerged 20 minutes later, looking destroyed, chugging milk at his desk. That evening at the party, I arrived with my official entry. Regular, delicious, non spicy meatballs. I placed them on the buffet table with a decorative sign known as Italian meatballs mild version. Derek approached the table, cautiously eyeing my dish. I smiled innocently. Everything okay, Derek? You seemed upset earlier. He cleared his throat. Fine. Stomach bug. That's terrible. Hope you're feeling better for the judging. As executives made their rounds, sampling each dish, Derek hovered nervously near my meatballs, warning people, careful with those. I heard they're extremely spicy. Our CEO laughed. These? They're delicious and perfectly mild. He turned to me. Alex, I didn't know you could cook like this. Family recipe, I replied. Though I do make a spicier version sometimes. Not everyone can handle it. The confused looks as people enjoyed my perfectly mild meatballs while Derek grew increasingly agitated was priceless. He kept insisting they must be different from what he tried. Perhaps you're Thinking of something else you ate today? I suggested innocently. Something not meant for you? Recognition flickered in his eyes, then embarrassment. My meatballs won first place. During my brief acceptance speech, I thanked my grandmother and added, I believe good food, like personal property, should be respected. Some things aren't meant to be taken without permission. I stared directly at Derek. He looked away first. The following Monday, a new sign appeared in the break room food theft is grounds for

When did you realize this generation of kids is lost? My 13 year old son, Lucas got invited to a birthday party at the local community pool. This was a huge deal. Lucas is autistic and struggles with sensory overload, but he's been working hard in therapy lately. He's been asking constantly to do normal kid things, and when his classmate Henry asked him to come, there was no way I was saying no. I spent days getting him ready. We talked through possible scenarios, practiced ways to cope, and packed his noise canceling headphones. I even reached out to Henry's mom to make sure she knew Lucas might need breaks or might have to head out early. When we arrived, he hesitated at the gate, grabbed my hand, and whispered, mom, I'm nervous, but I really wanna try. My heart nearly burst. Everything was perfect. Lucas stayed in the shallow end, laughing with two other boys. He ate cake without getting overwhelmed by the singing. I started to relax, watching from a distance so he could feel independent. Then some teenagers cannonballed right next to him. The splash, screaming, and sudden chaos triggered him instantly. I saw his face change, that distant look I know too well. He started stimming, flapping his hands and making his high pitched humming sound. I rushed over, but before I could reach him, Lucas was in full meltdown. He covered his ears, screaming and rocking. The other parents stared. Some kids backed away. While others whispered and pointed. When I finally reached him, I saw a teenage girl recording us on her phone. I snapped, stop filming my son! She stopped and walked off. Two days later, a parent messaged me. Their kid had shown them a video on TikTok. The clip showed Lucas's meltdown, no context at all, with

When did the high school legend become a legend? We had this kid in our school named Derek who barely spoke a word. Quiet, hoodie up every day, sat alone at lunch, never raised his hand. If you didn't have a class with him, you probably wouldn't even know he existed. But those of us who shared a schedule knew. The guy was scary smart, especially at math. He was the kind of kid whose homework got passed around before tests. More than once. A teacher used his assignments as the grading key. Still, he stayed invisible. Never bragged, never joined any clubs. Never even looked up from his desk unless called on. Then came AP Calculus. Our teacher, Mister Hoffman, was infamous. He'd randomly call on students during lectures and mock anyone who didn't have the answer immediately. Not light teasing, either. Full on public humiliation. He once made a guy cry during a pop quiz review. It was a cold Tuesday morning when it happened. Mister Hoffman was in rare form, tearing through problems on the board, peppering the class with questions like he was trying to thin the herd. Then he turned and called on Derek. Derek, he said, tapping the chalk on the blackboard, let's see you solve this one. He wrote out this monster equation. Long, dense, intimidating just to look at. Everyone turned in their seats. You could feel the room lock into silence. Derek didn't flinch. He stood up, walked slowly to the Board and just stared at it. No twitch, no awkward fidgeting. Just calm. Then he reached for the chalk, but instead of solving it, he erased the equation completely and wrote something.

What's something only kids who grew up poor would understand? In elementary school, hot lunch Fridays were everything. That was the only day the cafeteria served pizza instead of the usual bland government meals. The whole school buzzed about it all week. The smell would hit you before you even entered the lunchroom. Golden crust, melted cheese. Little square slices that somehow felt like magic. But the catch was, it cost two. We didn't have it. So every Friday, I faked being sick. Mom didn't push back. I was a good student. Never missed school unless I had to. When I said I wasn't feeling well, she believed me. I curl up in front of the TV and try not to think about what I was missing. It wasn't just the pizza. It was what the pizza meant. Sitting at the table, being part of the group. Not having to explain yourself or feel different. But one Friday, I had a spelling test I couldn't skip. I went to school, stomach twisted in knots. When lunchtime came, I grabbed my usual free tray and walked to the table, already bracing for it. All around me, kids were tearing open greasy cardboard boxes, laughing and trading slices. That's when the kid whose dad owned the town's car dealership looked at my tray and said, loud enough for everyone to hear you. What's that even supposed to be? The table exploded with laughter. My ears burned. I stared down at the gray Lump on my tray and said quietly, Salisbury steak. That night, I couldn't hold it in. I begged mom for pizza money. She emptied her purse on the table, counting out coins and old receipts. She gave me a small, tired smile and said, next week, baby. I promise. The next Friday, I opened my backpack and found $2 folded in a scrap of paper. For three weeks, I had pizza like everyone else. I laughed. I felt normal. But then mom lost her second job, and that Friday, I was back to the government tray. I tried to keep my head down. I sat quietly. But before I could even take a bite, the rich kid turned and started up again. Same smirk, same voice. Ready to embarrass me all over again. But he never got.

What weird rule did your parents suddenly make up that made no sense? My mom was always strict but fair. No TV on school nights, grades before games. The usual stuff. Then I got into this habit of whistling all the time. My mom would always tell me to knock it off. Then she announced a new household rule. No whistling. Not inside, not outside. Not even humming with a whistle like tone. At first I thought she was joking. Who bans whistling? But she was dead serious. Complete with a three strikes policy where the third offense meant losing my phone for a week. The first time I broke the rule, I was brushing my teeth and absent mindedly whistling a song. She appeared in the bathroom doorway. Strike one, she said, her face completely neutral. I laughed it off. Mom, this is ridiculous. It's just whistling. It's not just whistling, she snapped. Just follow the damn rule! Two nights later, I whistled while taking out the trash. Like, two. My dad thought the whole thing was as weird as I did. He'd raise his eyebrows and shrug whenever mom went on whistling patrol, but he never challenged her on it. That was their marriage in a nutshell. She made the rules, he went along to keep the peace. I made it almost a month without another slip up. Then one night, I was hanging in my room, headphones on, when I caught myself whistling along to the beat. I didn't even realize I'd done it until my door flew open. Mom stood there, tears streaming down her face. I yanked my headphones off. Mom. Instead of saying, strike three, she just buried her face in her hands, sobbing. In 14 years, I'd seen my mother cry exactly twice. When her dad died and when our dog got hit by a car. I'm sorry, I said. I didn't mean to whistle. It was an accident. She grabbed my hand.

I told my wife to divorce me because I'm not forcing adoption on my daughter. My eight year old daughter, Ella, has been through hell. Her mom is a complete mess. Drugs, alcohol, arrests, the whole disaster package. I got full custody when she was little, and I've been with my wife Laura, since Ella was two. Laura knew exactly what she was signing up for. When we got married, she said she was cool with it all, that she understood Ella came first. But now Laura wants to adopt Ella to completely cut out her biological mom. And I get it. Every time Ella's mom shows up for her court ordered visits, she either doesn't come at all or shows up high. Last time she came to pick up Ella for a supervised visit, she reeked of weed and couldn't even remember what grade Ella was in. Social worker had to send her home. Ella's been in therapy for years, trying to process why her mom can't just be normal. She draws pictures of them together sometimes, where her mom looks clean and happy. It breaks my heart every single time. But even with all this pain, Ella doesn't want Laura to adopt her. I asked her about it privately. She said she still loves her real mom and hopes she'll get better someday. Laura lost it when I told her Ella's decision. She started going on about how we have our two other kids to think about, how Ella might choose her train wreck mom over us if she keeps coming around. She said she's tired of just being the stepmom when she's been more of a mother to Ella than her actual mom ever was. I've been putting Ella first for six years, he said, pacing around our kitchen last week. I pack her lunches, I help with homework, I take her to therapy appointments, but legally, I'm nobody to her. Some junkie who can't even stay sober for a two hour visit has more rights than I do. I tried explaining that forcing adoption would destroy any trust Ella has in us, but Laura kept pushing. She said I

When did your wife realize you weren't just an unemployed? Twitch chatter. Sarah came home from her 12 hour hospital shift to find me in the same spot at my computer. Twitch stream on one monitor, spreadsheets minimized on the other. She dropped her bag with that familiar exhausted sound. Mike, eight months. You've been unemployed for eight months watching gamers play Fortnite? My mom keeps asking if you're depressed. I quickly switched tabs as she approached. Just keeping myself busy. Busy? You're watching someone build a virtual house. She saw my chat messages. Actively participating. This isn't a hobby anymore. It's an addiction. What she didn't see were the other tabs. Supplier emails from China, Shipping trackers, customer service responses. The Twitch streams were just background noise while I managed orders, adjusted Facebook ad campaigns, and negotiated with suppliers about delayed shipments. My sister's husband just bought a rental property, Sarah continued. Meanwhile, I'm telling people you're between opportunities. The truth was, my dropshipping business was finally profitable after six months of testing products. Gaming accessories of all things. Mouse pads with LED edges, custom keyboard caps, cable management systems. I found by watching what streamers complained about. Can you at least come to dinner tomorrow? Pretend you're trying. Her family dinner was torture. Her brother described his new BMW. Her father offered me a pity job at his hardware store. Again, Sarah deflected questions about our future, saying we were figuring things out. Maybe he could drive for Uber, her mother suggested, loud enough for me to hear. Everything unraveled because a doorbell camera notification. Sarah was showing her sister our ring footage to prove our neighbour's dog kept getting in our yard. She scrolled too far back and saw something odd. Delivery drivers. Dozens of them. Every single day. Mike, why are so many packages coming to our house? Her sister leaned in. Are you shopping addicts? Is that why you're broke? There returns, I said quickly. But Sarah kept scrolling. The packages were being picked up, not dropped off. Different drivers collecting them.

What moment finally made you snap? Slap? The sound of the owner's hand when he hit the pregnant waitress's face made the entire restaurant freeze. All you ever do is complain! You're lucky I even let you keep your job! Mister Schiller! Yelled. The pregnant waitress held her cheek tightly. Please, Mister Schiller, I need those tips for the hospital! She begged. Tips? You cost me more than you make! He grabbed her arm, dragging her towards the kitchen. My baby's due next month. Please! Not my problem! He shoved her hard. Now clean that up, he said, pointing to the broken glass jar he had dropped after stealing his employees tips. She started picking up glass on her knees, sobbing. Schiller kicked more glass toward her. Faster! I stood up, holding the heavy ceramic plate over my head. Yoo hoo! I whistled before dropping it onto the marble floor. Crash! Everyone gasped. What the? He spun around just as I picked up another plate and dropped it. Sir, what are you doing? That's $700 each! I shrugged, picked up the window glass and dropped it too. Then I walked over to the next tail and swept everything off. Stop! Stop! I'm calling the police! Good! I said. Call them! I kept going. Schiller rushed over and grabbed my collar. You'll pay for every piece! And you'll pay for everything everyone has had to deal with under you! I grinned back at him as he blew up in my face. Everyone stood still, watching us, wondering the same thing. Why? Why was a stranger suddenly throwing around plates? Well, it was for a good reason. The police arrived quickly, walking in, looking just as confused as everyone else was. Mister Schiller grinned, letting my collar go finally. Officers, arrest this man? He demanded snobbishly, pointing at me. The officers raised an eyebrow. You want us to arrest him? He's. I shook my head at them and smiled back at Mister Schiller. Why not arrest you instead

What's the boldest move you pulled at school? I convinced my entire high school I was colorblind for three years just to win a fifty dollar bet. It started in freshman biology when our teacher was droning on about genetic disorders. Jake Miller, cocky, rich, and always looking for entertainment, leaned over and whispered, I bet you couldn't fake being colorblind for a whole month without getting caught. I've never been able to resist a challenge. Especially from someone like Jake, who drove a BMW his daddy bought him while I worked weekends at Dairy Queen. Make it until graduation and you've got a deal, I whispered back. Fifty bucks says you crack in a month. He smirked, extending his hand. We shook on it right there between plastic models of DNA strands. That night I researched everything about red green color blindness. I Learned about Isihara tests, those dotted circles doctors use, how color blind people navigate traffic lights, and common mistakes they make. By morning, I had a game plan. Day one, I accidentally mixed up my red and green folders in front of our math teacher. Sorry, I mumbled, just loud enough for him to hear. They look the same to me. He paused mid equation. Thomas, are you colorblind? I feigned embarrassment, staring at my shoes. Yeah, I don't really talk about it. Words spread through the teacher's lounge like wildfire. By lunch, my history teacher was asking if I needed special accommodations for map activities. By the end of the week, the school counselor called me in to discuss my learning needs. I committed fully. I bought special colorblind glasses online that did absolutely nothing but look convincing, wearing them dramatically during school events and removing

To the front door, where no one could miss it. The first text came around 4 p m. Hey, the key isn't working. Did you lock the deadbolt? I didn't answer. The call started escalating from different numbers. First Olivia, then Marie. By 6 p m, the tone shifted from annoyance to panic. What did you do? There's a storage receipt taped to the door. Are you kidding me? Apparently, they'd spent the night sleeping in the U Haul truck because they had nowhere else to go. When Hannah finally called, screaming about me being a psychopath, I calmly explained, I didn't throw anything out. Your belongings are safe and climate controlled storage. You were a guest who tried to move two other people in and relegate the homeowner to the couch. I just declined your terms. They tried everything. Police, welfare checks. So social media campaigns, lawsuit threats. When police came, I showed them Hannah's texts about me sleeping on the couch and doorbell footage of them screaming at my door. The officer sighed and said, so she tried to move friends in without permission, and now she's claiming you're unstable? I compiled screenshots of their defamatory posts, sent them to Hannah's tech company HR Department. I contacted their old property management company with evidence of their harassment from Marie, the aspiring influencer. I sent her smear campaign screenshots to every brand she'd tagged. Three weeks later, Hannah was fired for violating her company's social media policy. Olivia and Marie were blacklisted from reputable apartments. Marie's influencer dreams imploded when brand started blocking her. The quiet in my house feels like justice.

I'm a rescue diver and I found a missing kid in the forbidden part of our lake. What I saw will haunt me forever. I've been doing water rescue for eight years now, and most calls are body recovery, not rescue. People don't survive long in these freezing northern waters. But what I found last Tuesday has me ready to quit and never look back. The all came at 2 p m. When a father took his seven year old daughter, Emma, fishing at Crystal Lake. He turned away for 30 seconds to untangle his line. And when he looked back, she was gone. No splash, no scream. Just gone. I knew she was dead before we even arrived because the water temp was 42 degrees. Even if she could swim, hypothermia would kill her in minutes. But we had to try. My dive partner Jake and I searched the main area for three hours, but we found nothing. The current was brutal from recent storms. And that's when I noticed something odd. One of the old creek beds that had been dry for years was flowing again. And heavy rains must have opened it back up. I followed the creek and realized where it LED, which made my blood go cold. The dead zone. That's what the older divers called the deepest part of Crystal Lake. Hundred yard stretch where the water drops to over two hundred feet. We're strictly forbidden from diving there because unpredictable currents will kill you. They Always said. But the creek LED directly into the dead zone. So if Emma got swept into that current, her body would be down there. Jake was searching the other side of the lake, so I made a decision that still haunts me. I geared up and dropped into the forbidden waters alone. The first thing I noticed was how wrong the older divers were, because there was no current at all. The water was eerily still, like swimming in black suit. And I descended fifty feet, then a hundred, with nothing but darkness below. At 150 feet, my light finally hit something, and I thought it was seaweed at first. Long, pale strands swaying in the water. But as I got closer, I realized what I was really looking at. Arms. Hundreds of human arms, growing from the lake bottom like some twisted underwater forest. They were all different sizes, from tiny baby arms no bigger than my thumb, to adult arms thick as tree branches. All of them were pale green and moving slowly, grasping at the water around them. And they had roots spreading through the sediment, like they've been planted there.

Who taught women this secret code? I thought I knew all the rules until my 16 year old sister saved me from my toxic boyfriend with moves I'd never seen. I was dating Tyler for eight months. Classic red flags. Checking my phone, controlling who I saw, getting mad when I hung out with friends. It started small. Who's texting you? Became going through my messages. I just worry about you became showing up at my work unannounced. Your friends don't really get you like I do. Became me. Canceling plans constantly. I kept making excuses. He's just protective. He loves me. But deep down, I felt like I was drowning. At my family barbecue, Tyler was being his usual controlling self, interrupting every conversation. I started pulling me away when I laughed, with my cousins standing so close behind me, I could barely breathe. I watched my family's faces change when he'd speak for me or cut me off mid sentence. I was embarrassed, but felt trapped. How do you tell your family your boyfriend is suffocating you when you're not even sure if it's bad enough to complain about? That's when my sister Maya appeared. Jess! She squealed, grabbing my arm with fake enthusiasm. Mom needs you inside right now. Wedding planning emergency. I was genuinely confused. What wedding? Cousin Amy's the 1 we've been helping plan. She shot Tyler a sweet smile that didn't reach her eyes. Sorry, Tyler. Total girl emergency. You know how crazy wedding Stuff gets. Before I could process what was happening, she was dragging me toward the house. Tyler tried to follow, his jaw tight with that familiar anger, but Maya spun around, still smiling. Actually, Tyler, could you help my dad with the grill? He's been asking

What's your I came looking for copper but found gold moment? I was 14 and I was walking through the mall when I saw a girl my age sitting alone at the arcade playing a racing game by herself. She looked really lonely, mashing buttons and talking to the screen like she had someone to compete with, making sound effects and celebrating when she won races against nobody. So I decided to go over and challenge her to try and make her day better. I walked up to her and asked if I wanted to race against her and I saw her face just completely change. Really? You really wanna play against me? I told her yes and I asked her which game she wanted to play so I could show her some moves. I knew she got excited and was about to pick a two player game, but then at the last second she stopped. She grabbed her backpack and said, the last time someone asked to play games with me and I let them use my quarters, they took all my money and left me standing there with nothing. My mom called me stupid and said stupid kids don't deserve more arcade money and I had to save up my allowance for three weeks just to come back here. I'm not stupid anymore and I'm not sharing. She turned around clutching her bag tight and my heart broke for her. I walked back over and Pinky promised her I wasn't going to take her money and told her I'd use my own quarters right next to her so I couldn't steal anything. I even showed her my wallet to prove I had my own money. She ended up agreeing to play, and when I showed her the combo moves, she was absolutely amazed. She yelled, that's so awesome! Teach me how to do that! She then started practicing really hard, and although she was messing up the timing at first, she seemed so focused and determined. I'll beat you, just you watch, she said with this fierce look in her eyes. And then after a full hour of trying and failing and trying again, she pulled off the combo perfectly. When she did, she was so thrilled she jumped up and down screaming and called me her awesome new gaming buddy. We took turns playing different games the rest of the afternoon, and she kept getting better and better at everything I taught her. When I told her I had to go home, she looked disappointed, but then asked me if I wanted to meet.

What's the most unhinged thing someone has ever done after you didn't text them back? So this girl reported me to my university's ethics committee because I didn't reply to her DM within 24 hours. I wish I was joking. We matched on hinge. Her name was Madison. Basic conversation, nothing special. She sends me a paragraph about her weekend plans. I read it, think cool story, and forget to respond because I was cramming for midterms and surviving on energy drinks. Next morning, I wake up to 17 messages, not spread out over hours. 17 consecutive texts in the span of 12 minutes. Message 1 hey, did you see my last text? Message 7 I know you're active because your location updated. Message 17 this is actually really disrespectful behavior, and I don't appreciate ignored. Ma'am, it's been 18 hours. I'm not ignoring you. I'm just living my life without my phone glued to my face. I finally respond, sorry, was studying. How was your weekend? Too late. The damage is done. She replies, studying for 18 hours straight? That seems unlikely. This girl really pulled out a calculator to fact check my study session like I'm filing taxes instead of trying to pass organic chemistry. I say, I had other stuff going on, too. Work, sleep, basic human functions. She goes, I think you're lying. People who are genuinely busy still make time for basic courtesy. Basic courtesy? We've exchanged like 10 messages total. We're not engaged, but Madison's just getting started. She screenshots our entire conversation and post it on her Instagram story with the caption, men really think they can just ignore women with no consequences? No consequences? It's a dating app, not a legally binding contract. Then she finds my LinkedIn somehow discovers where I go to school, and files a formal complaint with the university ethics committee for demonstrating poor character and disrespect.

When I started babysitting, the parents gave me a horrifying set of rules. I thought I hit the Jackpot when the Morrison family offered me $300 to babysit their daughter for one night. I had no idea this would be the last normal day of my life. The job seemed perfect. Rich neighborhood, well behaved kid, easy money. What could go wrong? Everything, apparently. When I arrived at their mansion on Elm Street, Missus Morrison answered the door, looking absolutely exhausted, dark circles under her eyes, hands shaking slightly as she spoke. Thank god you're here, Riley, she said, practically pulling me inside. We haven't had a night out in months. Mr. Morrison came downstairs carrying their seven year old daughter, Sophie. The little girl was adorable, with curly blonde hair and big blue eyes. But something felt off. She didn't smile when she saw me. She just stared. Before we leave, Miss, Missus Morrison said, handing me several folded papers. These are very important instructions. Please follow them exactly. Sophie's special. I nodded, stuffing the papers in my pocket without reading them. Big mistake. They left in a hurry, practically running to their car. I should have known something was wrong when they didn't even say goodbye to Sophie. The first few hours went great. Sophie and I watched cartoons, played board games, ate pizza. She was sweet and polite, nothing like the weird, difficult kids I usually dealt with. Around 7:30 she yawned and said she was getting Tired? What time is your bedtime? I asked. Mommy says I have to be in my room with the door locked by 8 p m, she said. Matter of factly locked? That seemed weird, but rich parents had strange rules sometimes. I figured I'd check the instructions once I got her settled. I tucked Sophie into her bed at 7:55. As I was leaving, she grabbed my arm. Don't forget to lock the door, whispered urgently. And whatever you hear tonight, don't come back in here. Promise me. Why would I need to? Promise me, she said, her grip tightening. Okay, okay. I promise. I closed her door and noticed the heavy duty lock installed on the outside. Not a regular bedroom lock. This was the kind they used in psychiatric hospitals. My hands were shaking as I turned the key. Downstairs, I finally pulled out Missus Morrison's instruction. What I read made my blood turn to ice.

Like this. She demonstrated by grabbing her own face and making exaggerated kissing sounds. Not a cheek peck, a real kiss. My seven year old was unknowingly describing my husband's affair in perfect detail. I had to excuse myself to the bathroom, where I sat on the toilet seat and cried for ten minutes, my whole body shaking. All those late nights, all those work emergencies. All those times he came home smelling different. And I'd actually

What's the hardest thing you've ever done? Three years ago, my wife Kathy was diagnosed with breast cancer. She fought for five years, but we never knew she was terminal until eight days before she passed. We were at the hospital for her regular chemotherapy when a nurse walked up and asked how she was feeling. Kathy smiled and said she was just tired. Then, without warning, the nurse asked what she wanted to do on her last few days. I stared at her. What are you talking about? The nurse's face dropped. Oh, I thought the doctor already told you. I broke down crying. The entire staff gathered around apologizing. But it didn't matter. We had just Learned the fight was over, and no one had told us. Two days before she passed, I was outside installing a new mailbox. Kathy came out and sat in a lawn chair watching me. The sun made her skin look less yellow, and I told her she was looking better. I wanted to believe she was getting better. That night, Kathy started vomiting constantly. By the morning, I told her we needed to go to the hospital. As I helped her get dressed, she was too weak to stand. I called my daughter over, and we decided to call an ambulance. I walked outside to wait. Then the front door burst open. Mom's not breathing. I ran inside. Kathy was sitting on the edge of the bed, eyes open, but she wasn't Breathing, I called 9 1 1, screaming for help. Paramedics arrived and rushed her to the hospital, while I followed behind and called her brother and sister. When I arrived, I begged to be with her, but they wouldn't let me back. The nurse told me they're doing the best they can. I begged her to ask the doctor if I could sit with her. A few minutes later, he returned and let me inside. The room was full of doctors and nurses fighting to bring her back. We have to make a decision. She's not going to make it. I broke down completely and we had to pull the plug. Everything stopped. Kathy was gone. I never got to say goodbye. I was outside waiting for the ambulance, but my stepdaughter told me Kathy's last words. I'm ready.

What's the weirdest thing you've ever been bribed to do? In fourth grade, a kid named Tyler walked up to me during recess and said, I'll give you five bucks if you pretend to be my twin brother for the whole day. I looked at him completely confused, because Tyler and I looked nothing alike. I had dark hair, he was blond. I wore glasses, he didn't. He was short, I was tall. But five bucks was five bucks, and I wasn't about to turn down free money. So I shrugged and said, deal. That's when I Learned he had already been telling everyone in our class that he had a secret twin who went to another school. Apparently, this started as a joke, but then people actually believed him. And instead of admitting he was lying, he doubled down. Now he needed me to prove it. The plan. Every time someone asked him something, I'd answer for him and vice versa. If a teacher called on him, I had to answer like I was also Tyler. If someone asked me a question, he'd respond like we were one person. It was the stupidest thing ever, but for some reason, people actually bought it. Then in gym class, things went very wrong. We were playing dodgeball when a teacher stopped the game and yelled, Tyler, why are you on both teams? I panicked. Tyler panicked. We both just stood there staring at her, waiting for the other to say something. Then Tyler grabbed his knee, fell over and yelled, Mrs. Davis, I think I'm seeing double. She genuinely looked concerned. She walked us both to the nurse's office, where Tyler kept acting dizzy, saying he felt weird, like there were two of him. We sat there for twenty minutes while the nurse gave him crackers and told him to breathe slowly. By the end of the day, he so committed to the bit that he even wrote my name on his homework and tried to turn it in. The next morning, he handed me a single dollar Bill and said, sorry, I only have this. But you were the best fake twin ever. I never got the rest of my money. Most importantly, Sophie has been dead for three years. What's in that room is something else. Something that found her body and decided to wear it. We can't get rid of it, so we contain it. We've been looking for someone young and healthy, too. Well, you'll understand soon enough. The doors are locked from the outside. There's no cell service here, no landline. You can't leave. We're sorry, but Sophie needs to feed, and we can't do this anymore. Good luck. The Morrisons. P S. If you're reading this,

I got an emergency alert telling me to stay out of my basement when I tried to leave town. Something was waiting for us. It was ten thirty one PM when my phone buzzed with an emergency alert that said do not enter underground structures such as basements. Stay above ground until they all clear. My husband Mark looked up from his own phone and we stared at each other, both having received the same message. What do you think's going on? I asked, glancing toward our basement door. Our five year old daughter, Emma had been asleep for an hour upstairs. Could be a gas leak or radar issue, Mark replied, but his voice sounded uncertain. I ran upstairs to check on Emma, who was sleeping peacefully in her bed, then came back down to find Mark staring at the TV. The local news channel was displaying the same emergency alert in blocky white letters on a black screen, but when he flipped to CNN and other networks, there was nothing about any emergency in our area. I pulled out my phone and searched Google for any news about the alert, but nothing came up. I texted Sarah, a neighbor from two streets over, asking if she'd gotten the same message. No response. I think we should leave, I said, grabbing a duffel bag from the closet. We can go to my sister's place until this clears up. But Emma has school tomorrow and I have work, Mark protested. Don't you work from home on Mondays, anyway? I replied, already packing clothes and Emma's favorite stuffed animals into the bag. While Mark hesitated, I walked over to our basement door and noticed the chain lock was latched. I hurried to the kitchen, grabbed some duct tape, and started sealing the cracks around the basement door. What are you doing? Mark asked. If it's some kind of gas leak, I don't want it getting into the rest of the house, I said, pulling another strip of tape across the bottom gap. Within 10 minutes, I had packed our essentials and was ready to leave. Mark finally agreed to wake Emma, and we carried her out to the car. Wrapped in blankets. She stirred sleepily, but didn't fully wake up as I strapped her into her car seat. As we pulled out of our driveway, I noticed how quiet the neighborhood was. If everyone had gotten the same alert, wouldn't more people be leaving? The houses on our street were all dark except for automatic porch lights, and there were no other cars on the road.

Why don't you talk to your parents anymore? They kicked me out at 17 when my girlfriend Thea got pregnant. Not asked to leave. Literally threw my stuff on the lawn and changed the locks. Dad screamed I was throwing my life away. Mom cried about the neighbors. Their ultimatum. Break up with Thea and give the baby up or never come home. I chose Thea. We lived in my car for two months, then a friend's basement. Those first weeks were hell. Thea had morning sickness so bad she couldn't keep anything down. I'd hold her hair back in gas station bathrooms, both of us crying. I remember one night in November, the car windows fog up from our breathing. Thea was shivering despite three blankets. She whispered, maybe your parents were right. Maybe we're too young for this. I held her tighter and said, no, we're going to prove them wrong. But honestly, I was terrified. I'd wake up at three a m. In panic attacks, wondering how we'd afford formula or doctor visits. Thea would rub my back and remind me we had each other. The worst part was driving past my house for school. I'd see mom watering her flowers, dad washing his car. Normal life continuing like I'd never existed. Thea caught me staring once and just squeezed my hand. They don't deserve you, she said. But I still missed them every single day. Her parents weren't thrilled either, but they never abandoned her. Mom Delfine started buying prenatal vitamins and baby clothes. Her dad taught me basic car maintenance so I wouldn't get stranded. Family sticks together, Delfine told me one night. Blood or not, that hit different when my own blood relatives had written me off. Christmas was the hardest. Thea's family invited me.

Bartenders, what's the most awkward first date you've ever seen? I've been working at this upscale steakhouse called the Prime Cut for almost four years now, and I've seen more first dates than I can count. Most blend together in my memory, but there was one last Tuesday that I'll never forget. The evening rush hadn't started yet when this woman walked in. Late 20s, wearing a sundress that still had the tags tucked in, clutching a small wrapped gift that looked like it came from the bookstore next door. She was 50 minutes early for her reservation and asked for a specific spot at the bar that she requested when booking. As I set up her area, I noticed her hands trembling slightly as she placed the gift on the empty stool beside her. She kept checking her reflection in the mirror behind the bar, are adjusting her earrings and practicing what looked like conversation starters under her breath. So how was your drive over? She whispered to herself, then shook her head and tried again. Is this your first time at the prime cut? The nervousness was radiating off her in waves. For those 15 minutes, she just sat there nursing a Diet Coke, rearranging her purse, and checking her phone every two minutes. Our manager even asked if everything was okay, and she assured us her date was coming at 7:00. When he finally arrived, the contrast was immediate. He was polished, expensive watch, tailored jacket. But He barely acknowledged her as he slid onto the stool. Before she could even hand him the gift, he pulled out his phone and started scrolling, saying, sorry. Client stuff. You know how it is. The woman's face fell for a split second before she plastered on a smile and gently placed the gift on the bar between them. I brought them water and took their drink orders. A simple wine spritzer for her, a specific brand of Bourbon with exactly two ice cubes, not crushed, for him. When I returned with their drinks, he was still glued to his phone. She was desperately trying to connect, asking about his work, his weekend plans, his thoughts on the restaurant, while he gave one word answers without looking up. The few times he did engage, it was to interrupt her

My new apartment came with a survival guide from the previous tenant. I just found my boyfriend's name on a murder list. I moved into apartment 42 with my boyfriend Marcus three days ago. We've been together for five years and finally saved enough to leave our parents houses. He's 24, I'm 22. And this was supposed to be our fresh start together. The apartment was way too good for our budget. Two bedrooms, city part views, balcony deposit free with a five year lease option. The landlord said no inspections, no questions asked. It felt too good to be true, but we were desperate. On our first morning, I found a handwritten note in the kitchen cupboard. Beautiful cursive writing that said new occupier of apartment 42 on the outside. Inside was a 12 rule survival guide from the previous tenant. Missus Prudence Hemmings, who lived here 35 years before her husband died in some kind of incident. Rule seemed insane at first. Never use the elevator between 1:11 and 3:00am. Ignore the window cleaner who appears on the balcony. Don't talk to neighbors claiming to live in apartment 65 to 72 because those burned down in the 80s and everyone died. Keep weapons in every room. Don't babysit Terry's kids from Apartment 26. I thought it was some sick joke until everything started happening exactly as described. At 11:00am, a friendly window cleaner knocked on our balcony door on the seventh floor. He exactly 30 minutes tapping and Calling out, never breaking eye contact through the glass. When he left, I checked every balcony in the building. He vanished completely. That afternoon, I heard the animal noises from apartment 48. Not dog barking or cat meowing. Something else. Something that sounded like it was in pain. Dying slowly, over and over again. At 8:00am the next morning, the postman, Ian, knocked. When I opened the door, he looked at me with sad eyes and said, missus Hemmings left something for you, didn't she? I'm sorry about what's coming. What do you mean? I asked. The rules aren't suggestions, he whispered. They're the only thing keeping you alive. This building feeds on people who don't follow them. That's when I noticed the damp patch on our bedroom ceiling had turned deep red overnight. Not rust or water damage. It looked like blood pooling and spreading, but never dripping. Marcus had been acting strange since we moved in. Distant, jumpy, checking the time constantly. Yesterday, he kept muttering about his early shift, saying he had to leave at 3:15.

Have you ever heard someone talking about you in a foreign language? For six months, my German neighbor Heidi had been hosting these fancy dinner parties. What Heidi didn't know was that my mom is German. I grew up speaking it at home, but rarely mentioned it since moving to the city. Why would I? Every weekend, like clockwork, I'd hear Heidi and her friends laughing. Die amerikanerin und die banane ist so languish. The American next door is so boring. Or the hat kind gushmack. She has no taste. Once she even joked about my pathetic dating life after seeing me bring home the same guy twice. At first, I brushed it off. Just mean girl talk, right? But week after week, it started to wear on me. I'd catch myself standing in front of my closet, overthinking my outfits. Is my style really that bad? I started ordering takeout from different restaurants to seem more cultured. And walking through our hallway with bags. God, how pathetic is that? The worst was when my mom came to visit. We were speaking German in the elevator when Heidi got in. Mom was mid sentence about her garden back home when Heidi's eyes widened with recognition at the language. She stared at the floor numbers like they were the most fascinating thing she'd ever first Seen. My stomach dropped, not because she'd heard us speaking German, but because I realized how deeply I'd let her comments affect me. I hadn't even told my own mother about the situation because I was embarrassed about not stand standing up for myself. That night, after mom left, I sat alone in my apartment, listening to Heidi's laughter. Through the wall I could hear glasses clinking, music playing, and then, right on cue, hear a mutter zephanio languidly like alswiezie. Her mother looks just as boring as she does.

What's your best instant karma story? I'm driving to work last Tuesday when this guy in a lifted truck starts tailgating me aggressively.
