I don't speed up, he starts swerving into the oncoming lane, trying to pass on a two lane road with heavy traffic. Finally he finds a gap and floors it past me, but not before rolling down his window to flip me off and scream something about learning how to drive. Here's where it gets interesting. The guy immediately cuts back into my lane, nearly clipping my front bumper, then slams on his brakes to teach me a lesson about following distance. I had to break hard to avoid rear ending him. This moron is literally brake checking me after complaining I was going too slow. For the next two miles he's weaving through traffic like he's in fast and furious, cutting people off, running yellow lights, the whole nine yards. I'm just maintaining my normal speed, watching this lunatic endanger everyone on the road. Then I see the construction zone ahead, single lane flaggers controlling traffic, and a long line of cars already stopped. Mister Road Rage doesn't notice until the last second. He slams on his brakes, but he's going way too fast. His truck starts skidding on the morning dew and He slides right past the stopped cars into the construction zone. I pull up safely behind the last car in line and watch through my windshield as this guy's truck gets stuck in wet concrete that the crew was pouring for a new sidewalk. The construction workers are yelling and waving their arms as his rear wheels spin uselessly and what's probably $1,000 worth of concrete mix. But wait, it gets better.

I complained the whole time about taking

When did you realize someone was stealing from you? I've been living with Jake for eight months when I started noticing my adderall running out faster than it should. At first, I thought maybe I was taking extra doses during final stress, but the numbers weren't adding up. I'm prescribed 30 pills per month, one daily, but by day 20, I'd only have five pills left. This happened three months in a row. Jake was the obvious suspect. He had access to my room where I kept my medication, and had been acting weird. New clothes, expensive dinners, always had cash when he used to be broke. Must be miscounting, he'd say when I mentioned running out early. ADHD brains, right? The thing is, I'm a pharmacy student. Tracking medication is literally what I do. For my senior thesis, I was researching prescription drug diversion, so I've been documenting everything. I decided to set a trap. I bought a small spy camera from Amazon and hid it in my bookshelf, aimed at my desk, where I kept my medication. Then I marked each pill bottle with a tiny dot and photographed every pill from multiple angles. I also started a spreadsheet tracking the exact number of pills, their characteristics, and when I took them. If Jake was stealing, I'd have proof. Three days later, I reviewed the camera footage. There was Jake, 2 p m. On Tuesday, going through my desk while I was in class. He opened my prescription Bottle shook out several pills and put them in his pocket, but I wanted to catch him in the act and see how deep this went. The post had dozens of responses from desperate students looking for Adderall during midterms. I created a fake account and message Jake's username pretending to be a freshman needing study help. Hey, I heard you have study aids available. My roommate mentioned you might have adderall. Yeah, I got the good stuff. Prescription grade, $20 per pill. Meet at the library. He was selling my medication for $20 per pill. Pills that cost me $5.

I turned to the father. Sir, she's completely fine. He squinted. What do you mean? She fabricated the whole situation. He looked at the steaming cloth, then at his daughter, and visibly deflated. Are you serious? The girl started scrambling. I didn't intend to. I just didn't prepare for my history presentation. Dead silence followed. Then he erupted. You summon paramedics over a school presentation? She attempted justification. I thought I'd get an F. He faced us. You're free to Go. Thanks. As we departed, he slammed her door. We heard objects crashing, yelling, and him declaring, your re. You're grounded till college. Use the money to become a criminal defense attorney specializing in cases involving prosecutorial misconduct. Trevor got out last year. Works at a gas station now. Sometimes I drive by just to see how far he's fallen. From governor candidate to night shift attendant. The Maxwells thought they could bury the truth forever. Instead, they just delayed it until the moment it would hurt the most.

He demanded to skip the basic training and go straight to advanced jumps because he'd played a lot of video games. When I refused, he pulled out his phone and showed me his social media. He had two million followers and made videos doing dangerous stunts. He threatened to post about how our school was refusing service to famous influencers unless we let him skip the basics. My boss, worried about bad publicity, asked me to give him a chance. The kid signed every waiver with a smirk, bragging about how he'd probably teach me some new tricks. He wouldn't stop talking about his parkour videos and how skydiving would be easy mode for someone like him. During the ground training, he kept interrupting me to explain how he'd seen it done differently on YouTube. When I tried to show him proper parachute handling, he rolled his eyes and said, I've watched literally every skydiving video on the internet. Morning of his first jump, he showed up hungover. I told him we'd have to reschedule, but he threatened to sue us for discrimination. He live streamed himself getting into the plane, telling his followers he was about to show this old instructor how it's really done at

What's the biggest power trip you've seen backfire? This cop pulled me over for reckless driving and started lecturing me about respecting authority until he realized I was rushing to diffuse a bomb threat at the courthouse. I'm driving to work when I get an emergency call. Suspicious package at the courthouse? Possible. I'm a bomb disposal technician. Every second matters. I flip on flashers and speed downtown. Five minutes later, red and blue lights. Local officer pulls me over. I roll down my window, already reaching for my badge. Officer, I'm. Save it. He cuts me off. License and registration. Do you have any idea how fast you were going? Sir, I'm responding to an emergency call. I don't want to hear excuses. You were doing 65 in a 35 zone, weaving through traffic like a maniac. This is Officer Bradley. I recognize him from department meetings. Young guy, maybe two years on the force. Always trying to prove how tough he is. Officer, I'm Detective Martinez, bomb squad. Code red at the courthouse. He barely glances at my badge. Yeah, right. Every speeder thinks they're a cop. You can call dispatch. I'm not calling anyone. You think some fake badge gets you out of a ticket? My radio crackles. All units, courthouse evacuation in progress. Bomb squad ETA requested. Bradley hears it but doesn't react. Turn that scanner off. You're not fooling anyone. That's not a scanner. That's my departmental radio. I really need to get to the Courthouse. Sure you do, buddy. And I'm the sheriff. He's taking his sweet time writing the ticket. Clearly enjoying the power trip. Officer, people could die if that device detonates. Please, just call your sergeant. Stop being so dramatic. There's no bomb threat. I would have been notified. My phone starts ringing. It's Captain Williams. Martinez, where are you? We need that device cleared now. Buildings evacuated.

What's the weirdest reason someone got offended at a coffee shop? So I accidentally started a full scale latte art controversy because I said thanks wrong. Let me explain. It was Tuesday morning. I'm running on three hours of sleep and the emotional stability of a wet napkin. I stumble into this bougie coffee shop downtown. You know the type. Edison bulbs everywhere. Baristas who look like they exclusively date people with septum piercings and a chalkboard menu written in cursive so fancy it might as well be hieroglyphics. I order a simple cappuccino. Nothing crazy. No oat milk, no extra shots, no interpretive dance on top. Just caffeine in a cup so I can pretend to be a functioning adult. The barista, let's call her Luna, because of course, that's her name, makes my drink with the intensity of someone performing surgery. She's got this little metal pitcher steaming milk like she's summoning spirits. Takes her a solid five minutes to create what I can only describe as the Mona Lisa of foam art. She slides across the counter with this proud smile and goes, I made you a swan. I look down. It's beautiful. Beautiful, like, genuinely impressive. This foam swan is sitting there looking more elegant than I've ever looked in my entire life. I'm genuinely appreciative. So I say, oh, wow, that's really cool. Thanks. And Luna's face just drops like, I told her my dog died. She blinks twice and goes, cool. I pause mid Sip? Yeah, it's. It's really well done. She crosses her arms. I spent six years perfecting latte art. This isn't cool. This is craft. Ma'am, I said it was cool because I think it's impressive. That's. That's a compliment. But Luna's not having it. She turns to her coworker, guy with a mustache that definitely has its own Instagram account, and goes, he called my swan cool. Mustache. Guy looks at me like I just vandalized the declaration of independence, bro. That's dismissive. I'm standing there holding my swan cappuccino, thinking, when did coffee shops become art galleries? With attitude, I try to backtrack. I'm sorry. I meant it's beautiful. Really skillful. Luna gasped. Skillful? It's not
NA

What's your they didn't realise I could understand their language story? I was adopted from Korea at age 3, but my white American parents made sure I kept learning Korean. Growing up in Texas, no one ever guessed I was fluent. I I was 16 when my high school got a new Korean math teacher, Missus Park. On my first day in her class, she looked surprised to see me, but said nothing. I heard her mutter in Korean, great, another banana. Yellow on the outside, white on the inside. For the next month, she'd make comments about me in Korean during class, thinking I couldn't understand. She called me the fake Korean and the whitewashed one. When I got good grades, she'd say in Korean that I must be cheating because adoptees are usually stupid. Other Korean students in class would laugh at her comments. Some even joined in, making fun of how I use chopsticks wrong or how I couldn't read Hangul. Missus park encouraged it, praising them in Korean for keeping their culture pure. During parent conferences, she switched between perfect English with my parents and Korean with other Korean parents. My parents she praised my performance, but in Korean she told other parents I was a disgrace to our people and that adoption should be banned. One day, she paired me with a Korean student for a project. In Korean, she told him to do all the work because the adopted one will just mess it Up! That's when I'd had enough. I turned to her and said in perfect Korean, I may be adopted, but at least I'm not a bitter teacher who bullies children. Classroom went silent. Missus Park's face turned white. She started stuttering in both languages, trying to explain herself. The Korean students who had laughed at her jokes sank in their seats. Realizing I had understood every insult, I switched to formal Korean. The kind you

They hid my confession to protect their son. So I made them watch him unravel live on TV. They destroyed evidence of their son's crime and left me to rot in juvenile detention. The Maxwell family. Political royalty who thought money could rewrite history. I was sixteen. House party, underage drinking. Typical teenage stupidity. When Emma Rodriguez ended up in a coma from hit and run that night, everything changed. Police found my car with front end damage. I've been drinking. Couldn't remember driving home. Physical evidence pointed to me. Vehicular assault charges followed. But I knew something was wrong. The damage was on the wrong side. Paint transfer didn't match. Three days before trial, I got a USB drive. Security footage showing the real driver, Trevor Maxwell, the mayor's son, drunk, behind the wheel of his father's identical car. Timestamp showed him hitting Emma and swapping cars while I was passed out. Perfect crime. Except for one camera. I gave the video to my public defender. She said it would change everything. Next morning, she called. Video was corrupted, couldn't be used. Suggested a plea deal. The Maxwells had bought her silence. Buried the only evidence that could save me. I took the plea. 18 months in juvenile detention while Trevor walked free. Got into Harvard, started his perfect career. But I made copies of that video. Hidden them everywhere, waiting for the right moment. Trevor became everything his family wanted. State senator at 28, being groomed for governor. I spent 10 years building my case. Financial records showing payments to my lawyer, communications between Trevor and his father, medical evidence proving my innocence. Trevor was running for governor, scheduled for a live debate, watched by Millions. Perfect Platform for truth. I had infiltrated his campaign as volunteer, worked up to social media coordinator. Had access to live stream controls. During commercial break, I uploaded evidence to every platform. The video, financial records, medical reports proving Trevor's guilt and the cover up. Before debate resumed, I texted him. Check your Twitter mention.

I told my ex boyfriend's daughter, it's not my problem. I dated this guy John for 6 months and his 16 year old daughter Tia made my life hell from day one. She called me that bitch every single time she saw me. Told people I broke up her parents marriage even though they divorced 10 years ago, and literally told me I should voluntarily leave this world. When I asked what I could do to make things better, John did absolutely nothing about it. He threatened to ground her or take her phone, but never followed through. Even her mom Chloe tried talking to her, but Tia just said she hated me for no reason. She just didn't. The final straw happened at my house during dinner. I went to pick up our food order and when I came back, John was sweeping up pieces of my grandmother's antique picture. This thing meant everything to me. It was the only thing I had left of her. He looked right at me with this smug little smirk and said, oops, it was an accident. I asked how the hell it was an accident, and she just shrugged. I think I bumped the table and it fell off. That was total bullshit. My dining table weighs like 200 pounds. You'd have to slam into it with your whole body to even make it shake. She broke it on purpose and we both knew it. I told them to leave and spent The whole night crying over the pieces. Called John the next day and broke up with him. He begged me to reconsider, but I was done. I couldn't spend my life walking on eggshells around a kid who wanted to destroy everything I cared about. Fast forward three months to last Tuesday. I'm leaving work, and there's Tia waiting by my car. She looked terrible. Eyes all red, hair a mess, like she'd been crying for hours. She started going off about John's new girlfriend, Jane. Apparently, Jane doesn't put up with Tia's crap like I did. When Tia calls her names, Jane calls her names right back. When Tia and

I threatened my wife with divorce after she quit her job to be a tradwife. So my wife Emma had been sending me these tradwife tik toks for months. You know the ones. Girls in flowy dresses baking bread and talking about serving their husbands. At first I thought it was just some random phase. He'd been married six years, and she'd never shown any interest in that lifestyle before. Emma worked part time at a dental office while I did construction. Between both our jobs, we were doing fine financially. Our kids, Aiden and Bella, were 11 and 9, so they didn't need constant supervision anymore. They were in school most of the day anyway. But Emma kept pushing. She'd show me videos of these women talking about unlimited intimacy and home cooked meals every night. I kept telling her our current setup worked perfectly. She worked mornings, I worked full days, and one of us was always home when the kids got back from school. Two weeks ago, she completely lost it during an argument about this whole thing. She literally said, fine, if you won't appreciate what you'd be getting, then you won't get anything at all. She cut me off completely. No affection, no conversations beyond logistics about the kids. He was treating me like some random roommate who happened to live in her house. I figured she'd get over it. Emma could be dramatic sometimes, but she usually came around after a few days. Boy, Was I wrong about that? Yesterday I came home from a long day pouring concrete in 90 degree heat. I was exhausted, covered in dust, just wanting to shower and maybe watch TV with the family. Instead I found a bunch of gift

What's the funniest way you've ever gotten revenge on a prank call? I kept getting these annoying prank calls from someone pretending to be conducting fake surveys about random stuff. Like, hello, sir, we're conducting a survey about how many socks you own. Or, ma'am, what's your opinion on purple vegetables? After the third call, I was getting pretty annoyed, but then I had a brilliant idea. The next time they called, I was ready. They started with their usual routine. Hello, we're conducting a survey about kitchen appliances. I immediately cut them off and said, oh, perfect timing. I'm actually conducting a survey about prank calling habit. There was a confused pause, and they said, excuse me. What? I said, since you're clearly a prank caller, this is a great opportunity to gather research data. Can you please rate your prank calling technique on a scale of 1 to ten? I tried to deny it, but I pressed on with complete seriousness. Sir, this is for scientific research purposes. I need to document various prank calling methodologies. Now, would you describe your approach as amateur or professional level? The caller was clearly thrown off and actually started answering my questions. They said, well, I guess I'm pretty good at it. Excellent. I said, now can you demonstrate your range of fake voices for my study? They actually started doing different accents like they were auditioning for a voice acting role. I took detailed notes and said, fascinating. Now tell Me. What inspired you to get into prank calling? They spent five minutes explaining how they started prank calling as a hobby in middle school. Very interesting. Now, for research purposes, can you rank your top three prank call? Top. They enthusiastically listed fake surveys, wrong numbers, and pizza delivery pranks. I said, excellent data. Now I need you to demonstrate each technique with a brief example. This person actually started performing different prank call scenarios while I pretended to take scientific notes. 20 minutes into this fake interview, I said, now I need you to rate your own performance today. They said, honestly, this might be my best work. I really felt like I connected with my subject. that's interesting, because technically, you just got reverse prank called. There was dead silence, and I could hear them processing what just happened. They said, wait, you're not actually conducting research? I said, nope, but congratulations.

What's the funniest thing you've ever done to prove a point to your parents? My parents had this annoying habit of shutting down every request I made with the same exact phrase. When you pay rent, you can make the rules. Didn't matter what I asked for your bedtime, different dinner, friends over on weekdays, the answer was always the same. When you pay rent, you can make the rules. I was 14 and getting sick of hearing it, so I decided to take them literally. I started saving. Every birthday dollar, every allowance payment, every lawn mowing job. For three months, I hoarded money like I was planning to buy a car. My parents thought I was being responsible. Little did they know, I was plotting their destruction. I looked up our monthly rent online. Turns out we paid one 2 hundred dollars a month. I counted my savings and had exactly one 2:47 perfect. One Tuesday morning, I walked into the kitchen where my parents were drinking coffee and reading the news. I slammed a stack of cash on the table and said, here's this month's rent payment. My dad nearly choked on his coffee, and my mom just stared at the money. What is this for? I said, well, you always told me when I pay rent, I can make the rules, so I'm paying rent. My dad tried to hand the money back, but I stepped away from the table. Nope. A deal's a deal. I'm Officially a rent paying tenant now. My mom said, honey, we didn't mean it literally. I said, too late. The transaction is complete and as the new co landlord, I'm implementing some house rules. I pulled out a typed list I prepared and started reading my new regulations. Rule No. 1 mandatory family dance time every night at seven PM. No exceptions. Rule No. 2 pizza only Tuesday. We're ordering pizza every Tuesday from now on. Rule number three no news during breakfast. Only cartoons are allowed on the TV. My parents looked at each other like I'd lost my mind. My dad said, this is ridiculous. You can't. I just pay rent and take over the house. I said, actually, according to your own logic, I can. You've been telling me for years that rent equals rule making power. My mom tried reasoning with me. Sweetie, we'll give you the money back. Just stop this. I shook my head. Sorry, but I've already invested in this household. As a paying tenant, I have rights. That night at seven PM, I turned on music and announced it was mandatory family.

What family rule did you break that got you disowned? My family had one rule. Never marry outside our culture. When my sister brought home James, a black song software engineer, my parents smiled politely through dinner, then told her to end it. Nice boy, wrong color, my mother said. My sister chose James. They disowned her that night. Changed the locks while she was at work. Threw her belongings on the lawn. Told the extended family she was dead to us. I was 17. Watched from my window as she picked up her clothes from the wet grass. James helping her load his car. My parents stood in the doorway like guards. Wanted to help, but my father grabbed my shoulder. You go out there, you don't come back either. For three years, I played the good son. Went to the right college, dated the right girls. Same religion, same skin color, same last names our grandparents would recognize. Sent my parents photos of every approved girlfriend, like trophies. Meanwhile, I had a secret phone. Called my sister every week. She was happy, really happy. James treated her like gold. They had a tiny apartment, but filled it with laughter. She was in nursing school. He got promoted twice. I miss you, she'd say. I miss you, too. It's okay. Graduate first, get independent. Then we'll figure it out. Senior year, my parents introduced me to perfect on paper. Right family, right background. Father owned hotels. The wedding was Planned before we'd had three dates. Two weeks before the wedding, my sister called. I'm pregnant. My heart broke. My parents first grandchild. And they'd never know. Unless. At our rehearsal dinner with 200 relatives watching. I stood up for the toast, pulled out my phone. Before I marry Praia, everyone should see who's missing. I projected the photo on the wall. My sister and James at their wedding. Her in scrubs. At graduation, them holding ultrasound pictures. The room went silent. My

What happened when you dated someone out of your league? Everyone knew Alexis Parker was untouchable. Investment banker at 28, drove a Tesla, lived in a penthouse. I fixed her AC unit when her buildings regular guy was sick. She watched me work, typing on her laptop, worth more than my monthly rent. When I finished, she said, you're different from the usual repair guys. Because I didn't hit on you? Because you noticed my MIT diploma and didn't suddenly get weird about it. Talked for an hour. She was brilliant, but lonely. Rich people, she said, only saw her money. Poor people only saw her money. Everyone saw her money. What do you see? She asked. Someone whose AC was broken. She laughed. A real laugh, not the polite one rich people do. Started texting me about random broken things. Dishwasher, cabinet door, flickering light. Half weren't even broken. I knew she knew I knew. We both pretended otherwise. One night she called crying. My engagement party is tomorrow. What parents arranged it? He's perfect on paper. Harvard Law, family money. Knows which fork to use. But? But he's never fixed anything with his hands. Never had to. Wouldn't know how. I showed up at her engage party in my only suit. Told everyone I was fixing the wine cooler. Her fiance, Christopher Hale, kept calling me the help. Alexis found me in the kitchen. You came? Your wine cooler is not actually broken. I know. She kissed me. Right there. Catering staff everywhere. This is insane, I said. My whole life is insane. You're the only real thing in it. We dated in secret for three months. She'd come to my studio apartment, amazed I could cook actual food, not just order it. I'd go to her penthouse, amazed anyone needed three bathrooms for one person. Her parents found out when her mother saw us at Home Depot. Alexis was helping me pick tile for a job. Her mother

Have you ever been banned from a drive through for being too polite? I'm at McDonald's at 2:00am. Not because I have my life together, but because I was up gooning to productivity videos and realized I hadn't eaten anything except sadness and energy drinks for 12 hours. I pull up to the drive through speaker and this voice comes through. Sound like it's been filtered through three layers of defeat and a broken dreams machine. What you want? Not welcome to McDonald's or how can I help you? Just pure, pure existential exhaustion in four words. So I respond the way my mom raised me. Good evening. Could I please get a Big Mac meal with a Coke? Thank you so much. Silence. Dead silence. Like I just spoke ancient Latin. What? A Big Mac meal, please, with a Coke. Thank you. More silence then. Why are you talking like that? I blink. Like what? All fancy and stuff. You making fun of me? No, I'm just ordering food. Nobody talks that polite at 2:00am. You being sarcastic? Ma'am, I said please and thank you. That's not sarcasm. That's basic human decency. But she's not having it. Hold on. I sit there for five minutes wondering if being raised with manners is now considered a hate crime. She comes back. My manager wants to talk to you. A new voice appears. Male, tired. Sounds like he's been managing teenagers since the Clinton administration. Sir, my employee says you're being Disrespectful? I said please and thank you. Right, but the way you said it was condescending. I'm getting accused of weaponizing politeness, like I'm some kind of manners terrorist. I was just trying to be nice. I explained. See, that's the problem. Nobody's that nice at 2:00am unless they're up to something. Up to something? I'm up to diabetes and poor life choices. That's what 2:00am McDonald's is for. Sir, I just want a burger. And I just want customers who don't mock my staff with fake politeness. Fake politeness? I've been accused of many things, but never artificial courtesy. How would you like me to order? I ask normal, like everyone else. What does normal sound like? Just say what you want. No fancy words. So I try again. Big Mac meal. Coke. Better, but lose the attitude. What attitude?

What toxic family tradition did you break that cost you everything? My Jewish family had a tradition called the debt book. Every child born into our family got their own Ledger on their first birthday. Every expense, diapers, food, clothes, school supplies, medical bills got logged with interest. On your 18th birthday, you were presented with your total debt. Mine was $247,000. Family takes care of family, my father would say. But family also pays family back. The tradition went back four generations. My great grandfather started it during the depression, supposedly to teach financial responsibility. Every adult child paid their parents back in monthly installments. Some took decades to clear their debt. My older brother Jake signed his repayment contract at 18, dropped out of college to work construction. 10 years later, still paying. My sister Maria became a nurse specifically because medical professionals pay off debt faster. When my 18th birthday approached, I did something nobody had ever done. I research. Found out child support is a parent's legal obligation. Not alone discovered that charging your children for their upbringing might actually be illegal. Learned that financial abuse is a real thing. The night of my birthday party, the whole extended family gathered. 50 relatives waiting to witness another debt book signing. My parents presented my Ledger like it was an honor. Two hundred forty seven thousand, one hundred eighty two dollars and sixty three cents. My father announced, very reasonable, Uncle Rob

What's the darkest thing your family ever did? My cousin Tommy weighed nearly 300 pounds by eighth grade. Kids at school were brutal about it, but at family gatherings, we never mentioned his size. He was just Tommy, the gentle giant who helped grandma pull weeds, always let the younger cousins win at board games, and laughed like a foghorn when something genuinely made him happy. He was everyone's favourite. Every Friday night, our entire family would gather at my aunt's house for dinner. That night, like always, Tommy was sitting cross legged on the floor playing Mario Kart with my little brother, while whiskers, our 17 year old family cat, slept in his usual warm spot near the sliding glass door. Whiskers was ancient. He had survived two house moves, four new babies, and more toddler tailpulls than any living creature should have to endure. We all joked he'd outlive us. Out of nowhere, my little brother came racing in with his new remote control car, zigzagging through the living room like a maniac, showing off to everyone. The car flew right under Tommy's legs. Just as he started getting up to grab a second plate of pizza, his foot caught on the corner of the carpet. He lost his balance. I watched it all in slow motion. His arms flailed his face, and then came the soft, dull crunch when he landed. Most people didn't even hear it, but I did. Whiskers didn't move. He didn't hiss. He Didn't cry. Just silent. The whole room froze. Tommy stayed on the floor, pale as a ghost, whispering no over and over while his eyes filled with tears. My dad crossed the room and gently picked up whiskers, wrapping him in the fleece blanket from the recliner, the one whiskers always curled up on. My mom quietly ushered the rest of us into the kitchen. From behind the doorway, I could see Tommy sitting there, shoulders heaving as he sobbed. My aunt knelt beside him, rubbing his back and trying to hold it together. But even she looked shattered. That blanket never came back. By the time we left that night, every trace of whiskers was gone. His toys, his bed, the food and water bowls by the fridge. It was like someone hit delete on his whole existence. We never talked about it again. No one.

Have you ever been accused of cheating on a test you didn't even take? So here's the situation. I have an identical twin, Marcus. We look exactly the same, sound the same, even have the same weird cow lick that makes us look like we got electrocuted by the same toaster. The only difference is he's the smart one, and I'm the one who once tried to microwave a Pop Tart. Still in the wrapper. We're both seniors, but we take completely different classes. He's in AP everything that makes your brain hurt. I'm in regular human classes for people who think algebra might be a country. Last Tuesday, I'm sitting in my criminal justice class. And yes, the irony will become clear when my teacher, Mister Rodriguez, walk. Then, looking like someone stole his lunch money and his dignity, he slams a stack of papers on his desk and says, we need to talk about academic integrity. I'm thinking, cool, a lecture about not copying homework. Time for a nap. But then he locks eyes with me. Just me. Like I personally betrayed him and his entire family lineage. You, he says, pointing directly at my soul office. Now I look around, confused. Me? What did I do? Don't play dumb, sir. I'm not playing anything. This is just my face. So I follow him to his office, and he pulls out a test paper. But here's the thing. It's not from his class. It's from AP Physics. You Know, the class I've never taken, would never take, and couldn't pass if my life depended on it? He slides it across the desk. Explain this. I stare at the paper. It's got my name on it. Well, technically, it says M. Johnson, but we have the same last name, same first initial. And the handwriting looks exactly like mine. Because it's Marcus's handwriting. Because we're twins. Because genetics is a thing. Mr. Rodriguez, I say slowly, I don't take physics. Leans back in his chair like he just caught me in the lie of the century. Really? Then how do you explain getting a perfect score on yesterday's quantum mechanics exam? I blink. I don't even know what quantum mechanics means. I thought it was a type of car repair. He's not buying it. He pulls out another paper. This one's from AP Calculus. Also signed M. Johnson. Also, my brother's identical.

Call the cops on my eight year old daughter? So I made his life a living hell. We moved into our house three years ago, and everything was perfect until Logan moved in next door six months later. He's maybe 35, works from home doing something with cryptocurrency, and has way too much time to monitor everyone else. No trespassing signs every five feet along his fence. Guy even painted his grass with some kind of spray to make it look more green, which was weird, but whatever. My daughter Zoe plays in our backyard all the time. She's 8, loves soccer, and kicks the ball around for hours. The yards are separated by one of those low, decorative fences, maybe two feet high. And sometimes her ball goes over like any normal kid. She'd hop over, grab it, and hop back. Takes literally ten seconds. Last Tuesday, Zoe was playing when her ball went over Logan's fence. She hopped over to get it, and I watched from the kitchen window as Logan came storming out of his house. He started screaming at her. I could hear him yelling about property rights and respect for boundaries at an eight year old. I ran outside and told Logan to back off. Zoe was crying and ran inside. I explained that kids sometimes chase balls. It's not a big deal, and asked him to not yell at my daughter. Logan got up in my face and said, your little brat needs to Learn boundaries. This is my property, and I don't want her stepping foot on it ever again. I told him she was just getting her ball and would be more careful, but he wasn't having it. Then yesterday came, so he was playing again when her ball went over. She looked at me through the window, and I nodded. It's a ball, for crying out loud. She hopped over, grabbed it, and started hopping back. That's when Logan appeared with his phone already dialing. I couldn't believe it. I ran outside as Zoe came back, confused and scared because this grown man was on the phone with the police about her. 20 minutes later, a police car pulled up the office

Doctor said I was lucky I didn't lose my vision. For the first few days, I felt terrible for Emma. She was absolutely destroyed. She barely ate, couldn't sleep, kept apologizing every five minutes. I could see how guilty she felt, and I genuinely didn't want her to torture herself over it. It was an accident, right? She didn't mean to almost kill me over a spider. But then I started thinking about it more. I talked to Tyler and his girlfriend, who saw the whole thing. They said it wasn't just, like, a quick reaction. She grabbed that candle holder and kept hitting me. Even after the spider was obviously gone. Even after I was bleeding and unconscious on the deck. The burns healed slowly. Every morning, I'd look in the mirror and see these angry red marks all over my face. People at work would stare, and I'd have to explain that my fiance accidentally burned my face off because of a spider. It sounded insane, even saying it out loud. Three weeks later, we were having dinner, and Emma was telling me about her day when a fly landed on the table. Just a regular house fly. She saw it and immediately grabbed a kitchen knife. Not to kill the fly. She was holding it like she was ready to stab something. The look in her eyes was the same look Tyler described from that night. That's when it hit me. This wasn't just about being afraid. Of bugs. Something was seriously wrong here. And I was the one who was going to pay for it next time. I sat her down the next day and told her I thought we should call off the engagement. I tried to be gentle about it. I said I didn't blame her, and I didn't want her to blame herself either. But I couldn't risk going through something like that again. She completely

What's the most ridiculous reason you've been called suspicious? So I'm at the park on a Wednesday because my roommate brought his Twitch E girl home, and I'd rather touch grass than hear him raising up someone who sounds like a squeaky toy. I find a bench, pull out my fantasy novel about dragons and emotional damage, and start reading like a normal human being. Everything's peaceful. Then this woman power walks over. Let's call her Karen, because the universe has a sense of humor. She's got that I peaked in high school and manage a Facebook neighborhood watch energy. She stops in front of me, hands on her hips like she caught me selling drugs. Excuse me, she says, but what exactly are you doing here? I look up from my book. Reading. She squints at me like I just spoke ancient sumerian. Reading what? I show her the cover. It's got a dragon and some dude with a sword. That's suspicious, she declares. I blink. Reading fantasy is suspicious? No, she says, pulling out her phone like she's about to call the FBI. Reading alone in public on a Wednesday? Ma'am, when did literacy become a crime? Should I've brought a reading buddy? Do I need a permit for solo book consumption? It's weird, she continues. Normal. Normal people don't just sit in parks reading books. I look around. What's the most insane coincidence that's ever happened to you? I was flying to Chicago for a job interview when my flight got delayed for six hours. I'm sitting at the gate feeling sorry for myself when this old man next to me starts having trouble breathing. Everyone's just staring, so I help him sit down and get him some water. He thanks me and we start talking to pass the time. He tells me he's flying to see his grandson graduate college. But he's nervous because they haven't spoken in 15 years. Apparently, his son died in a car accident. He blamed his daughter in law for it. He said some horrible things and she moved across the country with his grandson. He's been trying to reach out for years, but she won't return his calls. He finally decided to just show up at the graduation ceremony. I felt bad for him and told him about my own situation. How I was flying to interview for my dream job. But I was terrified because I've been unemployed for eight months and this was my last shot. We spent hours talking and he gave me advice about staying confident. When our flight finally boarded, we exchanged numbers and I wish each other luck. Three days later, I'm sitting in the waiting room for my interview and the receptionist calls my name. I walk into the office and nearly fall over. The hiring manager is the same old man from the Airport. We both just stare at each other in complete shock. He starts laughing and asks how Chicago treated me. I tell him I was too nervous to really see the city, but meeting him made the trip worthwhile. He looks at me seriously and says he has to ask me something before we start the interview. He wants to know if I still think he should go to his grandson's graduation. I tell him absolutely, and that life's too short to hold grudges. He smiles and tells me I'm hired. Then he pulls out his phone and shows me a picture from the weekend. It's him hugging a young man in a cap and gown. He went to the graduation and his grandson ran up and hugged him the moment he saw him. His daughter in law had been hoping he'd come for year.

I gave my future mother in law three days to pay me for a new wedding dress or else I show the family a photo of her wearing it. So I'm getting married to my fiance in 6 weeks. I saved up for months to buy this gorgeous dress, $3,000. That took me forever to save working at a coffee shop while going to school. My future mother in law kept bugging me about trying it on since the day I brought it home. She'd text me constantly asking when she could see it. She'd show up to our apartment unannounced asking to peek at it. She even offered me a hundred bucks to let her try it on just once. I kept saying no because honestly, something felt off about how obsessed she was. Like, who gets that excited about someone else's wedding dress? My fiance thought I was being dramatic. He kept saying his mom just loves weddings and she's excited for us. But I stood my ground. The dress stays in my closet until my wedding day. Last Tuesday, I came home from my shift early because we were slow. I walked into our apartment and immediately heard my fiance panicking upstairs. He was texting someone frantically and blocking me from going to our bedroom. That's when I knew something was seriously wrong. I, I pushed past him and opened the door. There she was, his mother standing in front of my mirror wearing my wedding dress. My 3,000 dollar dress that I specifically told her she couldn't even look at. She had somehow gotten it on perfectly. The zipper was done up and everything. She was posing and taking selfies in it like it was some kind of photo shoot. When she saw me, her face went completely white. I pulled out my phone and snapped a picture before either of them could stop me. He started yelling at me to delete it, but I was already backing it up to the cloud. My fiance jumped in trying to calm everyone down saying it was just harmless fun and no damage was done. But I felt sick looking at the dress knowing she had been in it, taking pictures, probably planning to show all her friends. The whole thing felt violated. I told them both she had three days to Venmo me $3,000 for a replacement dress or I'm sending that photo to every single person in their family. Group chat, she burst into tears saying I was being cruel and that she just wanted to feel connected to our wedding. My fiance said I was overreact.

I wanted my daughter's boyfriend, slash soon to be fiance, to know her dark secret before marriage. My daughter Emma is 25 and absolutely beautiful, not just physically, but she's charming in a way that makes everyone want to be around her. She's got this perfect smile and this laugh that makes guys lose their minds. Her boyfriend, Tyler, is head over heels for her. The poor guy follows her around like a lost puppy and talks about her like she hung the moon. But here's the thing, nobody knows. Emma is a diagnosed sociopath, has been since she was 18, though I knew something was off way before that. When she was 8, she locked her little sister Mia in the basement for three hours just to see what would happen. When I found Mia crying and scared in the dark, Emma was upstairs watching TV like nothing happened. When I asked her why she did it, she just shrugged and said she was curious. No tears, no sorry, nothing. School was a nightmare. Teachers called constantly about Emma lying to get other kids in trouble, stealing lunch money. And once she convinced a boy to eat glue by telling him it was candy. The counselor said she was just going through a phase, but I knew better. After years of therapy and medication, Emma Learned how to act normal. She, she studied other people like a science project, copying their emotions until she could fake them perfectly by High school, she was popular, dated constantly and had everyone fooled. The diagnosis came when she was 18, antisocial personality disorder. The doctor explained it in fancy terms, but basically Emma doesn't feel love, guilt or empathy. She can't. Her brain just doesn't work that way. We've had honest conversations about it since then. When her best friend died in a car accident last year, Emma cried at the funeral and gave this heartbreaking speech later that night. She told me she felt absolutely nothing. The whole thing was an act because that's what people expected. She's been with Tyler for almost two years now. He's a good guy, works as a teacher, volunteers at animal shelters, brings me coffee when he visits. He talks about marrying Emma constantly. Last week, he asked me for my blessing to propose. That's when I told Emma she needs to tell him the truth or I will. She laughed and said I'd never have the guts. She thinks I'm bluffing because she's my daughter and I love her. But Tyler deserves to know what he's signing up for. Emma flat out told me she doesn't love him, never has and never will. She likes the stability he provides and thinks he'll be a good father if they have kids. To her, marriage is just a business transaction. When I brought it up again yesterday, Emma got that cold look.

People who bought a house, what is the weirdest thing you have found left by the previous owner? One first time I took a hot shower in our new home, the steam covered the mirror only to reveal the phrase, hello, I see you in large finger drawn writing. It freaked me out for a second but made me laugh soon after that. It was such an inconspicuous yet obvious thing to leave for the new homeowner. Me. Two, wasn't a purchase, but I was showing a house to a couple and we couldn't believe the reported square footage. It looked like a nice 1,700 square foot house in a semi rural community, but the square footage on the listing said about 4,500. I was sure it was a typo. Turns out most of it was in the basement. Think Buffalo Bills basement. That just goes on and on with random rooms. The place was vacant. The lighting wasn't great. We got to a dead end room down there and turned on the lights and there was this porcelain doll just chilling in the middle of the room. Only thing left in the house. Husband yells, screw this, and we all run out. We ruled out that whole neighborhood as an option for obvious reasons. 3, $1,200 in cash above the door on the inside of the closet. I found it while painting. 4, we bought a house being foreclosed on. We gave him an extra month after closing in. 2000 to help with his move. Still had to have the sheriff come to remove him. Anywho, I was doing some clean up and remodeling before we moved in. The whole house was carpeted. When I started ripping it out, there was a giant blood stain that started in a downstairs spare bedroom and then trailed up to the master bath where there was another stain. His wife had left him. So I had to call the realtor to find out if anyone knew where she was. Turns out he had taken out a deer in the yard and gutted it in the house. What a hassle. Had to rip up and install new sub floors. My vegan ex wife was not thrilled. 5. The property my wife and I moved to three years ago had a bucket full of wrapped Dinosaur bones. Took them to our local museum where they confirm they are roughly 68 million years old. Hadrosaur. Pretty cool. 6. We bought the house from the CEO of the company which we franchise from. It was her childhood home where her mother lived until the day she passed. In true rich person fashion, they didn't care to clean out the house before selling it. They just told us we can do whatever we want with the old lady stuff that was there. We found a hidden box of spicy letters from the old lady to her secret partner spanning many years. That was fun to give to the CEO 7, my uncle was renovating the house that he bought for his chiropractic practice. And when he knocked down a wall to enlarge a room, a few dozen pill bottles fell to the floor. They were each filled with about 25 US silver dollars, which at the time were worth more like $6 in silver each. So it was about $5,000 in vintage coins. 8, that they wired a room by connecting the outlet with an extension cord inside the wall. 9, a diary of an American soldier in World War 2 South Pacific Theater found it above a door when remodeling 20+ years ago. My wife and I tried everything we could think of to find a descendant, but to no avail. Ten, a basement room that was fully decked out as a dungeon. Fake stone walls, a stocks like where you lock your head and hands in Old England. Candle scones on the walls, a metal barred cage in the corner from floor to ceiling. Oh, and the closet had a load of toys, some normal, some not so normal. 11, an entire tribe of raccoons living in the attic.

Which memorable Reddit post slash comment can you still not get over? One. The grandma who used coconut oil on her granddaughter who was extremely allergic and passed from it. As someone who works with toddlers, that story is a nightmare. Grandma nonchalantly caused the passing of her granddaughter. Not because she didn't know about the allergy, because she just didn't think it was a big deal. And in no time flat, a toddler is gone and two parents and two surviving siblings are forever traumatized. And grandma can't figure out why her daughter won't see her two. It wasn't as memorable or as big as most Reddit comments, but one has stuck with me. I forgot what the question was, but this guy commented that he was asked to bring like two gallons of milk to his girlfriend's family dinner. He thought, oh, they must really like milk. When he arrived, each family member had their own gallon of milk, and when dinner was served they all just started guzzling their own milk like animals. I need to try finding that. It was hilarious. 3 the one where the guy had an imaginary girlfriend, later wife, who was a giant cockroach, and his coworkers eventually found out that he had a whole fantasy life with his life size cockroach girlfriend slash wife. Four people seem to regularly post what Reddit post can't you get over? And I always drop in to say the pregnant woman whose husband and father In law decided she'd pass in labor and we're doing all the planning for that to happen. She never updated and I always wonder and worry a little. Wish I'd save the post. 5 the guy who was looking for legal advice because his landlord was sneaking in and leaving him notes while he was sleeping and someone in the comment section saved his life by realizing he was actually suffering carbon monoxide poisoning. Six the lady on ADA who unplugged her fridge to deep clean it while her husband had a box in there who told her to not open the box. I frequently wonder what was in the box. 7 the dude that bought a house with his GF and wasn't allowed upstairs. I want an update to this more than any unsolved mystery. 8 the guy who caught his wife cheating thanks to his Dyson fan epic. 9 the guy who Rick rolled Rick Astley.

What is the longest you've gone without knowing a person's name? 1. I moved into my condo in 2011 and I introduced myself to my one neighbor next door to me but instantly forgot his name. We would see each other in passing for years and I would always just say hi and the casual conversation. I met my wife in 2018 from a long distance relationship. When she finally moved in with me, there was an awkward moment when I introduced her to him. I said this is my fiance and we're getting married next month. He said congratulations and nice to meet you, then walked away. She asked me what his name was and I said I have no clue. Later that day she said his name was Brad. And I was like, oh, he looks like a Brad. And she said he had no clue what my name was either, so no big deal. 2. 2 years. I used to be a club promoter and I had a guy that bought tickets for me for every event he went to. He told me his name when I first met him, but I forgot it soon after he told me. Meeting lots of people makes it hard to remember names, especially when I don't even know if I'll ever see them again. So what's the point of remembering everyone's names after a certain point? I saw him out partying often enough, but it was past the point where I could ask him his name without it being awkward. I had him saved in my phone as Sir Prince Albert since he told me about his piercing so that I'd know who was texting me if we ever texted each other. But I didn't think to add his name since I wasn't sure what it was. So that was no help. Eventually we ended up at a party together and some people walked in and asked, hey, have you seen Phil? After not remembering meeting anyone that night named Phil, I said, no, I don't think there's a Phil here. Then that guy whose name I couldn't remember came up and joined the group and said, I'm right here. Don't worry, these guys are cool. I invited them. At that moment, I finally found out his name and I played it off as, oh, okay, well, if they are your friends, then I guess it's cool if they stay and just went with it. 3. A whole school year I knew their names. I just didn't know which twin was which and they weren't identical. 4. My name is apparently Darren to this nice couple who own a restaurant in my town. My name is not Darren. I've known them for two years. We're even FB friends. They can literally see and read my name. But it's cool. I always wanted to try being a Darren. 5. I've lived in my townhouse for almost five years now and I Don't know the name of the guy who lives directly across from me. I have pretty regular interactions with most of my neighbors, but I've never talked with this one guy beyond just exchanging pleasantries while passing each other. When I moved in and first met him, I immediately forgot his name. I was almost positive he said it was Mike. So I went about four years just assuming that was probably his name, but not quite confident enough to actually call him Mike. Then a few months ago, I was talking to some other neighbors in the parking lot when he walked by and my other neighbors called out, hey. So it was confirmed that this guy's name is not, in fact, Mike. And I was relieved. I hadn't been calling him that for the past 5 years. But I immediately forgot again what his name actually is. So now all I know is that it is something other than Mike. Maybe I'll learn his name by the time I've lived here 10 years. Six, a whole date. Someone fixed us up, but my dude never told me her name, just the address. She wanted me to pick her up. I didn't have the guts to ask her name between the date. She became a longtime GF after that date and we laughed about it. 7. My nickname in college was the mayor and I had people I had known for years coming up to me at my graduation. Saying, I had no idea your name was actually Dan.

What's a women's thing? Men should absolutely start doing one. As a former cook and current welder, hand motioning. My dad refused to use hand lotion for a while and he kept getting big cracks in his knuckles. The cold would destroy his skin. He would only put lotion on when it was basically bleeding, by which point it can't really do much help. Moisturize. To steal from Bill Burr, guys, you can put lotion on places other than your weapon. It still looks brand new while the rest of you looks like an aging pirate. You need to increase the circumference of the lotion distribution. 2, going to the doctor before it's too late. I am a doctor and seriously, the wives are always dragging them in there. That was my mom with my dad. He got sick, wasn't eating enough, didn't want to go to the doctor, collapsed in the kitchen and then she had to call 911. Turned out to be sepsis and he almost passed. Married men live like five years longer than unmarried men or something like that because of their wives forcing them to be seen. 3. Squat in the shower and reach under my dude. Pro tip, use hair conditioner when shaving any body part that isn't your face. It's much better than shaving foam but does make things slipper. So be careful. Also, if you shave your butt, prepare for an unholy swamp butt. I refuse to shave my butt anymore because The grow back is horrific. Four, my husband never really did pedicures before we met and the first time I did one for him, he was in love with it. I used a scraper to get the dead skin off his heels. He calls them hooves. Haha. And he was horrified at how much came off. He'll even inspect my work now and say this toenail is a little jagged. Do want me to look a messy? He likes being pampered. I'm happy to do it for him. 5. I was trying on jeans for work the other day and I found this magical material that stretches but looks like denim. I was gushing over them and my wife laughed and said a lot of women's jeans use that material and a lot of hers are the same. Men should discover these jeans. 6. A man started carrying a satchel years ago and never looked back. I mean, Indiana Jones has one. I'm a new man. Breath stinky. Boom. Here's some gum. Headache, boom. Here's a pill. Phone dead. Boom. Here's a charger. My little bag carries so much and has saved me so many times. 7. Separate shampoo, conditioner and body wash. 8, making an effort to make their home smell nice. The way you clean, taking a shower does not actually clean your shower. Washing your bedding with more frequency, buy a few candles, etc. You will feel more relaxed at home. And clean sheets are better for Your skin and health. 9, buying clothes when they should be replaced. I see so many men with holes in their socks and shirts with stretched collars. Please just get new ones instead of putting it off. Lol. 10. Prior girlfriends and now my wife have said I should sand my feet. Calluses off his office office. I'm in work boots all day and they get dried, crack and bleed. Now I have this cheese grater thing that I use occasionally and rub lotion on my feet a few times a week. I'm happy to no longer bleed from my feet as it is quite painful to work with open sores on my feet. I do miss having Spider Man feet that had these little Velcro like hooks on them that I'd rub on her legs to annoy her while in bed. I could attach to the sheets and move them with the bottom of my feet. Hey, 11 p. Sitting down.

I refused to wake up my husband when my parents visited. And kicking them out when they insisted. My husband Tyler, had been working 18 hour days for three weeks straight. Some department at his company completely screwed up and cost them $50 million. So his team had to fix everything. I'm talking coming home at two in the morning, eating cold leftovers, showering and passing out. Some nights I'd find him literally sleeping face first in his dinner plate or passed out on the bathroom floor with the shower still running. Two nights ago, he finally stumbled through the door around midnight with this huge grin on his exhausted face. We did it, he said. Boss gave us the rest of the week off. He ate some leftover pizza, took the world's quickest shower and was snoring before his head hit the pillow. Next morning around 9, I made breakfast but let him sleep. Poor guy looked like a zombie for weeks. Around noon, my parents showed up unannounced. I'm six months pregnant, so they visit sometimes to check on me. We're sitting there having coffee when my mom asks where Tyler is. Since his truck's in the driveway, he's still sleeping, I said. My mom's face went all pinched. It's past noon. That's unacceptable with a pregnant wife. Wake him up. I explained the whole situation. Three weeks of hell. Fifty million dollar crisis. Barely any sleep. My dad just shook his head like Tyler was some lazy bum. I'm not waking him up, I said. He needs to rest. Well, if you won't do it, I will, my mom said, standing up and heading for the stairs. I jumped up and blocked her path. If you can't respect my husband getting proper sleep after three weeks of torture, then you need to leave our house now. Are you kicking us out? My dad asked, all shocked. Yes, get out! They left, all huffy and dramatic. Within an hour, my phone was blowing up, my sister texting me, I'm an ungrateful bitch. My bro

I lost my shit and screamed at my girlfriend to get out of my house after what her stepbrother did. My girlfriend Taylor and I were both 20, and things had been going pretty solid between us for about eight months. She had this stepbrother, Ethan, who was 23. And honestly, the few times I'd met him before, he seemed like a normal dude. Maybe a little too friendly, but nothing that set off major alarm bells. Two weeks ago, Taylor asked if Ethan could come hang out at my place for a few hours. She said he was bringing pizza and beer, and since my parents were visiting my aunt for the weekend, I figured, why not? My little sister Mia is 15, and she was just gonna stay upstairs doing homework anyway. So they showed up around 7. Ethan had this huge grin and two cases of beer. We started drinking and playing video games, just chilling on the couch. Everything was normal for, like, an hour. Taylor was curled up next to me. Ethan was cracking jokes about the game, and I was thinking, this was actually pretty fun. Then Ethan said he needed to use the bathroom. I pointed down the hall to the one on the first floor. Taylor and I kept playing, and I didn't even notice how long he'd been gone until we heard yelling upstairs. My blood went cold. Mia never yells. We both jumped up and ran upstairs, and I found My sister standing in her doorway crying, like full on sobbing. Ethan was right there in the hallway looking all flustered and red in the face. I immediately asked Mia what happened and she could barely get the words out between sobs. She said Ethan had walked into her room even though her door was only cracked open a little. She thought maybe he was lost looking for the bathroom, so she tried to be polite and tell him it was downstairs.

What happened when my parents blamed me for my brother's chaos? When I turned eighteen, my parents sat me down for what they called a long overdue conversation. You need to move out, mom announced. Every disaster in this house happens because you're constantly provoking Gonzales. I stared in disbelief while my 14 year old brother Gonzales sat there looking innocent. The kitchen fire last week, the destroyed laptop, the hole in the garage door. It's always when you two are together. We need peace. You have two weeks to find somewhere else to live. Gonzalez smiled sweetly. I just want our family to be safe, he said, hiding behind my parents backs as he mouth goodbye. Fine. If they wanted me to stop protecting them from Hurricane Gonzalez, I'd wish them good luck. The day after I moved out, Gonzalez decided to upgrade the house's electrical system. Every light in the neighborhood now flickered in rhythm with our toaster. When mom tried to make toast. It activated the garage door, the ceiling fans, and somehow started Dad's car. The power company had to shut down our entire grid and rewire our house. The Bill was $3,000. It's synchronized living, Gonzalez explained proudly to the electrician. Next, he discovered online chemistry tutorials without me. Secretly replacing his chemicals with baking soda, he created what he called rainbow smoke bombs in the kitchen. But they were actually just straight up acid that ate through the tiles and corrupted all the food. Hazmat had to gut our kitchen entirely. Total cost $8,000. Why didn't you tell us this would happen? Mom yelled at me through the phone. I did. You just never listened. I reminded her. Then Gonzales revealed he'd been training squirrels in the attic. They're my army, he explained, as 20 squirrels wearing tiny tin foil hats ended through the ceiling during Dad's Zoom meeting with his boss. Dad got fired on the spot. Then came the car improvement incident. Gonzalez filled Dad's gas tank with what he called Super Juice, a mixture of energy drinks, lighter fluid, and glitter. The car made

My girlfriend's dad said I couldn't appreciate their Italian family values, so I showed him real tradition. The first time I met Angela's father, he served everyone homemade wine, but handed me store bought beer. He said something in Italian to his brother while smiling at me, and Angela told me he was praising my manners, but I caught one word I recognized. Americano. American. My stomach dropped because his tone didn't match Angela's translation at all. That night, I downloaded a language app. We've been dating two years. I figured I had time to prove myself. Three months later, I understood basic phrases, but sounded terrible trying to speak. Easter dinner, her father kept switching between English and Italian. He'd say something nice in English, like he seems responsible, then immediately say something in Italian that made his brothers laugh. I understood non capisce niente doesn't understand anything. Then Mangia come un Bambino eats like a child. I just sat there pretending I didn't understand. Angela asked me later why I was so quiet. I told her I was just overwhelmed. She's squeeze my hand and said her dad was warming up to me. I wanted to laugh, but I needed him to think I was clueless. By month six, I understood most conversations, but sounded awful when I tried to speak. My tutor kept making me repeat the same phrases over and over. She told me my comprehension was great, but my accent was rough. Angela worked Saturday Mornings, I was actually at the Italian American Center learning traditional cooking from this nonna named Rosaria. She was tough but honest. Told me I understood like an adult, but cooked like a child. Month eight, almost ruined everything. Angela found my Italian workbook with hundreds of pages of notes. The worst part was that I've been documenting phrases I heard. Vocabulary practice. She went through them excitedly. She suggested maybe I could say Grace in Italian at Christmas. I agreed, knowing I was planning way more than that. Month 10, her father started switching to Italian mid conversation. Whenever I walked in the room, he'd wave and say it was family business, but he was getting more dismissive. He told his brother, America
